Contrary to some narratives, it is genuinely not the intention of any professional and ethical collection agency or firm to pursue collections from individuals who do not owe the debt, yet this challenge is tough to tackle without effective communication between the misidentified party and the collector.

I'm afraid you're incorrect in believing that debt collectors lack the ability to alter details in your credit report. Indeed, they have the capability to do so, and they actively engage in these updates. Consider this: if my account has been transferred multiple times to different parties and the original creditor no longer holds ownership, how would the entity that bought the account (the debt collector) manage to revise or report it? Furthermore, those responsible for providing information to credit bureaus are indeed capable of delivering false data. This is precisely why debt collectors end up facing legal action.

Larry S, your remark..."A plaintiff in a lawsuit should not be put in a position where it is profitable to sue with little justification and minimal risk," is a striking assertion and one I completely concur with. This situation encourages debt collectors to employ disreputable service companies who might falsely claim to have performed legal services or substitute services, and seemingly escape consequences. I have personally fallen victim to two fraudulent substitute services. I suspect that both incidents were carried out by the same service company.

My cell phone is bombarded with at least four collection calls daily meant for some unknown individual. I've continuously informed them that this number doesn't belong to that person. I've recently acquired a new phone number. and it's incredibly frustrating to have to screen calls due to someone else's issues.

I believe the duration for validation needs to be revised. As a consumer, I have a 30-day window from the date on the letter to contest the debt, yet, the collection agency is not bound by this and can take an indefinite period, even years, to respond to the consumer. This approach is not only detrimental but it also involves charging interest on the debt, without labeling it as such (referred to as "fees"), during the time they claim to be 'investigating' it. If I'm restricted to 30 days, the collection agency should equally have a 30-day limit to respond, no exceptions.
Primary parties ought to retain the ability to initiate legal action when they find it warranted. I am comfortable with this regulation as long as it targets third-party debt purchasers.

In numerous states, a debt collection law firm is only required to submit a complaint. The typical consumer is often unaware of the distinction between a balance and a total sum. They lack the knowledge to compute interest and are unfamiliar with what is deemed "legal" under state or Federal Credit Card Act constraints. The Plaintiff's name might be completely unfamiliar to them. Their understanding is limited to knowing they have some debt and have missed payments. Frequently, they choose not to respond at all.

I think what is considered reasonable can vary based on the specific situation of the disagreement and the nature of the debt involved. It is advisable to develop an official checklist tailored to different circumstances and allow the analyst examining the dispute to append comments to this checklist, which would then be included in the eoscar record.

A universal Statute of Limitations should be established. The existing system is utterly chaotic. Some 17 states enforce a three to four-year Statute of Limitations (SOL), whereas 19 states adhere to a six-year limit. Others vary, with some states allowing SOL to extend up to 10 years. Tolling provisions further complicate the situation. It should be simplified. Implement a unified NATIONAL Statute of Limitations. Ensure it is equitable for both debt collectors and debtors. A five-year limit appears to be a sensible duration. Adopting a universal Statute of Limitations will remove uncertainty and vagueness regarding the timing and location of legal actions against debtors.

When debt collectors make calls, they often can't confirm whether the original creditor has merged with another entity. It's possible that the debt has been removed from the records of the company that was acquired. I suggest that the CFPB establish a regulation concerning debts erased from the books by an acquired firm, along with specific stipulations regarding the timeframe for collecting old debts. This should only be allowed if the consumer has been properly informed that the debt has been transferred to a collection agency, excluding the initial contact from the debt collection agency.

Indeed, I believe there is a method to gain the cooperation of debt collectors. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) can remind them that debt collection agencies might be putting their own phone representatives at risk of unnecessary verbal aggression from customers who have a valid reason for being frustrated due to follow-up calls that disregard a recently updated agreement made in the previous conversation. In cases where prior communication with the debt collector establishes a new repayment timeline, the debt collector should respect this timeline and avoid making additional calls within a week unless the customer specifically requests a follow-up sooner. This also empowers the debt collection representative to say, "It has been over a week since our last interaction," which gives the customer an opportunity to acknowledge that they are not being subjected to daily harassment by the same debt collector. Certain consumers face situations where their income drops to nothing. and as a result, they might default on several accounts. Consider the scenario where five different debt collectors each make two calls a day. Even receiving one call a week can add up to a daily call if a consumer is dealing with five defaults at the same time. However, this is undoubtedly better than receiving two calls every day from each debt account, which would total 10 calls daily.

For lawyers who engage in debt collection, requiring them to detail all possible consumer rights dangerously approaches offering legal counsel; even if it doesn't entirely cross that boundary, the less informed debtor might perceive the attorney as a neutral entity of the court instead of an advocate for the opposing side. I've encountered debtors questioning me, "Is it necessary for me to attend court for this?" after initiating a lawsuit against them.

A former neighbor had her outstanding debts transferred to collections. Despite our requests to be removed from their call list, we constantly receive calls asking for her contact details. While it's an unfortunate circumstance, we're unaware of her current location and should not be subjected to this kind of harassment.

In my opinion, Amex manages this situation the most effectively. The account owner is responsible for all expenses incurred by themselves and any designated users they add to the account. However, authorized users receive a distinct card number and can be held responsible for any purchases they make.

Moreover, collectors must be prohibited, in all situations, from employing any tactics that would incur expenses for the consumer. To illustrate, all calls from collectors should strictly exclude the use of cellphones and texting.
I remain firm in my belief; the CFPB ought to employ a significant number of undercover agents equipped with the authority to make arrests.

It's not a rare occurrence. This issue is incredibly frequent. Individuals with common names are easy targets for these unscrupulous individuals. I often find myself being bombarded by calls from debt collectors searching for others. Call blocking programs fail to function outside specified areas, thus, they offer no real protection.

For many years, I have often found myself on the receiving end of debt collectors' persistent phone calls. The apparent reason for this is my surname, which is quite common. In reality, I don't owe any money. Initially, when a debt collector begins contacting me, it becomes incredibly challenging to shake them off. One company accused me of dishonesty and continued to call. Another pursued me for debts associated with two different individuals. Additionally, being bombarded by collection calls can indeed be damaging. The constant interactions with debt collectors have negatively affected my physical and mental well-being. I am an elderly woman. Moreover, it has instilled a sense of unease regarding my personal financial situation.

I'm uncertain whether technology enables collectors to differentiate between landlines and mobile phones. It seems reasonable for collectors to utilize information provided in credit applications. Collectors should be permitted to presume that the recorded mailing address accurately reflects the debtor's time zone. In some instances, creditors occasionally seek updated contact information; it would be beneficial for all creditors to adopt this practice. The mailing address should be prioritized for determining the time zone unless informed otherwise by the debtor. As previously noted, individuals with mobile phones might relocate to different regions without altering their area code.

They will persist in making calls. Ignoring the calls does not put an end to their persistence. There should be a mandate for them to disclose their identity clearly so that consumers can at least have a reasonable opportunity to communicate with them. Personally, I have no debts, yet I'm frequently targeted over other people's liabilities due to having a relatively common surname. They indiscriminately call anyone sharing the same surname as the legitimate debtor.

I am employed at a private university where we choose not to pursue legal action for collections. Debts have the potential to be listed on credit reports for a duration of 7 years, therefore, we prefer to assign our accounts to collection agencies for that entire period. However, with the new stipulations regarding debts that are time-barred, our collection agencies are reluctant to handle accounts that are more than 4 years old in Texas.

However, private agreements among these parties do not alter the reality that the debt still exists. The fact that the initial lender has absorbed a financial hit does not negate the actual obligation. Is it morally acceptable for someone to accumulate significant debt and simply not repay it?

A few years back, a debt collector was attempting to recover a debt related to an emergency room visit that included x-rays of my foot and leg. The issue was that my only visit to that hospital was for a workplace injury, which was covered by worker's compensation, and it concerned just my hand (which had been sliced open and required six stitches). I reached out to the collection agency to inform them that I didn't owe any money and explained the details of that hospital visit. Even though this did not resolve the issue initially, when I provided the same information to all three credit bureaus, the debt collector couldn't validate the debt. Consequently, the debt was removed from my credit report, and the collector ceased their attempts to contact me.

The cost of bad debt, also known as 'paper,' fluctuates based on the debtor's ability to pay, as determined by available information, and is also influenced by how much documentation is obtained from the original lender. Many debt purchasers only acquire a few recent credit card statements. They might offer a 'bill of sale' but these documents do not specify an individual account being transferred and instead refer to a master purchase agreement that is never disclosed.

Emails are not necessarily more accessible or visible to the debtor than phone calls it's actually more challenging to keep a call private if it is received in the presence of others), SMS or text message. Regulations should address sensitive data by requiring it to be sent as an attachment or through a link within the email, as opposed to placing it directly in the email body. Encrypting the attachment or storing details on a secure webpage ensures that they remain inaccessible to unauthorized individuals. Indeed, this method offers superior protection compared to any other form of communication with the debtor. Emails sent to work addresses should be treated differently, similar to workplace calls, since they can be monitored by the employer.

Even though Demand Letters might not always succeed in debt collection, "providing notice exemplifies the essence of fairness." What truly matters is that individuals adhere to established standards, which subsequently contribute to the eradication of abusive practices. Procedural protections, such as demand letters, remain crucial standards irrespective of their success.

In the absence of a federal law or regulation addressing what occurs with time-barred debts when a debtor moves from one state’s statute of limitations to another, such legislation needs to be established. There should be a definitive rule outlining which statute of limitations applies when a debtor relocates across state lines.

The FTC must incorporate an exemption for trivial and unrelated disputes in any rule about verification. This is due to the overwhelming number of websites offering template dispute letters and encouraging their use, leading to widespread misuse by debtors, resulting in a generic response letter to tackle this problem.

Debt collectors initiate a substantial number of default judgments primarily because consumers fail to respond, not due to ignorance of the matter. Typically, by the time a lawsuit commences, debt collectors have attempted resolution through calls and/or letters. This doesn't take into account the efforts made by the original creditor. Initiating a lawsuit is never the initial response. It generally occurs after multiple unsuccessful attempts to collaborate with a consumer to settle an unpaid debt. A default judgment simply extends this process further. Even after litigation begins, we may endeavor to contact the consumer to resolve the issue prior to a judgment being made. I've encountered many cases where we've communicated with the consumer, informing them they can respond, yet they still don't. In my view, default judgments predominantly stem from consumers' intentional disengagement rather than misleading actions by collectors. I must mention that several states have regulations stipulating that if there's no reaction to a summons and the consumer defaults, they aren't required to be notified of a motion for default judgment. Thus, the actual issuance of the judgment could indeed be unexpected, despite the summons indicating that a judgment might be issued if unresponded. Nevertheless, an attorney adhering to local regulations isn't behaving deceitfully. To mitigate the surprise for consumers who don't respond, it might be beneficial to mandate that all judgment motions be served to the consumer, despite existing local rules. I would highlight that numerous default judgment motions aren't scheduled for motion hour. They might be simply presented for decision without a court session. Regarding what is necessary to substantiate a default judgment, this varies between different courts and judges. The courts I've observed that require more documentation typically seek affidavits of debt, charge-off statements, and records of payments or charges, along with the assignment (if the plaintiff is a debt purchaser).

The validation notice should comprehensively include items numbered 1 to 10. Particularly, item number 10 should specify the Date-of-service (DOS) for any medical debts. A lot of consumers are unaware that medical debts are sent to collections like other types of consumer debt. There is a common misconception that their insurance providers will handle these debts. Moreover, patients often face charges from each medical professional involved, such as radiologists and pathologists, along with the technical fees for the facility, especially after extensive medical procedures like surgical inpatient stays. Frequently, patients never meet these healthcare providers and might confuse the bill with other service-related charges or assume it will be resolved without their involvement. Including the name of the consumer's insurance company or plan on the validation notice would be significantly beneficial. This might appear to add a substantial amount of information however, the originating physician or facility typically collects this information at or before the service is provided.

When mortgage companies shift the servicing of a mortgage loan to a different lender, they are required to notify the borrower that their loan has been transferred. Implement these same notification requirements for all types of debts.

Honestly, I feel like yelling. You've never had to deal with a collection agency that sees people merely as cash cows, irrespective of their debt situation. And this has been happening for a long time. It's disappointing that this is the first thing you mention to me.

In my experience, some banks refuse to let their branches accept debit or credit cards. Every branch should be required to accept payments via debit and credit cards. It's as if they're operating in the 1950s.

Debt neutrality is a commendable concept. Unfortunately, owing money is not regarded as a criminal offense. Nevertheless, given the current laws and the aggressive tactics of debt collection agencies, you might as well be treated like a lawbreaker. I concur. Establish a framework where consumers have equal standing with debt collectors.

The core issue with privacy lies in the fact that we use the SS# universally, which links all our information. This has been a flawed concept ever since it was used as a taxpayer identification number. While it might deter some fraudulent activities, the drawbacks outweigh the benefits. In essence, it has become illegal to remain untraceable, which poses significant problems for those like domestic abuse survivors.

Nancy H's statement highlights the core issue: the absence of uniform standards. Wishing you all the best. Your experience in such a scenario is influenced by the collection agency, the original creditor, and your location. Your place of residence should not be a determining factor.

Indeed, you are right. There is a considerable difference between sending and receiving. What I'm proposing is that a creditor should only be obligated to dispatch a notice to the most recent address on record - not necessarily to ensure the consumer receives it. and it's an overestimation to assume that every undelivered mail is always returned to the sender. in such cases, the creditor is required to send the notification to the updated address. If the aim of this discussion is to guarantee consumer protection, then it should be mandated that consumers safeguard themselves by supplying this information to creditors. If they fail to do so, a creditor shouldn't be held liable in a lawsuit for a notification not reaching the consumer, provided the creditor acted based on the best information available.

Consumers should receive and have access to a distinct "summary of rights." We remain largely uninformed and often misinformed regarding our consumer rights, the negotiation options available to us, and who can provide assistance. Additionally, there ought to be legislation outlining situations where collectors are prohibited from pursuing collections. In cases where the original creditor hasn't attempted to recover the debt for a long duration, it is unreasonable to receive a collection notice two decades later.

After leaving a lengthy comment on one specific debt collector, I recently faced harassment from another collector targeting someone else unrelated to me. The caller ID displayed was not a typical phone number; instead, it showed names of various states, yet it was the same company behind all calls. These individuals operate without morals, sinking to the lowest levels. Mandating accurate caller ID should be imperative allowing the recipient to recognize the collector and obtain a reliable contact number. Furthermore, financial penalties should be substantially increased to deter their appalling, exploitative, and aggressive tactics. Harassment forms a core part of their operational strategies. These individuals are despicable and should at the very least be obligated to reveal their true identities. Automated calls and identity masking should be banned with substantial fines imposed.

Since the phone belongs to the consumer it is their entitlement! Why should customers bear the cost of being disturbed?! The financial burden of this business should fall on the companies, not the consumers! I cover the expenses for my mobile device, I pay for the airtime, I am the one who will determine how my resources are utilized and who gets to contact me, not these unscrupulous companies!

My daughter is burdened with loans from both private lenders and the federal government, specifically through Sallie Mae. She receives incessant calls on her mobile phone, as do I, amounting to at least ten times each day. They contacted me, and despite lacking her consent to discuss her matters with me, they suggested ceasing payments on her federal loans, which can be deferred, in favor of addressing the private ones. She is struggling under a debt of $176,000 from private loans, unable to meet the repayment demands. The collectors even reached out to her workplace asking for details about her. She has formally requested that they limit their communication to email and postal mail. During one of their calls to me, I inquired if they had received her request and they confirmed they had, but insisted on needing verbal contact with someone. However, my number isn't supposed to be a contact point for them. I informed them of this fact, yet they persist in calling my mobile every day. My daughter is barely managing to cover her current expenses. I contribute to her private loan repayments. Despite this, I am not listed on any of her loans. This persistent harassment must come to an end!

You highlight a problem involving two separate definitions: "sent" versus "received." I doubt any consumer desires to "receive" a notification that was never "sent" initially. Moreover, letters and packages frequently go missing in transit. If there is an obligation for a creditor or collector to "send" the notices you're discussing, the initial destination will be an address that's recorded. If the correspondence is returned, it indicates that the recipient is no longer at the recorded address. However, these letters need to be "sent" initially.

I require a visible number. Cease obstructing the number and refrain from using toll-free numbers. In my opinion, toll-free numbers are typically associated with telemarketers or salespeople. I need to be aware if I have any debts that have been sent to collections. Therefore, do not conceal your identity.

Collectors who employ robocalls without first confirming the phone number through a personal call exhibit laziness and irresponsibility. Robocalls to third parties are not only a significant annoyance but also an improper disclosure. This is due to the requirement that prerecorded calls must state the company's name at the beginning of the message, as mandated by the TCPA. I have received countless calls of this nature, and I've come to learn which neighbors supposedly owe money. I use the term "supposedly", because the firms making these calls are often the same offenders who have faced numerous lawsuits for attempting to collect debts that don't exist. Banning robocalls, especially those targeting third parties, would penalize the wrongdoers while leaving legitimate collectors largely unaffected. I wouldn't mind if live operators used autodialers, but the technology employed by certain collection agencies is outdated. Telemarketers manage to comply with the mandated 3% call abandonment rate, but in my experience, the abandonment rate for live calls from collectors fluctuates between 50% and 100%. Indeed, there was one company that hung up instantly whenever one of their representatives contacted me. I'm unsure how this approach could be financially viable. Applying the FTC's 3% rule to debt collection calls could potentially resolve this issue.

I make it a point to ignore any phone calls labeled as "unknown caller" or simply "unknown". Failing to display a name on the caller ID line suggests either dishonesty or concealment on the company's part. It's important to remember that you are the one initiating contact with me, thus, unsolicited phone calls can be perceived as a breach of my personal privacy. I am under no obligation to respond to calls that I choose not to engage with. It's crucial to implement a rule mandating debt collection agencies to clearly identify themselves when making calls.

This is simply a part of the cost associated with the industry. Should debt collectors find themselves unable to cope with reality, they ought to consider pursuing careers in alternate business sectors.

There should be a rigorous crackdown on the service industry. They have significantly disrupted the debt collection process by having their service personnel engage in FALSE SERVICE and FALSE SUBSERVICE of alleged debt defaulters. I've experienced this twice; the first instance involved the process server guessing by using the most generic age, size, and weight descriptors and assigning a fictitious name! On the second occasion, the servicer referred to the sub-server as 'Jane Doe' and again concocted the most generic descriptions spanning various ages, heights, and races they could think of, making it completely inaccurate. In court, I overheard another defendant telling the judge they were never served, and the paperwork was left outside their door. Besides, the service company falsely claims in court documents to have served someone who wasn't actually served, which alone should provide the judge with the discretion to take action to safeguard the defendants, when debt collectors realize they can execute a false service, they become FAR LESS INCLINED to negotiate with the defendant. Judges seem to overlook this dimension of false service. I am certain of my experiences and I will confidently declare anywhere that I have been falsely served/subserved on two occasions.

The debt collection agency is not obligated to authenticate the debt or supply details to the consumer. For instance, I challenged the validity of a debt. The response I received simply stated: "The consumer owes the debt." This, in my opinion, does not constitute validation, nor would it for any reasonable individual. Collection agencies ought to be mandated to provide sufficient information for consumers to identify or contest the debt. Optimally, this would include a copy of the original application and the final billing statement.

State and local court regulations can sometimes increase the likelihood of default judgments. For instance, if an individual accused of owing a debt is required to appear in court on a workday, they might have to decide between facing a default judgment and preserving their employment. I strongly recommend that the CFPB consider practices that involve scheduling hearings at inconvenient times as unfair, deceptive, and abusive, or as contrary to 1692i.

Government regulations ought to prevent them from gaining excessive profits on such trivial investments (usury!!!). Additional factors to take into account regarding this issue include: The bad debt. The purchaser of the bad debt does not reveal the price paid for acquiring it. This information must be made public and clear. since they possess the initial debt details, encompassing SSN, phone and financial data. I don't oppose them earning a profit, but their exploitative tactics require regulation. A high-ranking judge should be able to review the original transaction, all the paperwork related to the debt's purchase by a third party, and establish a fair and reasonable payment to address the issue, avoiding bankruptcy.

I want to clarify that I am not suggesting escaping debt due to a significant life event. I am suggesting that the debt should be locked at the amount it was when the involuntary default occurred, allowing repayment even if it spans a decade.

I fully support drose977's viewpoint. At present, debt collection agencies are permitted to sell debts without ensuring proper verification. Additionally, they can transfer the debt even if a consumer disputes it and the agency fails to provide adequate validation. These practices should be prohibited as they severely harm consumers. The interests of consumers must be prioritized over those of collectors and similar entities. because consumers generally lack the resources necessary to challenge incorrect information. Moreover, false information impacts consumers more negatively than any other group involved in these instances. Debt collectors should be prohibited from marking a debt as 30 days overdue if it is not actually 30 days past due. Legislation should impose strict and enforceable penalties to discourage collectors from falsely backdating debt. These regulations need to apply to any late-reported debt at any duration, not just within the initial 30 days.

I am in agreement with josephusmyer. About eight years back, our son accrued minor debts at various shops and banks. Debt collectors, who purchase these debts, have reached out to him, threatening legal proceedings over debts that are past the statute of limitations, without informing him of this fact.

I have no issue with receiving work-related calls. What bothers me is how often they occur. I acknowledge that the bill is my responsibility and am aware of it. However, I believe they shouldn't contact my workplace unless I fail to return their calls. They should text or call me first, allowing me a few days to respond. If needed, then reach out to my workplace, but not on a daily basis.

It is essential for consumers to actively engage in all their activities. Individuals who are capable of incurring debt should also be equipped to manage and settle it. The credit unions I'm familiar with consistently go above and beyond to support their members in attaining financial stability.
All types of written correspondence ought to be recognized as official written notification. Debt collectors must comply with any instructions they receive by email regarding contact.

In a legal battle, each party showcases their evidence to back up their claims. As someone who collects debts, I present the proof of the owed amount. The person owing the debt must also provide some form of evidence to demonstrate that the debt does not belong to them. While the principle is that one is innocent until proven otherwise, it's essential to present evidence to substantiate the claim of innocence. If I present a document with your signature indicating agreement to the purchase and accompanying records showing non-payment, I have met my proof obligations. In our judicial framework, the debtor also carries a burden to prove their case. The role of the judge is crucial - they listen to both parties, evaluate the evidence, and deliver a just verdict based on the presented arguments and proof.

Publishing a piece on landlords involved in unlawful litigation and debt recovery would elicit a substantial number of reactions. This issue is largely concealed from public view, yet it is quite common in New York City.

I'm sorry to hear about what you're going through. As a consumer, it's distressing to learn about such abusive behavior. There's no necessity for them to 'speak' with anyone. You or your daughter have every legal right to request that the phone calls cease and to ask for communication through other means. Collectors who disregard this request are breaching legal obligations. Additionally, they should refrain from contacting you at all and certainly not reach out to you or your daughter ten times daily. This level of contact is undeniably excessive and abusive. I also want to point out that, even though they mention federal loans can often be deferred, debt collectors are not fiduciaries, and they neither act with nor are they qualified to offer financial advice that caters to the consumer's or debtor's best interests. Collectors will resort to any statements or actions to ensure payment is received. They should be prohibited from advising on which bills to settle and the methods of payment. Such 'advice' can be harmful to consumers or debtors. Perhaps the CFPB should permit collectors to offer referrals for financial advice, but they should not be allowed to provide financial advice directly.

What if we allowed arbitrators the flexibility to rely not just on legalities but also on practical judgment in cases of credit card defaults? It's only logical to assume that if a flood in Colorado devastates a community, residents might struggle to pay their credit card bills for a period. It's reasonable to argue that situations like a medical crisis, being involved in a hit-and-run accident, losing one's home, or acting as an unpaid caregiver for a loved one should outweigh the necessity of making monthly payments. This discussion isn't about wiping out debts, it's about designating a debt as neutral, meaning no further penalties, fees, or interest rate increases would be imposed, and the debtor commits to repaying the debt sensibly, even if it takes a decade. __URL__

Collectors frequently exploit regulations related to phone communications, and there is a lack of enforcement against those who breach these rules. Legal restrictions should confine collectors to communication through postal mail only. These individuals are opportunists who blatantly disregard legal boundaries. Prohibit them entirely from making phone calls. For decades, they have consistently demonstrated their disregard for the law. Ban phone communications.

The importance of security cannot be overstated. Given that the vulnerabilities in existing authentication methods used by financial institutions and others governed by FACTA and the FCRA are not addressed by this legislation, applying equivalent security standards to a centralized debt collection database should be straightforward.

A debt from 19 years ago resurfaced to trouble me. I approached three lawyers in an attempt to hire them to communicate with the company, as the contact information I had did not respond to my numerous messages, including a settlement offer for slightly over half of what they said I owed.. Over those 19 years, this debt ballooned from about $1,200 to $9,300.. Such conduct needs to be controlled, because it is nothing short of a scam..

Let's be clear, it is 2013! Avoiding phone calls is frustrating and repeatedly seeing missed calls is infuriating. Why are debt collectors acting like it's the past? Send me a text! Shoot me an email! These calls will remain unanswered since I have a job and children. It would be much simpler to communicate if I could text and email these individuals. Honestly, we are not living in the 1950s!

I recently found out that my mortgage lender doesn't possess the note on my loan. and they are unable to find it. I am up to date with payments and I'm not worried about lowering the payment amount. I've inquired with the mortgage company about what steps we should take. For the past 8 months, they have been sending us notifications indicating that they are investigating the matter.

The CFPB ought to completely prohibit phone calls to workplaces., When consumers acquire debt, they typically provide their home phone number, which should be the sole contact number for collection purposes.. Sending registered or certified mail should be the alternative communication method instead of workplace calls.. Massachusetts' idea to limit the total number of calls is absolutely brilliant.. In today's society, we do not imprison debtors, yet the excessive level of mistreatment and disdain they face is utterly intolerable.. It is crucial for the CFPB to reform the debt collection industry..

As someone who lends money, I mostly concur with this remark. In my view, a well-crafted validation notice could address many inquiries consumers might have. I believe the writer of the previous note presented some very insightful arguments. I wouldn't go as far as to insist on providing a detailed statement, especially if it's not available due to reasons such as record retention policies or its non-existence, yet offering details like the account type, the brand name of the original creditor, the account number, the last payment date, and the name of the party that may have acquired the debt would be beneficial. Initially furnishing documentation seems unnecessary and expensive, particularly if the letter’s phrasing allows the consumer to easily recognize the account, and the disclosures enable the consumer to ask for validation documentation.

I have no objections to my spouse. After all, she is my wife. so it seems perfectly reasonable to me. However, I don't support the idea of girlfriends or boyfriends for those who aren't married. Having a spouse is acceptable.

I find it unjust when a third party acquires a delinquent debt and proceeds to sue for the full amount, adding attorney costs, court fees, and other charges related to mediators or arbitrators. It is my opinion that there should be a cap on how much a third-party debt purchaser can litigate for, beyond their original expenditure. Often, the initial creditor is a publicly traded company and the shareholders have already absorbed the loss. Subsequently, a debt purchaser acquires a batch of non-performing debts for just ten cents on the dollar. They then forward the entire portfolio to a law firm to attempt to collect 100% or more of the supposed original debt. Debt buyers should not have the right to litigate for 900% of what they spent. Their ability to sue should be confined to a fraction of the actual damages. I am unaware of any other civil process where such actions would be deemed ethical.

I am in favor of imposing stringent regulations on what are known as "skip-trace" vendors. These entities are hired by debt collectors and others to supply them with contact information. Based on my own experience (having a common last name and being pursued by various debt collectors), I feel that I am at the mercy of these vendors. They collect a vast array of personal information without appearing to verify any of it, to the best of my knowledge. A debt collector informed my state's Attorney General that they had employed one of these vendors who wrongly identified my phone number as a legitimate contact for someone sharing my last name and first initial. This individual was unknown to me, yet the debt collector demanded that I settle the debt. I believe these vendors ought to be heavily regulated and should employ more reliable research tools than merely a phone book for gathering data. They should be prohibited from providing information labeled as "valid" unless it is genuinely accurate.

I am in favor of imposing limitations on robo-calls as well as any calls made during working hours. Regarding robo-calls, it is important to impose restrictions on any that are deceptive. For instance, a robo-call that claims you have a message or account update and directs you to call a specific number with an extension, only for you to hear the same message demanding payment, squanders the consumer's time and cellular resources (involving both an incoming and an outgoing call).
In Illinois, there exists legislation against Caller ID spoofing. Despite this, I still receive daily calls with either fake or unreadable caller ID information and no voicemail. __URL__
Indeed, that's exactly what I experienced today, a person contacted me, claiming to be from a "courier service," while attempting to find a friend.

Considering the severe repercussions of negative data being shared with or by CRAs on consumer credit reports, it is fair to assert that a debt should not be considered "verified" or "substantiated" until a final non-appealable judgment is issued, but only if the consumer has promptly contested the debt's existence or amount. At present, disputing a debt leads to the debt collector notifying the CRAs which results in an unfavorable effect on your credit score; essentially, the damage is done by that stage. To put it simply, the indication that a consumer disputes a debt on their credit report is mostly disregarded by potential lenders, employers, landlords, and others. Consequently, disputing the debt fails to shield the consumer from harm. Debt collectors and creditors use the threat of reporting to CRAs as a manipulative strategy to compel payment even though you may not actually owe the debt or the full amount claimed. Regarding my suggestion, I believe it won't result in increased litigation. In fact, it might do the opposite. If a consumer does not dispute the debt promptly, then it can be considered verified or substantiated. However, if the debt is disputed in a timely manner, creditors and collectors will need to decide whether to pursue legal action and evaluate their chances of success at trial, potentially leading them to be more selective about which debts to litigate. This proposal would further safeguard consumers from credit score damage until it is definitively established that a contested debt is actually owed and the precise amount is confirmed. Alternatively, a rule could be established imposing hefty statutory penalties, triple damages, and recovery of attorney's fees against creditors, collectors, and CRAs if the consumer can prove the disputed debt is nonexistent or less than claimed. This method, however, places the responsibility of proving the case on the consumer. And I strongly believe that creditors and collectors should bear the responsibility of proving both the existence and amount of any contested debt before negatively affecting a consumer's credit report.

I believe the system should implement a series of 'handshakes' at critical stages: when a dispute is initiated, when it is resolved, and if it is withdrawn. In each scenario, it is crucial that the consumer is assured that the collector has acknowledged their stance and that the credit reporting agency (CRA) has been duly informed. The CRA should be an integral part of this handshake process. It is intolerable for consumer complaints to remain unresolved for extended periods, leaving consumers in the dark about whether the CRA has received updated information from the collector or if the CRA is taking excessively long to process the update.

In the realm of social media, although courts have occasionally allowed it as a method for delivering notices, it's important to note that not all individuals are present on every social media site. Despite being quite internet savvy, I still do not engage with platforms like Foursquare, Pinterest, and many more. Platforms such as Facebook and Twitter host countless individuals with my name, leading to potential misdirected notifications.

Although this website does not specifically tackle this issue, the penalties for breaching the FDCPA are largely ineffective. A $100 fine hardly impacts most corporations. The legislation should be amended to allow a statute of limitations of 7 years (as opposed to the current one year) and impose a maximum fine, payable to the claimant, ranging from $10,000 to $100,000 per infraction.

Unless a consumer opts to interact over the phone, all communications from debt collectors should be conducted via mail. This method affords the consumer the opportunity to carefully evaluate the collector's requests. It also helps prevent misunderstandings for both involved parties. The sole reason this isn't the usual practice is because it restricts collectors from being irritating and humiliating—it's that straightforward.
If you don't respond, the call will be repeated. Instead of dismissing the call, you could pick up and request that the company refrain from contacting you.

In response to the first query, it is essential to exercise thorough diligence. Collectors may continue pursuing legal action, yet I believe that measures should be in place to penalize them when false claims are made. Should litigation be initiated against an incorrect party, the instigating collector must compensate the victim and pay substantial fees to regulatory authorities to assist with oversight costs. Regarding the second issue, I contend that a significant majority of consumer debts are repayable. Nevertheless, exceptions will inevitably occur. For debts deemed irrecoverable for any reason, they should be written off and barred from being resold for collection. Clarification and precise definitions of "Not Collectable" should be established by the relevant regulatory body. Addressing the third point, both parties need to be evaluated. Existing credit reporting agencies already track consumer-related aspects, and an additional score could be integrated into the consumer's credit history. This would serve as a foundation to enhance as refinements are made to the system. Conversely, the collector would necessitate a new evaluation system that assesses both the organization and the individuals involved in debt settlement processes. For effective models of such a system, one might look to the Department of Transportation's Compliance-Safety-Accountability framework. Admittedly, their methodology is more intricate and detailed than what the debt industry demands. Nonetheless, their scoring approach is adaptable and poised for future modifications. It would also enable the evaluation of the original creditor. Such evaluation would provide government and investors with a clearer understanding of a business's risk profile. Incorporating Mr. Bartmann's suggestions would foster a self-regulating environment among collectors and financial entities aimed at ethical outcomes rather than hiding behind legal technicalities. This approach benefits both parties and assists many consumers in escaping the vicious cycle of debt. Finally, the federal government could deploy this system with minimal interference with state sovereignty. This would decrease the instances of court cases at the state and local levels, encouraging states to participate.

My surname is quite ordinary, and in the directory, my entry shows two initials instead of a full first name. I frequently receive phone calls from debt collectors who are searching for individuals with my last name and one of my initials. Their approach is purely speculative. Once I inform them that I don't share my home with relatives and maintain a solid credit score, they remove my number from their list for the person they're interested in today. Despite asking them not to contact me, as there are no other individuals at my residence they need to find, they reply that I was included for today's target. My number might appear again tomorrow for the next target, but they claim "there's nothing they can do about future calls." A credit collector from India actually told me this.

I'm puzzled as to why bill collectors seem to be trapped in outdated methods. Receiving numerous calls is quite irritating. I would much prefer to get a text message or an email. The sound of a ringing phone can be bothersome, whereas a text is less intrusive. It also spares me from listening to an unnecessarily lengthy voicemail. I'd rather receive a text identifying who they are and their purpose. If I don't reply promptly, then they should feel free to call me.

that would lack efficiency. According to the FCRA, debts that are no longer handled by a creditor or collector cannot be reported. For instance, if your debt is being reported by a creditor who decides to transfer it to a debt collector, the original creditor is then unable to continue reporting that debt. However, the purchaser can report it, provided they comply with the relevant federal regulations.
The ability to try verifying the debt should be eliminated. It should be mandatory to make verification attempts and if verification isn't completed, the debt must not be passed on.

Requiring such extensive information is excessive. It's not the responsibility of creditors or collectors to provide notices about 'best practices' or details about staff. The focus here is on notifying that a debt has been handed over for collection. Not sold, merely entrusted to professionals who specialize in recovering overdue debts. Notification is provided when the validation notice is dispatched. The entity that sends it is the collection agency. The letter will clearly mention the name of the creditor to whom the outstanding debt is due. That suffices.

My late daughter, who passed away two years ago, had some outstanding debts. Despite our requests for them to stop, debt collectors persist in calling us. In response to this harassment, my wife has lodged complaints with the Oregon State Justice Department. Is it too much to ask for these collectors to verify the debtor's information before they start harassing the parents?
I firmly believe that documentation must invariably be supplied. What reason would there be for me to settle a debt without concrete evidence that it is indeed mine?

In my view, the CFPB's authority should not extend to this domain, because there is no such restriction mentioned in the federal laws.. Informing a consumer that a debt has surpassed the statute is concerning, as the date is subject to change.. Making a partial payment on a debt resets the statute of limitations.. I am skeptical that a regulation from the CFPB would be beneficial in this situation.. Educating consumers is the sole proactive strategy I believe is viable here.. Nonetheless, this education should also involve alerting the legal community that the CFPB intends to report any violations in this matter to their state's Attorney General..

Marian provides a compelling insight regarding the remuneration of Debt Collectors. Their strategy involves securing the maximum amount of money upfront. Interestingly, if they manage to collect an excessive amount initially, the credit card company might reclaim the account from the debt collector. Debt collectors lose interest if the sum they receive is considered "too low." This contradicts many sales strategies, as it is often simpler to engage with a customer who makes payments over time, rather than aiming for a substantial one-time gain.

The core issue lies in the lack of proper enforcement. When debt collectors are instructed to cease contacting the consumer's place of employment, they often disregard the legal requirement to halt their actions. Bringing these violations to the attention of regulatory bodies proves pointless, as enforcement is consistently absent, and collectors are fully aware of this. Enhance enforcement measures to be more effective.

It can be handled similarly to how you would deal with documents sent by fax or traditional mail, uploading simply provides a more convenient method for delivery. Regarding the appropriate timing, I would suggest 48 hours.

I encountered a situation where my lawyer, representing me, sought confirmation of the loan amount, but the debt collector failed to reply. As a result, I am unable to proceed with the settlement until they provide a response.

I experienced a similar issue with a different mobile network provider. This appears to be a strategy to continually present the debt as new. It involved another charge for ending the contract early, and I had to send numerous letters before it was eventually erased from my credit file. I believe that this practice of repeatedly selling the same debt to prolong its presence on a credit report should be halted. It's a single debt, and there's a specified duration it can remain on a person's credit history. An effective way to manage this is to mandate notification to individuals when a debt changes hands. Such notification is mandatory when a mortgage is transferred. This seems like an obvious solution. Regulations should be established to not only discourage but outright prevent collection agencies from transferring debt to manipulate credit records.

Indeed, a bank is required to retain the agreement for a duration of 20 years if the account remains active. In cases where the account defaulted two decades prior to legal action, the statute of limitations would have expired, rendering the lawsuit unfounded; it ought to be thrown out with penalties imposed.
There should be no overarching regulations at the national level. States should be permitted to persist in enforcing their own legislation.

Our office broadly encompasses various "disputes." Defining this is particularly challenging because it can manifest in very unique and individual ways. Typically, the disputes we encounter involve situations where a debt buyer has acquired the debt, yet the consumer does not recognize the debt buyer's name, often leading to claims that they don't owe the debt (without providing further explanation) or that the amount being claimed is incorrect. There may also be allegations of fraud or previous payments. Our office takes a cautious approach by accepting both verbal and written disputes. I believe the more significant issue isn't what qualifies as a dispute, but rather how a collector substantiates the debt. Many consumers request extremely detailed documentation. There is a widely circulated template letter online, which many consumers use, that asks for verification instead of validation, whatever the distinction may be, and demands specific details be provided. I mention this because it seems that many consumers assume all these requested details must be supplied, although the FDCPA does not specify what constitutes proper verification. I will save that discussion for another post, though I suspect that pinpointing what verification entails will be quite complex since it cannot be defined so rigidly that different types of creditors can't provide the required information, nor so vaguely that extensive legal action is necessary to clarify it.

I have doubts that a registry for debt collectors effectively tackles the problem. I'm uncertain about how the registration system would function. In Massachusetts, individuals can go online to verify if a debt collector holds a license to operate within the state. However, many people are unaware of the website or, more fundamentally, don't realize that the debt collector lacks the authority to pursue them for payment. Is the intention of the registration system to override state mandates that necessitate debt collectors to be licensed in different states? I sincerely hope that isn't the situation. because states have a vested interest in overseeing debt collectors to safeguard their citizens.

A notification should be issued stating that the debt has been transferred. since this undoubtedly guides the consumer on how to proceed with negotiating the debt's repayment. When a debt is transferred, it is often done at a price considerably less than the full amount owed, allowing the lender to write it off, while the borrower faces a negative impact on their credit report for seven years. Occasionally, dealing with debt collectors means that the 'debt collector' is actually a subsidiary wholly owned by the original lender, leading to a tax write-off for them, a credit hit for you, yet they still pursue the full debt amount. If a debt is transferred, it ought to be sold to an independent third party, rather than a subsidiary of the initial lender. Furthermore, consumers must receive complete information about whom their debt has been 'sold' to.

Although this isn't the ideal platform to delve into the entire procedure my company employs for collections, we persistently pursue debts for a minimum of 120 days. This involves sending letters, making calls both live and automated, dispatching emails, mailing invoices, and suspending subscription services (when permissible) as part of our recovery strategy. Even after these efforts, we choose to pursue legal action only when the debtor remains unresponsive to our communication attempts. In my experience, when debtors engage in discussions with their creditors, creditors often consider their circumstances. I have proposed extended payment plans, offered reduced or waived interest and late fees, or agreed to partial settlements for those who explain their difficulties. However, if a debtor chooses not to cooperate or ignores our efforts to negotiate a resolution, what options remain for creditors?

we are constantly inundated with robocalls from dawn until dusk, all from unknown numbers; after the answering machine activates, no messages are ever left; such calls should be prohibited unless a message is left that includes the caller's identity and the purpose of the call, specifying both the creditor's and debtor's names

I must highlight that there are numerous complaints from consumers about the aggressive or harassing behavior of debt collectors. Working as a third-party debt collector, I encounter numerous harassment complaints on a daily basis. I would like to emphasize that in 80% of the cases, the consumers my colleagues and I deal with are reporting issues of harassment and abuse; and all of them are simply reluctant to acknowledge the reality. That's the essence of their grievances. When we inform them of their outstanding debt, they interpret it as harassment and abuse. They are unwilling to confront their issues. Admittedly, a few debt collectors can be harassing and abusive, but the vast majority, 98%, are merely stating facts. Once consumers understand that the issue lies with them and not with us, the reputation of debt collectors would improve. Until that realization occurs, we remain seen as the adversary in the eyes of consumers.

Moreover, the landlord's real estate lawyer also owned a debt collection agency which allowed him to repeatedly transfer the landlord's debts to his agency enabling the landlords to continually write it off with each lawsuit, and in this particular case, it involved 8 lawsuits for the same debt.

In cases where consumers are informed about the sale of their debt, there should be an option to reach out to the initial creditor for verification. Additionally, maintaining a documented record is essential. The situation creates a chance for fraudulent individuals to assert, as they currently do, that the consumer owes them money and must settle the debt promptly with the scammer. A transparent paper or electronic trail ensures the journey of a debt from one creditor to another can be validated and confirmed, providing assurance to the consumer, and ensuring the correct entity receives payment.

It should be prohibited for debt collectors to change their caller ID details. They often disguise their identity, posing as "Process Servers" to gather details about someone else's financial obligations. This tactic stops consumers from lodging complaints against the debt collectors for breaching laws designed to protect them. since they operate using a fraudulent identity.

There's a persistent caller asking for someone named Sean, who isn't associated with this address, and I'm unfamiliar with anyone by that name. I inform them of their mistake, yet the calls persist. Occasionally, they leave automated messages on my voicemail. I'm aware that some debtors might falsely claim they are not at the number being dialed, however, these collectors should cross-check the information to avoid repeatedly dialing incorrect numbers. It's uncertain whether the debtor deliberately provided the wrong contact or if someone else used this number before it was assigned to me. This situation is highly frustrating. Though the callers never explicitly identify themselves as debt collectors, it's quite apparent.

Possessing a last name that is quite common, I endured relentless collection calls for around three years, intended for others who shared my surname and initial. Eventually, I altered my phone listing from using my initials to my nickname, and since then, I've received just one collection call. As a senior who is retired, I am free from any car loans or mortgages. I ensure all my bills are settled promptly, and I maintain zero balances on my credit cards. No debt collector has confessed that they obtained my number from the phone directory, but, this is precisely what they are doing. It would be beneficial if every debt collector disclosed to the person they contact where they got their information. Currently, I possess an extensive list of individuals who have debts that are in collections. Given that I am not a debt collector, I feel no legal duty to keep their identities confidential. Nevertheless, I do feel a moral responsibility to refrain from doing so. Efforts should be made to prevent debt collectors from troubling individuals who are not responsible for the debt.

I was just tuning into "CBS This Morning", where they talked about FICO collaborating with more financial entities, enabling these institutions to provide their customers with complimentary access to their FICO scores.. A free FICO score is already available through numerous financial institutions, but now FICO is vigorously expanding this initiative via their "Open Access" program—__URL__. I've been aware of this since FICO issued a press release earlier this month.. Today, I learned on "CBS This Morning" that Discover will allow its cardholders to view their FICO scores for free on their monthly billing statements.. I believe it is inappropriate for Discover or any business to display a consumer's FICO score on a billing statement or any documents that could be handed over to debt collectors.. Currently, debt collectors do not have access to any consumer's FICO scores.. However, they do possess access to a "collection score", which bears no connection whatsoever to FICO or a consumer's creditworthiness.. Discover's decision poses a significant privacy issue. and the CFPB should prohibit creditors and others from accessing a consumer's FICO score..

A majority of businesses enforce a stringent "NO PERSONAL CALLS" rule; therefore, the legislation should stipulate that "...unless expressly permitted in writing by the debtor, a collector is prohibited from trying to reach a debtor at their workplace."

That's completely outrageous. While I was playing my voice messages at home, my mom overheard one. They ought to communicate solely through text messages. Texts are not something that can be overheard by others. That lengthy message announcing they are debt collectors and trying to collect a debt is absurd!

Individuals who owe money ought to be allowed to send a message directly to a particular creditor, including their company's name and a request for them to return the call to a specific number. Upon receiving such a return call from a consumer, it should be mandatory for the collector or creditor to provide the mini-Miranda warning. Collectors do not need to disclose the purpose of their calls when leaving messages. The Health Information Privacy and Portability Act restricts sharing protected data with unauthorized individuals. and this same principle should be extended to those collecting debts.

From my perspective, individuals younger than myself, being part of the baby boomer generation, tend to favor electronic means of communication such as emails, texts, and chats. Reflecting on my own experience when I was overwhelmed with debt, I would have preferred avoiding direct conversations with people. There is a valid concern regarding the security of unencrypted emails and the possibility that consumers may not realize others might access their emails. Nonetheless, it is essential to promote communication in any form, particularly if it aligns with the preferences of the consumer. I advocate that emails, chats, and texts should all be recognized as written forms of communication. I'm uncertain how to convey all necessary disclosures unless individuals are guided to a source where they can read them clearly and comprehensively.

I find myself in a similar predicament, receiving calls about various individuals sharing my last name and one of my two initials. From what I can tell, none of the individuals being sought have any familial connection to me, let alone reside with me. I wish I could officially assert that I have no outstanding debts and that no one living with me does either. I am ready to renew this declaration annually to put an end to these calls which are essentially speculative inquiries.

Residing in Georgia, it appears that the laws here strongly favor those who hold debt. A case in point is the statute of limitations concerning mortgage debts. To illustrate, when the first lienholder initiates foreclosure, the second mortgage still remains active. According to the OCGA, the statute of limitations on any "debt instrument under seal" extends to 20 years following foreclosure. This secondary lien can be repeatedly sold. and whoever possesses it last has the right to pursue it for up to 20 years. In situations where homes are forfeited due to severe illness, unemployment, or other circumstances not caused by homeowner negligence, new laws should be enacted to safeguard consumers from financial devastation.

Engaging in legal proceedings in a courtroom contrasts sharply with conversing with a debt collector over the phone who asks for evidence to show that the disputed debt is indeed invalid. If your goal is to initiate legal action, proceed with filing a lawsuit. However, demanding proof from individuals you contact, insisting they confirm to you (rather than a judge) that the debt is not their responsibility, is coercive behavior.

It's astonishing that this situation has been allowed to persist for such a lengthy period. This issue should have been resolved long ago! Prevent the company from rebranding to continue unethical practices. Prohibit companies from using countless phone numbers to deceive individuals. Stop them from blocking numbers so that caller ID only displays "unknown" or even 000-0000. Stop placing the responsibility of halting this entire industry on consumers (who lack authority or means to ensure the enforcement of judgments). That responsibility falls under consumer protection! It is implied in your name! Your role is to safeguard the interests of the consumer. Compel these entities to accurately disclose their identities when requested! Debt collectors have persistently contacted my mobile phone for five years, seeking to collect a debt from someone unfamiliar to me. A random individual listed my phone number as a contact on a loan, defaulted on that loan, and now I am the one being pestered due to a complete stranger! When they call and state who they are looking for, I used to explain that I didn't know the person, then tried to inquire about the company's name, but they would already have disconnected the call, only to contact me again later. So now, after they ask for the individual, I promptly request the name and address of the company. They repeat their request for "name," and I reiterate my request for the company's name and address. They persist in asking for "name," I continue to request the company's name and address. The conversation escalates into a shouting match; they say, "I'll call back later when you're more willing to provide information," and then disconnect. There is no recourse, protection, or assistance available for individuals like myself. The company refuses to disclose their name, and I lack a phone number (because it appears as "unknown") to report their harassing conduct to regulatory authorities. I am powerless to prevent these individuals from contacting my cell phone! This is my phone! I am the one who pays the bill, not them! They should not have the "RIGHT," as they claim, to contact a cell phone!

I propose that the CFPB should tackle the problem of their "phishing" operations, which involve scouring phone directories and contacting anyone with a similar name. My phone listing was under my initials, but due to having a common surname, I received daily calls from debt agencies until I changed my listing to a nickname. Numerous comments on this site indicate others are facing the same issue, making it clear that this is a widespread practice. Oddly enough, the individuals in call centers react poorly when I inquire about how my phone number was added to their automated dialer system. The typical reaction is for them to abruptly end the call. I also suggest that the CFPB should deal with the issue of repeated calls to incorrect individuals. If I am not the intended person on the initial call, it's unlikely I will be on subsequent calls. Based on my dealings with debt collectors, I've realized there are two motives for their persistent calls: Staff in call centers are instructed to not accept No as an answer. The debt collector's strategy of repeatedly calling me is aimed at exhausting me into paying a debt that isn't mine just to end the calls.

Consumers ought not to bear extra charges for phone calls, text messages, or voice messages when these are linked to collections. Increasing expenses for a debtor means less available funds to settle their debts with creditors. It should be mandatory for debt collectors and creditors to cease all communication methods to a device identified by the debtor as lacking free communication services for calls or texts.

Credit reporting agencies should be mandated to promptly act on information about disputed debts and erase all mentions of such debts. For instance, I am working to get a time-barred paid lien off my credit report. Two of the three credit bureaus removed it instantly, but one refuses to do so. Despite providing documents from the court, the original creditor, and the office of the probate judge, I have seen no success. Without any resolution, I am stuck with an incorrect entry on my credit report.

Perhaps I overlooked something but I was never informed by my initial mortgage lender about the sale of my mortgage. Possibly, this is an improvement because the new "owner" could be an investment group. in my case, the purchaser provided a notice that included the original lender's name. Mandating both the seller and buyer to issue notices could lead to confusion among consumers.

In my opinion, the majority of default judgments arise because consumers acknowledge their debt and find no justification in prolonging the matter. Once served, numerous consumers reach out to us to arrange payment plans. Although we inform them of their right to present their case in court, most choose not to. Their primary goal is to settle the outstanding debt.

Consider robocalling: answering these calls signals to the caller that this is an ideal time to reach you in the future. The account ownership keeps transferring, causing repetition. "Updating our do not call lists requires time..."

banks can easily incorporate this clause into their Loan Sale Agreements. Every buyer entering into a Loan Sale Agreement with such a clause would be contractually bound to avoid legal action or the threat of it. some current buyers might decline to purchase because of this clause while other existing buyers might demand a price reduction due to their inability to initiate lawsuits. In either case, any stock not taken by current buyers would be quickly acquired by other buyers who are agreeable to these terms. This approach would eliminate the need for new laws or regulations as the issue would be resolved through the agreement between a willing seller and buyer. there would be no constitutional concerns about limiting lawsuits nor would there be any delays in putting this into practice. The only requirement would be the cooperation of the banks selling the loans which could be easily achieved by including some Safe-Harbor provisions for banks adhering to this protocol.

They have indeed taken such actions. I've received calls from the same debt collector, who uses different numbers—first a toll-free one, then another with a local area code, and sometimes just changes a digit in the number. Look up the number on Google. That's extremely useful. This action will reveal which company is behind the call. The name was consistently the same. I concur that this approach is dishonest, deceptive, and an unethical way to handle individuals. However, the overwhelming theme I'm seeing here is that collectors are engaging in harassment, primarily through phone calls. The solution is to strengthen the laws that prohibit such practices. Currently, consumers' only recourse is legal action, which is impractical given the $1000 amount—finding a lawyer to take on such a small case is quite challenging. This has resulted in a situation that heavily disadvantages consumers, and it has developed into this state.

To equalize opportunities rapidly, make credit card debt beyond the point of default open to dispute. Allowing any sums beyond the default amount to be contestable would immediately motivate credit card firms and debt collectors to collaborate with consumers on a feasible plan, wouldn't it? Currently, credit card companies often escalate the interest rate to as much as 29.9%. and might even permit the account to remain in default while accumulating default points against the borrower. When I closed my regional Emmy award-winning video business to care for my parents, my savings eventually dwindled, and I informed my credit card providers before any defaults occurred. NONE of them could offer me anything other than repeated advice to "pay your bill on time." If, instead, credit card companies were aware that post-default, they couldn't levy additional penalties, fees, or interest rate hikes on the debt, they would go to great lengths to collaborate with the alleged defaulter to help reduce the debt. Citibank increased the rate on my punctual 15-year-old credit card account by $5,000. I contest that excessive amount given my reasons for default, but Citibank remains indifferent, as does the debt collector. If the debt reverted to its original amount at the time of default, Citibank would undoubtedly strive to reach a resolution with me.

I propose that the CFPB establish a rule preventing creditors and debt collectors from transferring a disputed debt to another collection agency after a consumer has disputed the debt or issued a "cease and desist" letter. In the cases I handled, a "cease and desist" letter was sent to both the debt collector and the original creditor, demanding they halt debt collection efforts in accordance with the FDCPA. Despite this, they merely close the current collection agency and pass the account to another, forcing the consumer to start the process over. The CFPB should establish a regulation requiring that once a debt is disputed or a "cease and desist" letter is issued, the debt collector must inform the original creditor of the receipt of the C&D letter.

Due to the adhesive nature of credit card contracts, it is essential for informed third-party evaluators to ensure the fairness of these agreements. When someone faces a significant and uncontrollable event that diminishes their income, it seems unreasonable to deny them the right to pause interest accruals, penalties, and fees until their financial situation improves. They remain committed to repaying the debt, but since their circumstances have been drastically altered by uncontrollable events, this should be considered in certain situations. It appears unethical to penalize a consumer when their home is suddenly swept away, engulfed in flames, destroyed by an earthquake, or similar disasters. Moreover, it seems particularly unfair for credit card companies to obscure the consequences imposed on consumers whose intent was always to meet their payment obligations, only thwarted by acts of God. Insurance policies do not extend coverage to acts of war, yet the government allowed the proprietor of the twin towers to receive insurance compensation despite the fact that the 911 incident was unequivocally an act of war. Polls indicate that a majority of Americans were dissatisfied because the 2008 financial bailouts offered them no relief whatsoever. The "Promise to Pay" does not specify that payments must be made monthly regardless of any other circumstances or events. I believe the "Promise to Pay" has been misunderstood by judges, and attorneys favor the current structure thus they are reluctant to address the evident flaws in credit card adhesion contracts as it might jeopardize their own future earnings.

When Bayview, a debt collection company, assumed responsibility for handling my mortgage, I started getting calls both at my workplace and on my mobile concerning my mortgage payments despite the fact that they were not overdue. These included automated calls. I was informed that this was 'standard procedure' and that I should disregard these calls, but I became quite frustrated and lodged a complaint with the BBB in the state where one of their offices is located. I consistently paid on time, and our mortgage was not under any debt collection process. Although Bayview is indeed a debt collector, they must ensure that their debt collection operations are distinct from their mortgage servicing. It should be illegal to contact individuals at work, use automated calling, or harass them when they do not have outstanding debts.

I am subscribed to a Senior plan for my mobile phone and I incur charges for each text message sent or received. While I can send and receive texts, there is a cost for every message... therefore, it seems unjust to impose additional charges beyond my current expenses. I oppose the use of mobile phones for commercial advertisement or debt collection communications.

I recommend examining the Federal Bankruptcy Rule 3001, effective from December 1, 2012, along with remarks made during the proposal stage, as well as the presentation statements from the hearing, which are published and accessible. The Rule already tackles the issues related to documentation. I still hold the view that including all the suggested paperwork with the validation notice is neither beneficial to the consumer nor the sender. I genuinely believe that extra documentation concerning the chain of title should be available if a consumer faces a lawsuit in Court.

Collection communications, whether through phone calls or written notices, should incorporate a distinct Collection ID. This identifier would be included in credit reports to facilitate monitoring. Furthermore, consumers should have the ability to log into an online database provided by the CRPB to report the type of violation or concern. This system would also simplify the process for the CRPB to investigate disputes and verify the existence of any actual problems.

When our client(s) fail to provide proof of the debt, we proceed by closing the account and informing the debtor through a letter about this action. It's worth mentioning that this scenario has occurred only once or twice in the past 20 years. Furthermore, an account with unresolved disputes should not be sold. If this happens, the seller should be held accountable.
