Just last week, they threatened to reach out to me at my workplace and said they would initiate civil action if I didn't respond before the end of the business day. Such actions are inappropriate and should be halted.

While I believe it is unnecessary for the CFPB to employ undercover agents, I do advocate for the establishment of a new category of examiners by the CFPB. At present, CFPB examiners focus solely on scrutinizing financial lenders and nonbank lenders. However, given that the CFPB is now expanding its oversight to include the collection industry, it is imperative for the CFPB to establish a distinct group of examiners dedicated to conducting onsite evaluations of debt collection firms. Implementing this change would not cause any detriment to the CFPB nor would it affect the CFPB's financial plan or its operational processes. The CFPB's funding is not determined through congressional approval but rather through financial allocations from the Federal Reserve. To establish this new class of examiners, the CFPB simply needs to request additional funds from the Federal Reserve. These additional examiners would not only help the CFPB keep a closer watch on the debt collection sector but also contribute to economic growth by creating more job opportunities. This approach presents a mutually beneficial outcome.

Having struggled for over two years with an aggressive collections firm wrongly listing a debt on my credit report, I strongly believe these debt buyers should be outlawed. Genuine third-party entities can function, but those unreliable companies that purchase debts for a fraction of their value, indifferent to the accuracy of records, should face penalties and be shut down. In essence, regulations should be stringent enough to make it economically unfeasible for them to continue operations. They only cause chaos for individuals. I have been dealing with a dishonest firm for two years; the Attorney General of my state intervened to have it removed from my credit report with one agency, only for the company to report it anew to another agency. No collection should appear on a credit report until it is fully verified. Furthermore, if a debt is older than two years, the creditor should be required to inform the alleged debtor in writing and provide a 30-day window for a response—be it denial, request for validation, payment, etc.—before it is listed on the credit report.

Halt any further attempts to gather or resell. Enforcing a rule that stops a collector from reporting details to a CRA within the 30-day period would be a nightmare akin to a horror movie and would only lead to additional complications. Disputes that remain unresolved should neither be sold nor kept in collections, full stop.

I firmly support and feel compelled to reiterate, even at the risk of repeating myself, that the inconsistency in regulations nationwide is truly concerning. This should not be misconstrued as a matter of 'state's rights,' as some might argue, but rather as an attempt to introduce more fairness and rationality into this procedure.

I reached out to the debt collection agency in an attempt to negotiate a payment plan for the outstanding debt, the reason behind my inability to settle the bills was because my husband had been laid off and was just starting a new job. I proposed to pay $100 each month, but the collectors refused. I then offered $200 monthly, which they also rejected, insisting on $1,000 a month instead. We are a family of six with a mortgage and utility bills. The debt collectors suggested $500 a month, while my husband earned $1,100 after taxes twice a month. With a mortgage of $1,300 each month, excluding utilities, I informed the debt company that I simply couldn't afford it. I always believed that paying something was better than nothing and assumed a debt company would be willing to negotiate. I came to realize that they are not willing to cooperate.

In my opinion, the 9-8 seems to be an error. I've noticed other mistakes on this website as well, and they offer an FDCPA link that indicates it should be 8-9, so it's not a significant issue. However, regarding this matter, I wish to see the 8-9 altered to 9-8. Calling at 8 is too early, and 9 is too late in the evening.

It would be a brilliant move to document these instances. From reviewing these remarks, it's evident that there are numerous instances of misconduct, it appears the Consumer Protection agency should have realized by now that phones are being used for harassment. To effectively halt this, laws need to be enforced with substantial penalties, rather than making it the consumer's responsibility to initiate legal action.

For the past three years, I've been receiving calls from debt collectors regarding a supposed debt. I consistently provide proof of payment, but it goes unnoticed, and after a few months, a different agency sends the same notice about the same debt. The debt collector never replies, investigates, or confirms the dispute. They should be mandated to do so.

The Ninth and First Circuits are currently divided on the applicability of 1692i and other FDCPA provisions to garnishment proceedings., In numerous states, the official defendant is the employer of the judgment debtor., Nevertheless, the actual party with a vested interest is the judgment debtor., and The CFPB should implement a rule that extends 1692i to garnishment proceedings, enabling consumers to more effectively claim defenses and exemptions provided by state law..

The federal government should establish clear regulations dictating how collection agencies and credit reporting agencies handle dispute investigations. All collection and reporting processes should cease instantly. The timeline for actions should be uniform for consumers, collection agencies, and credit reporting agencies. The original creditor or the collection agency that has bought the account must provide the original signed contract, any court documents, and relevant verifiable records concerning the dispute. These documents should be sent to the disputing party within the designated timeframe. All verification letters must clearly state and outline the findings. If a dispute cannot be verified through name, social security number, or a signed document of the original agreement, it must be removed immediately. Collection agencies and original creditors must ensure the accuracy of the information they acquire, purchase, receive, dispatch, or share. Thus, regardless of whether they acquire good or bad debt, they must be held accountable. All types of collections disputes, whether clear or ambiguous, should undergo the same level of investigation.

Such matters are generally governed by the family court regulations applicable in the debtor's area of residence. Factors like community property statutes, divorce or separation agreements, and domestic violence laws are all relevant in these situations.

It appears that virtually anyone has the ability to establish a debt collection agency and if those in charge or working there harbor unethical motives, it seems privacy becomes a significant issue. Additionally, given the ease of starting or owning debt collection firms, it's not surprising that numerous such companies violate regulations. Stricter regulations should be implemented regarding the creation of debt collection agencies and the selection of their personnel.

Having extensive experience in evaluating credit reports, I am deeply disturbed by a recurring practice I encounter. Debt collectors often refile the report of a debt as overdue on a monthly basis. This practice severely damages the credit ratings of consumers.

In cases where a consumer disputes a debt, the debt collector must halt all collection efforts until the debt is properly verified. Moreover, verification should involve more than just confirming that the name and social security details align with the creditor's files. The verification process must provide a comprehensive and clear copy of every document that constitutes the claimed debt. If such documents do not exist, the debt should be nullified.
What is the rationale behind requiring an agency to send a letter to a consumer who has already asked not to be contacted by phone? Chances are, they probably won't even look at it

In the past, I was burdened with significant debt and instructed each creditor that contacted me to send written correspondence. I settled every debt for which I received a mailed notice. Years afterward, an entity pursued me again and due to my lack of understanding of the regulations, I found myself trapped. To this day, I haven't received any written documentation to confirm what the debt pertains to — and the legal system offered no better clarity — I was not afforded the opportunity to speak with the judge. Is this fair?

The agency should exercise caution with new regulations that might inadvertently damage the free market. It is crucial to monitor litigation to ensure that the system does not allow for rewards without accompanying risks. A lawsuit plaintiff should not be placed in a scenario where it becomes rewarding to sue without valid reasons and with minimal risk. Creditors and individuals involved in recovery processes do not require additional regulations in this regard. because their activities are overseen by the CFPB. It is unnecessary for the CFPB to establish standards for the industry, but it should be specified that only the documents submitted in the initial court filing will be considered in a CFPB review. Should a CFPB review reveal that a lawsuit was filed without proper fact verification, the CFPB might award the amount sought to the defendant and impose a fine ranging from $2,000 to the sought amount. This stance would encourage litigants to verify their facts before filing. This approach would permit the CFPB to review cases irrespective of the court's decision. This review could be performed at CFPB offices since it only necessitates the original filings. This review could be triggered by a complaint lodged with the agency's offices. The penalty could be adjusted according to various agency standards. I would need to allocate more time to assess situations where the plaintiff is neither the original creditor nor part of the recovery sector, yet, there still must be a risk linked to the reward to deter frivolous lawsuits.

Bank of America never informed me that they had sold my credit card and subsequently closed the account. Upon discovering this, I promptly settled the outstanding balance. In that same period, after enduring prolonged illnesses, both my Father and Mother passed away, only 31 days apart. Understandably, managing credit card payments was not my primary concern at that time. Moreover, the fact that banks or credit card companies are exempt from Usury laws doesn't mean they aren't committing such violations. This practice needs to be addressed and halted!

Debt collectors have contacted me, accusing me of failing to cooperate in settling the debt, shouting at me, and suggesting I'm either lazy or unaware of my financial obligations. They've reached out to me from as early as 7:00 in the morning until 9:00 in the evening, up to ten times a day, using different company names, phone numbers, and locations, including both my city and various other cities and states within the same day. Upon informing them that I'm a senior citizen, they advise me to borrow money from family or friends. When I refuse, the barrage of harassment begins anew. Several callers pretend to be longtime acquaintances before revealing their actual identities. They threaten to damage my credit score, seize my home, possessions, and vehicle, The most irritating scenario is when they call, and upon answering, they hang up, only to repeat this an hour later. I'm aware it's them thanks to my caller ID.
Got it. What I was trying to convey is that, due to my job, I'm familiar with numerous automated dialers. These dialers don't redial on their own. They are compelled to do so by the company.

It seems you think that the attorney representing the creditor or debt collector ought to provide legal counsel to the consumer, who is essentially the adversary in this situation. This poses a major conflict of interest and breaches the attorney's obligation to their client. Even more troubling is the notion that you appear to desire non-attorney debt collectors, or those not affiliated with a legal firm, to offer legal guidance to consumers. This action contravenes the regulations against the unauthorized practice of law. I recognize the issue stemming from the lack of knowledge and sophistication shown by defendant debtors. My suggestion is for the CFPB to create a standard notice outlining rights under the FDCPA. Should it decide to do so, the CFPB could also feature a section on its website dedicated to resources specific to state laws and include a reference to this site in the notice form.

Displaying a collector's toll-free number on Caller ID is the most favorable option, because it enables individuals to return the call from any location without incurring long-distance fees. Additionally, it immediately signals to the recipient that the call is not personal and likely not from a local business. I would much prefer to see an 800 number rather than a falsified local number from a company that is actually located 1000 miles away (or overseas in India). Such spoofing is undoubtedly a misleading and dishonest tactic that is prohibited by the FDCPA, yet it still occasionally occurs.

Why can't we return to the way things were in the past? For over 35 years, I've been a "victim" of aggressive debt collectors. In earlier times, a debt would be handled by a single collector who persistently chased me for a debt that wasn't mine. Today, with automated dialers, collection calls are directed to the "next available operator." Why not revert to the times when only one collector was tasked with making contact?

It is essential to implement measures to prevent frivolous lawsuits, as agencies are compelled to expend significant funds defending themselves, even after explaining to consumers or their attorneys that no misconduct occurred and no case exists. Many of these consumers initiate lawsuits on their own without legal representation and persist in seeking a settlement or trial. In such scenarios, agencies are forced to allocate resources to demonstrate that there was never a valid reason for legal action, ultimately requiring judicial confirmation of their innocence. Consider imposing penalties on consumers or their legal representatives when they issue settlement demands or initiate lawsuits despite being presented with evidence that no legitimate case exists or ever existed.

At present, credit reporting agencies disclaim accountability for disseminating incorrect data provided to them. Credit reporting agencies ought to be held accountable for both real and punitive damages resulting from the dissemination of incorrect data.

I've had the experience of a debt collector repeatedly calling me within a single day, even after they received my voicemail. Despite having already spoken to them, explaining my situation, and setting up a 'payment date,' they still call me again the very next day. I'm uncertain whether their system communicates internally or if they just use an 'auto dialer' that makes calls incessantly. This behavior is overbearing and borders on harassment. Moreover, they tend to call at 10pm or 9pm, which I consider an inappropriate time for such calls. There should be a sensible time frame for making calls, determined by the time zone in which you reside, not just the area code of your mobile number.

Email is a beneficial substitute however, it often ends up in the junk or spam folder and its intended function is not fulfilled. A combination of regular mail with email follow-up would be more effective

I got an invoice from a lawyer's office for a charge I believed wasn't mine. I sent a certified letter requesting verification, but I never got any reply. Therefore, I dispatched a second certified letter seeking validation, yet again, no reply came. The legal firm initiated a civil lawsuit and dragged me to court. I presented my case to the judge, backing it up with evidence. My evidence included copies of the validation requests, USPS certified letter statements, and verification receipt statements filed with the court. Unfortunately, the judge disregarded all of this. because I represented myself and was unfamiliar with Washington state laws. I had made the validation request before the lawsuit was filed. Later, an attorney clarified that local county civil courts adhere only to state laws, not federal, and in state court, a validation request isn't acknowledged. I also asked for proof of licensing, which I didn't obtain because the claimant was not, and still isn't, licensed as a debt collection agency in Washington state. - they are practicing attorneys. The claimant won the lawsuit and I ended up responsible for a debt that wasn't mine. I ask you, how is this just? It is crucial that laws are made transparent for both ordinary citizens and the judiciary.

Much like how cable providers might require their clients to accommodate a four-hour slot for service appointments, it is reasonable that consumers should have the option to select a preferred time window for receiving calls. Should there be no response during the chosen period, the debt collector can then attempt to reach out at a different time.

Debt collectors should be required to confirm that they are communicating with the debtor or another adult in the household when discussing debts. This requirement is outlined in the FDCPA. However, based on my own experiences, this protocol is not always adhered to. My personal experience dates back to the 1970s, and during that time, this verification was practiced. It is likely that similar practices are still occurring in the present day. Harassing calls, threats, shouting, and swearing at children achieve nothing for debt collectors. Such behavior is an abhorrent form of mistreatment that should not be accepted under any circumstances. The FDCPA should be amended to explicitly prohibit these actions. Furthermore, there ought to be penalties imposed on collectors who partake in these degrading and ineffective tactics.

On my credit report, there's an alias listed that I've never used. Despite multiple disputes, I cannot remove this alias and the associated debt from my record. Therefore, I advocate for federal laws that obligate agencies to provide documentation or legal evidence proving a consumer used that alias in any credit application or paperwork. In cases of disputes with a Credit Reporting Agency (CRA), they should also be required to request this documentation from the agencies involved. CRAs ought to act as impartial entities, serving as enforcement authorities on all sides. CRAs must be obligated to report precise information and be held accountable for collecting accurate data. At present, they serve as repositories of inaccurate information, often siding with collectors. There is no dependable agency championing consumers' rights. Without enforcement, federal laws are merely ineffective words on paper.

I agree with the earlier statement. Consumers should be notified when our mortgages are sold, and this should be standardized. It's not costly to send a notice through the mail. The notification should include details such as the amount, information about the original debt, the name and address of the new debt holder, and ideally the price at which the debt was sold. This helps consumers monitor their financial situation and ensures debts aren't mistakenly listed twice on our credit histories. It also informs individuals whom they should reach out to regarding the debt.

In situations where a consumer alleges identity theft, debt collectors must be mandated to demonstrate the contrary. Credit reporting agencies should be prohibited from listing any debt as identity theft-related unless they can present legally admissible evidence proving its legitimacy. It is imperative that credit reporting agencies face stringent consequences and substantial penalties for disseminating inaccurate data. These penalties should be awarded directly to consumers for the extensive time they dedicate to rectifying their credit histories. Credit reporting agencies must be obliged to inform consumers' insurance and mortgage providers, along with others who imposed elevated charges due to incorrect credit scores, and ascertain the financial impact on the consumer. The total of these extra expenses should be compensated by the credit reporting agencies to the consumer, in addition to the fines imposed. Responsibility for proof should rest with the credit reporting agencies and debt collectors, rather than the consumer.

Frequently, I receive automated calls regarding debts of family members, sometimes as many as three or four times a day, usually concerning relatives I haven't communicated with for many years. I'm puzzled as to how they obtained my phone number. since it's unlisted and I'm confident that my family members don't have it.

Kindly READ this insightful piece on global debt. Continuing with the current debt collection practices only serves to endorse a flawed system. PLEASE TAKE FURTHER ACTION beyond that, Please WORK TOWARDS EQUALIZING THE DEBT CONDITIONS. GLOBAL DEBT CRISIS UNADDRESSED. __URL__

I am troubled by the possibility that state and federal bodies are significantly facilitating identity theft. Just last month, I was compelled to settle an online payment regarding what I consider a federal Hobbs Act breach by the Los Angeles Building and Safety Department. The day following my payment, which I made to avoid losing my home, the same credit card was fraudulently used by criminals online. Subsequently, a few weeks later, another agency requested bank records, which I faxed to them, only for those documents to disappear! Moreover, there seemed to be a lack of concern about the disappearance of these documents.

When crafting regulations for this section, please take into account the aspect of robo-calls. Refer to my remarks regarding robo-callers leaving messages on mobile phones under the topic of robo-calling. I recognize the importance of safeguarding privacy, however, this approach is not the solution. Messages left on my mobile phone could have been accessed by anyone using the phone (relatives, curious friends), thus revealing information about an alleged overdue payment through the robo-caller. Robo-calling does not prioritize the consumer's privacy.

Though I don't support the idea of daily robo-calls, it makes me question why consumers end up receiving them in the first place. Getting such calls every day suggests that the consumer is constantly neglecting their debt. Regrettably, there is a segment of the population that thinks like this. If consumers find themselves in a difficult situation, it seems logical that they would either answer the call or reach out to the debt collectors to try and resolve the issue. Regarding regulations, I believe a single call per week is adequate. The purpose of robo-calls is to keep the debt fresh in consumers' minds so that when they have the funds, they remember to settle the debt. Any other intention would likely be seen as an attempt to badger the consumer into making a payment. The segment of people who permit this will never make the payment anyway so why continue the charade. Even robo-calls incur costs so why keep wasting good money on a lost cause. After three decades in this business, I have come to understand there are two kinds of people: those who are willing to pay their bills and those who never had any intention of doing so.

It's incredibly perplexing whether I should pay my student loans directly to the Department of Education or to one of the numerous private entities that have managed my loan over time. They persistently try to lure me into restructuring the student loan debt - it's very deceptive - without revealing their fees. Currently, I can't even identify a $30,000 fee that was incorrectly billed twice to my account. It's a tangled web of confusion that I can't break free from. I foresee carrying my student loans to my grave. since I have no other means to manage the monthly payments.

In my opinion, the most pressing issue arises from financial institutions operating two separate systems that are not seamlessly connected. The first system is a record-keeping platform that holds detailed account information while the second is a charge-off system designed for monitoring activities post charge-off. Typically, events logged in the charge-off system don't get updated in the record-keeping system. Moreover, the charge-off system is neither employed nor intended for credit reporting purposes. Another issue stems from mergers or acquisitions where only the record-keeping system is integrated, neglecting the acquired charge-off system. This creates an informational gap regarding the account's status after it has been charged off. When accounts are outsourced or sold the dependency falls on the record-keeping system, rather than on the charge-off system. A third complication arises when a consumer holds multiple accounts with the original lender, increasing the likelihood that different accounts may be transferred to varying agencies or debt purchasers. Even if debt buyers and collectors can access the accounts, the activities recorded are typically absent from the record-keeping system, while the charge-off system might no longer be in use. The matter of credit reporting disputes hinges on whether data is provided to a credit reporting agency by the agency or debt buyer. The volume of consumer data previously and currently reported to credit agencies may lack precision, especially regarding charged-off accounts, and demanding a title chain would be costly without guaranteeing accuracy. Moving forward, I believe the primary emphasis should be placed on ensuring the accuracy of credit reporting.

Banks should be mandated to inform consumers beforehand if they intend to sell their debt, providing them a fair opportunity to buy back their own debt under terms as favorable as those offered to other debt purchasers, typically at a fraction of the original debt value. Debt buyers offer no benefits to the community. Nevertheless, they are permitted to reap substantial profits by targeting financially struggling consumers to collect the full amount owed. Implementing this idea would require more than just a simple notification. It would necessitate transitioning from bulk sales of loans to allowing the purchase of individual loans in specific situations.

I propose eliminating the option for initiating a lawsuit in the jurisdiction where the consumer originally signed the contract. Often, consumers do not actually sign a contract, such as with credit cards, or they might sign an agreement in a far-off place, like for medical expenses at a hospital while on a vacation, or they might have relocated since opening the account. I consider it most favorable for consumers to allow lawsuits to be filed where the consumer currently lives, except when dealing with real estate, in which case it should occur where the property is situated. Regarding concerns about geographic size, many states are experiencing financial crises that impact the civil branches of state courts. In one of our largest districts, the available courts for filing suits were reduced from 32 to just 2. To ensure consumer protection in this area, I suggest incorporating a rule segment that prevents collectors from selecting a court venue with the aim of hindering the consumer's ability to engage in the legal process. To establish a violation, the consumer or regulatory body must show that the collector had no other reason to file in that particular court other than to impose a burden on the consumer, thus proving intent.

Before a case reaches the stage of litigation, the debtor has already been given at least one prior chance to settle the debt with the collector, which is through the initial demand letter. This letter, as required by law, must inform the debtor about their right to dispute the legitimacy of the debt being claimed. If the CFPB were to make obtaining a default judgment more challenging, it would essentially be providing a benefit to those debtors who decide not to take any steps to address their grievances. Moreover, it's debatable whether the CFPB has the jurisdiction to enforce additional, more onerous obligations on parties involved in state court proceedings. Such an action would imply that state court civil procedural rules fail to ensure due process in other kinds of cases that don't receive the "advantage" of federal supervision.

I've always used paper applications when seeking credit, and every creditor I've dealt with has a mountain of paperwork. I'm unsure about the process when applying online, but what stops someone from falsely claiming they are owed money? Creditors must shoulder the responsibility of proving their claims, and if they're not obtaining signed documents, they need to provide solid evidence. If you believe they wouldn't deceive, I have some oceanfront property in Nebraska to sell you.

There should be a complete ban on making calls to individuals at their workplaces. Contacting someone while they are at work can attract the employer's attention, potentially leading to the employee's dismissal or hindering their career progression. As a result of such inappropriate behavior, the collector ends up not receiving payment.

It is often suggested to address credit report disputes through written communication. because online processes tend to be expedited by the personnel assigned to manage them. There is no obligation to resolve these issues online.

My spouse reached out to a creditor concerning payments for an old account and aimed to update the account status after missing payments because of unemployment. The creditor proceeded to reopen the account under a different account number. As a result, I now have two accounts listed on my credit report reflecting identical amounts.

Unexpected changes in assignments might result in individuals mistakenly paying the incorrect party. The CFPB ought to promote appropriate notification by deciding that a payment made to either the original creditor or the new assignee should decrease the overall debt.

My relatives encountered the same problem with Bank of America. Despite paying their mortgage ahead of time each month, they were consistently marked as late. This situation is heartbreaking and severely damaged their credit score. It takes years to restore credit when false, inaccurate, and repeated information is reported by collectors. Bank of America should face significant penalties for these violations because otherwise, consumer grievances are simply ignored.

If email communication is permitted, it should be restricted to the hours deemed appropriate for phone conversations. I propose that emails be confined to regular working hours based on the debtor's local time. It's important to ensure that no business-related emails are dispatched from the office beyond standard business hours. This aligns with fundamental and conventional email etiquette in the business world. Yet, there might be room for negotiation regarding the norms for phone call timings. Additionally, I believe that emails should not be sent on Sundays. Since the USPS doesn't operate on Sundays, business emails should likewise be avoided on this day.

Jeffreyjon, you seem to be describing the behavior of someone who defaults on payments deliberately. On the other hand, those who default involuntarily lack the financial means to settle their debts, especially when interest keeps piling up.
I concur. I've come across stories of this occurring and it's unfair.

When it comes to medical debt, the notice should clearly indicate the date and place where the service was received, and importantly, the name of the attending physician (instead of a third-party agency that never communicated with the patient) or the name commonly associated with the facility (such as a hospital or clinic) where the treatment occurred. Based on my experience, consumers who are cautious about costs and wary of scams have sometimes refused to settle valid medical debts because they could not recognize the debt and were unable to get a straightforward answer to the question, "Why am I being asked to pay this?" It is wise to withhold payment when the debt lacks a clear explanation, yet if the debt is legitimate, failing to pay can lead to significant penalties for the consumer. A medical debt validation letter should avoid using only numerical codes or confusing abbreviations. The notice should clearly state, "You received a bill on (DATE) for your visit to (PLACE)." If there are other payments associated with the same visit that have been settled, the letter should mention this, for instance, "You have already paid for other services from this visit, but you still owe..." or "Your insurance covered part of the costs for this visit, but you still owe...." This problem is linked to the overwhelming complexities of medical billing, yet these complexities should never be used to obscure the origin of a debt from the consumer.

In my opinion, this practice is already implemented in three significant ways. Creditors typically mandate that all their clients provide updated contact details, When a consumer relocates, the new address and any other updated contact information are reflected in their credit report, and lastly, the USPS keeps track of mail forwarding instructions once a consumer relocates.

Since I am responsible for the phone minutes I purchase, it is only right that I have the freedom to decide which calls to accept or reject. When a call appears as 'unknown', how can I distinguish if it's a collection agency, a telemarketer offering vacation properties, cruise lines selling trips, or someone proposing a better mortgage rate, among others? Every time I pick up a call, it reduces my available minutes. This situation is unjust to me. I've taken the step of blocking all calls listed as 'unknown, withheld, and private'. If the callers are genuinely legitimate and wish to communicate with me, they can press 1 to get through, just as I am required to do.

The debate between States' Rights and Federal Rights stands as a central challenge in formulating rules. The significant variation in states' legal requirements leads to confusion among consumers, regulators, and industry professionals regarding applicable laws in different contexts. Implementing a single, universal rule across all scenarios would help eliminate the existing ambiguity and conflict caused by various levels of regulation at the municipal, state, and dual federal levels.

I frequently receive calls, typically once a week, from individuals involved in legal cases who tell me, "I got served with a summons today, and it indicates that I must respond to this complaint within 10 (or 30) days, but there's no specified court date on the documents for me to attend." I then have to explain the process to them and highlight the section explaining that they are not required to physically appear in court to respond. I'm uncertain about how the wording in the summons could be made any clearer, I comprehend them entirely, not merely because I'm acquainted with the forms, I guess it might be because I am more knowledgeable than the typical litigant I encounter. The complaints initially indicate that they have the rights to the debt, supported by a notarized verification... however, they cannot proceed with the default judgment unless they submit the affidavit signed by both the previous and current debt owners, which is usually included with their judgments.

You're not telling the truth! For more than five years, I've been persistently bothered by companies searching for an individual I've never known. This happened because the person randomly combined parts of our area code, local exchange, and four digits, which coincidentally resulted in my phone number, to put on a loan that he later defaulted on. I've repeatedly informed them to cease calling as they have the wrong number, and guess what? Even after five years, the calls have not stopped!

Back in 2008, a firm in Michigan faced revocation of its Collection Agency status because of unethical conduct. However, this did not deter them. They have since transitioned into legal practice, where they persist with the same unethical behavior. Indeed, it is imperative that states devise strategies to eliminate this loophole.

Leaving a detailed voicemail that clearly states the reason for the call shows a commendable level of diligence. Opting to call without leaving a message is essentially equivalent to doing nothing. This approach ensures that their message is communicated.

I interpret "free to end" as the agency being responsible for the charges incurred from that specific call. I believe it is absolutely worth investigating further. There are instances where the consumer does not have a landline and denies access to their mobile phone. Upon receiving a cease and desist request, we annotate the account and return it to our client accordingly. If a consumer simply requests not to be contacted via mobile, we remove the mobile number and send a collection letter, provided it adheres to FDCPA regulations. Another approach might be to send a settlement letter offering the consumer a chance to save money while resolving the matter. The industry certainly has not established a commendable standard. and regulation is undoubtedly necessary. I believe the majority of us understand the message clearly and are ensuring strict compliance. The approach needs to be two-pronged. Consumers need to be open to discussing their accounts and showing a readiness to settle them. Ultimately, if all debts were settled, there would be no need for any calls. And that is not intended to seem confrontational. The undeniable truth is that debts remain and our clients expect their payments. Consumers need to bear some of the accountability.

Contacting a debtor at their workplace seems illogical; if collectors repeatedly call someone at their job, there's a chance that coworkers might bring this up with the debtor's boss. Many businesses have guidelines restricting personal calls on company or mobile phones during work hours. If a collector or creditor contacts a debtor on their mobile phone and learns the debtor is at work, the call should be immediately ended. Calls to the debtor's place of employment should be strictly prohibited. because it puts the debtor's employment at risk. How does this assist in collecting debts? It doesn't.

I concur with RBell. Borrowers who are overdue are typically aware of their situation. Thus, sending additional alerts tends to be ineffective. Any notifications sent should clearly state the name of the original account holder and display the complete account number to link any debt collector to the initial account holder.

In my opinion, the reason behind some individuals being in debt is due to health issues that have hindered their ability to earn a living. Such individuals might be receiving Social Security disability benefits as a result. There are instances where medical conditions, like heart diseases or anxiety disorders, are scientifically proven to be exacerbated by stress. As it stands, the FDCPA's Section 806 prohibits any form of abuse or harassment towards debtors. Nonetheless, what constitutes abuse could vary for a debtor suffering from a stress-sensitive, disabling health issue. I wish, and propose, that there exists a mechanism for debtors to inform collection agencies about their documented medical disabilities, emphasizing that harassing calls could have further health implications.

Federal district and circuit courts are presently divided over the question of whether a debt assignee after default is covered by the creditor exception. The CFPB ought to establish a regulation clarifying that a post-default assignee qualifies as a collector under the FDCPA.

I assert that collection agencies are unreliable and frequently exceed their authorized functions. Some of them operate like loan sharks instead of legitimate collection agencies. Furthermore, I believe their conduct becomes borderline criminal when they resort to threatening consumers and harassing vulnerable groups like disabled individuals and the elderly. Therefore, I advocate for the pursuit of criminal charges against these agencies for their cover-ups, harassment, and other violations of privacy and fairness.

Over three decades ago, someone residing at my address owed money to Household Finance. We still receive letters, which we send back marked 'Addressee Unknown,' and get calls. Eventually, I returned a call and informed them that the individual they sought was not at this address. That law firm ceased their automated calls. However, after a few months, a different company began contacting us. There should be a record-keeping process that tracks the transfer of debts from one collection agency to another. Why should I have to endure this ordeal again? Additionally, I believe that after two years, debt collectors should not be allowed to use an address to obtain a phone number. This debt dates back more than 30 years. Why would they assume that anyone familiar with this place would still reside here? I searched for the woman's name on Google. On my first try, I discovered she lives approximately 10 miles away from here. If I can locate her with such ease, why can't a debt collector, who has a vested interest, be motivated to conduct some basic research?

Establishing a national registry for collectors and providing them with an identification number similar to the IRS would be beneficial. Mandate that they disclose their name and identification number in the same manner as IRS staff. This system would enable debtors to promptly recognize a problematic collector or reach out to a debt collection agency to request communication with a specific agent. When leaving a voicemail, they are obligated to include their ID number in the message. Such a measure would be advantageous for both debtors and collectors.

It looks like the debt collection sector is engaged in money laundering and racketeering, exploiting consumers by extracting funds for goods they haven't sold or services they haven't provided, all without any initial purchase agreement. Debt collectors are reportedly obtaining funds from consumers in regions where they lack the necessary licenses to sell goods or offer services. Debt collectors are causing financial losses for companies attempting to recover unpaid debts from customers who have legally purchased their goods or services. It appears that debt collectors are depending on both corporate and consumer funds for their livelihood, even though they weren't part of the initial sale or distribution of goods and services.

Implementing this concept would be remarkable. At present, debt purchasers acquire debt at an average cost of four cents per dollar. Numerous debts are purchased for amounts ranging from two to four cents on the dollar. Additionally, many debts are transferred at no cost. As an initial lender, I would want to maximize the returns on the debt owed to me. Thus, if I could obtain ten cents directly from the debtor instead of four cents from a debt purchaser, I would certainly offer a considerably reduced settlement option to the debtor, which involves consumers bidding on their own debt. Currently, original lenders do not provide substantial discounts to debtors before selling for four cents on the dollar. Most creditors hardly offer debtors even a 10% reduction on the debt as a settlement. Certainly, creditors could swiftly dispose of debt portfolios to buyers by selling them at four cents on the dollar. However, creditors could potentially earn significantly more by providing a one-time opportunity at ten cents on the dollar or another appealing rate that exceeds four cents. The CFPB might consider establishing a regulation that grants consumers/debtors a limited-time opportunity, perhaps lasting 45 days from the date of the notification, to accept a substantially reduced rate from their creditors. This offer would have a short validity period and would inform the consumer that, if declined, the creditor would proceed to sell the debt to a buyer. Such a letter would only be dispatched if the creditor intends to sell the debt, rather than as another collection attempt. In this manner, consumers are given a final opportunity to settle their outstanding debt. Creditors incur fewer losses, gain higher profits, and can offer more loans, better rates, and thereby boost the economy. More money exchanging hands at higher values, like ten cents on the dollar compared to four, instead of sitting in accounts receivable indefinitely, stimulates economic growth. This policy would have no adverse effects and would bring benefits to everyone involved. A minor consequence could be the debt collection industry receiving fewer debts in their acquisition. However, this minor consequence is outweighed by the substantial benefits to the economy.

Most of the clients I assist are keen on settling their outstanding accounts. The primary problem is that many collection agencies refuse to issue a letter of agreement until the payment has been completed. Moreover, clients frequently experience delays of several weeks before receiving a receipt. Some clients have even mentioned to me that they were asked to pay $10.00 to obtain a receipt.

Failing to fulfill a payment commitment isn't equivalent to committing a crime. It's not appropriate to equate criminal law with civil law as they are fundamentally different. However, the crucial aspect missing here is the justification for interest. Let’s put the focus away from large financial institutions for a moment, and consider the scenario of borrowing funds from a close friend or neighbor. Holding onto money that belongs to another person causes them harm, since they are deprived of the opportunity to either invest it for growth or spend it to enhance their living standards. This is one of the reasons why interest is charged to provide compensation for the temporary loss of access to their funds until repayment. I acknowledge that interest rates can be exorbitant and indeed, they often are but unfortunately, that is a distinct matter. Yet, eliminating interest entirely and allowing borrowers to indefinitely halt their debt repayments because they borrowed irresponsibly or didn't foresee unexpected costs... I doubt anyone, aside from perhaps one's parents, would agree to lend under such conditions.

Should the CFPB wish to regulate this domain, it seems essential to begin collaborative actions with State judicial bodies. Given that the CFPB functions as a federal entity, it lacks the power to dictate to State administrations, including their judicial systems, how to manage or interpret their own legal frameworks. With certain states, such as New York, already making strides in this direction, the CFPB might anticipate a welcoming response to this initiative. However, pursuing changes through federal rulemaking is not feasible in this specific context.

The FDCPA outlines specific criteria that must be met to verify a debt owed by a customer. Federal law includes investigation mandates when a consumer challenges a claim. It's not possible for a debt to be fabricated without grounds. Agencies engaging in such practices are typically halted swiftly and face substantial fines, along with cease and desist orders and regulatory measures. Essentially, while debt collectors must uphold certain data and verify specific information, consumers need only state, "I don't owe this" to temporarily cease collection efforts. Like debt collectors, a few wrongdoers tarnish the reputation of those who act correctly. I believe consumers should be obligated to provide some form of evidence when disputing claims.

Obtain a copy of the police report and send it via mail to all three agencies. They are obligated to place a freeze on your report, and you will be provided with a pin, which you must use if you ever need to lift the freeze. It is indeed a hassle. In 2012, I experienced a burglary with 14 pages listing stolen items, and I was required to contact all my credit card companies to have new cards issued. It was heartbreaking—not just for losing items like my computer, but for losing things with significant personal and sentimental worth. At the very least, you should have the reassurance that comes with a freeze on your report. And they are compelled to comply. If not, consult a lawyer and let the authorities feel the pressure of legal action. It's inconvenient, but ultimately worth the effort.
Customers should have the option to ask for calls to be restricted to a single interaction weekly, should they wish. This represents a reasonable and respectable middle ground,

Numerous courts have determined, with concurrence from both the FTC and CFPB, that pursuing or threatening legal action for a debt that is beyond the statute of limitations breaches the FDCPA. The FDCPA explicitly forbids the use of any false, deceptive, or misleading representations or methods when attempting to collect a debt. This includes misrepresenting the nature, amount, or legal status of a debt, threatening to take actions that cannot legally be taken or are not intended to be taken, and using deceptive means to collect or attempt to collect a debt. __URL__ Claiming that statutes of limitations serve as a defense mechanism to prevent a plaintiff from being unfairly penalized for failing to file a timely lawsuit is a significant misinterpretation and misrepresentation of the law.

I've noticed that the procedures among different creditors can differ significantly when it comes to handing over overdue or default debts to a collection agency. In my case, I received little to no advance warning. Creditors should at least provide detailed information, including the date and the company to which the debt is being assigned or sold. Receiving such a notice would clarify that there will be a shift in whom I will be interacting with from that point onward. The costs, expenses, or issues faced by debt collectors are minor in comparison to the problems that arise from not providing a notice. I assert that sending such notices would actually result in cost savings over time. The notification should clearly include: (1) the date when the debt will be transferred to the collection agency; (2) the name and address of the collection firm that received the debt; and (3) detailed information about the debt collection company along with a list of their 'best practices', policies, and procedures to inform consumers of what they should expect. Involuntary Default implies that the defaulter agrees to repay only the amount owed at the time of the default, without additional charges. I discovered an unsealed envelope in my mailbox containing court papers. I reached out to the debt collection agency to inquire about the situation because I hadn't been properly served. They asserted that a substitute service had been executed at my residence. I pointed out that such a service was improbable as I am a caregiver and would be the sole person to answer the door, yet no service occurred. I was compelled to pay for filing a response, which was delayed by a day, and had to contest the default due to the lack of service. The judge concurred that the subservice was invalid since the service company used the most unremarkable description they could muster: a woman aged between mid-30s to late-40s, approximately 5 feet 4 inches tall, weighing around 130 to 150 pounds. That is one of the most vague descriptions imaginable, and it was utterly incorrect. because such a person did not exist. They even fabricated a name unfamiliar to me, and upon searching online, I found no traces of it. The second instance of a false subservice presented a description that closely resembled the initial one, and the supposed recipient of the subservice was labeled "Jane Doe". I wish to highlight how perilous these fabrications can be from another perspective. I have been solely responsible for providing caregiving services to my parents, with no other individuals involved. By falsifying information in court documents, there could be future allegations accusing me of exposing my parents to a non-existent person at our home. I was also somewhat paralyzed by the depth of this deception because on the rare occasions I needed to sue someone, I adhered to legal protocols and ensured proper service was conducted. I simply anticipated the same courtesy in return and failing to receive it diminishes one's capacity to respond effectively.

The most pressing issue that stands out is clearly the phone number displayed on caller ID, indicating it should reflect the actual business number and, if a message is left, the return call number should be the same.
jfearon, it seems that this task requires online processing. I successfully managed to tidy up a relative's credit report through online means.

Let's begin by presuming that a creditor has supplied something for which a consumer has agreed to make a payment. Creditors ought to have the right to obtain the consumer's phone number and address for contact purposes, and receive updates while any debt remains unpaid. Should a consumer opt to use only a mobile phone, it is reasonable for the creditor and collector to contact them using that number.

For several years, I've received phone calls intended for a Hispanic man who shares my phone number but has a different area code. Whenever I inform the callers that I don't know this person and request that they stop dialing my number, they always promise to resolve the issue. However, after a few weeks, they inevitably contact me again.

This approach could be effective if every state implemented sensible, informed, and practical guidelines for collection. However, the wide variation in the costs of obtaining a report clearly indicates significant differences between states. I strongly believe that establishing some level of consistency is urgently necessary. Such standardization would enable individuals to understand their obligations and anticipate what is required.

In my company, it is customary to issue a debt validation notice to almost every account that is referred to us. Although not mandatory, it is considered a best practice. In most situations, I believe that the original creditor informs the consumer via their bill if their account will be sent to collections. Moreover, it's essential to adopt a realistic perspective. Is there a chance that a consumer might not be informed about their account being transferred to collections? Indeed, that is possible. Nevertheless, most consumers, if not all, are aware that they haven't settled their bill for over 30 days and thus may face collections. It's about time that personal responsibility is emphasized in rule-making, ensuring the rules cater to the majority rather than focusing on the uncommon scenarios where the process might fail.

I'm currently enduring a dreadful ordeal with a creditor and a debt collector. In 2004, I graduated from college and consolidated all my student loans through Nelnet. Around 2005, I began receiving calls from debt collectors claiming I was behind on my loan payments. I clarified that I had consistently made my payments to Nelnet and insisted on seeing evidence of the debt before making any further payments. However, I never received any such proof of the debt. This scenario repeated itself multiple times over the next five years. In 2011, I aimed to purchase my wife's dream home. This was a major financial commitment. The bankers I consulted informed me that resolving the student loan issue was necessary for approval. I contacted both the original creditor and the debt collector, pleading for some form of loan documentation. What they provided was simply a loan application, lacking any indication of approval or disbursement of funds. Although I was uneasy about the evidence provided, I realized that pursuing legal action would take more time than I was willing to invest. Therefore, I was careful in my discussions with the creditor and debt collector to ensure my credit report would be cleared upon paying the full amount of the supposed loan. I also recorded my conversations with both the creditor and the debt collector. I settled the original loan balance, but, as you might have anticipated, the original creditor refused to update my credit report. Even after supplying credit reporting agencies with proof of payment, they also declined to amend my credit report. To complicate matters further, after the debt was paid, the debt collector sent me a notice stating that several thousand dollars had been forgiven. I promptly contacted the debt collector, requesting documentation to support their claimed amount, including proof of agreed interest rates. No reply from the debt collector. Currently, I'm disputing the issue with the IRS regarding possible additional taxes. And, despite having paid the debt two years prior, my credit report remains unchanged. It's utterly absurd that any company can wield such influence to negatively affect a person's life without backing it up with proper documentation. Creditors should be mandated to present specific documentation before filing negative credit reports, with severe penalties for those pursuing debts without the necessary proof.

The initial lender possesses details regarding the debtor's preferred language; ii) The debt collector discovers the debtor's language preference; *or* iii) The debtor resides in an area where a significant proportion (perhaps 5%?) of the population does not speak English. This requirement should focus solely on languages with large Limited English Proficiency (LEP) communities - a possible threshold could be 100,000 - to prevent excessive costs. Could consumers be given the option to completely opt out of specific types of communication? Implementing clear and restricted rate hikes for each communication method that consumers choose to eliminate could be an approach for debt collectors. Establishing a rule on such rate hikes would provide essential clarity regarding the value of these communications for the agencies.

The Pro Publica article on a particular 'installment' loan company highlights numerous instances of harassment that exceed acceptable limits and are not addressed by this terminology. Absolutely appalling behavior. __URL__

Concealing caller ID details is, at the very least, misleading. Moreover, the majority of consumers are unlikely to engage with calls from hidden numbers or unknown IDs. It should be mandatory for collectors to reveal their identity and provide caller ID information that accurately reflects who they are. A significant number of individuals who struggle to settle their bills are already conscious of their financial issues, therefore, being alerted under deceptive circumstances tends to be more irritating than effective in addressing the issue.

I wish there were some measures in place to shield me from the persistent calls I've been receiving for many years from debt collectors trying to reach a woman who neither resides here nor has ever lived here. Despite being repeatedly promised that my number will be taken off their list, the calls just keep coming.

In my view, your proposal is truly outstanding. However, I am worried that this could drive interest rates up further. Ideally, if consumers were mandated to pay at least 5% of their total balance every month upon initially receiving credit, the overall rate of defaults might likely decrease.

It seems reasonable to assert that individuals who default on debts unintentionally lack the financial resources to hire a lawyer, making it understandable why they might perceive attending court without legal representation as futile. Why doesn't the judicial system extend the provision of free legal counsel to debt defaulters, similar to what is offered to those facing criminal charges?
I believe it's important for both parties to be informed if a recording is taking place. This approach is equitable for all involved.

On paper, this policy appears sensible, yet how can debt collectors ascertain a debtor's location if they are contacting via a mobile phone? Deliberately reaching out to third parties should be universally banned. The dealings between lenders and borrowers are private matters that should not concern others. Calling a person's employer or relatives can lead to further financial and familial complications, neither of which contribute to resolving the debt.
this statement may not always hold true. Certain services operate by allowing the sender to cover the cost of the text message.

California has already achieved significant progress concerning debt purchasers. All collection agencies should adhere to a standard that requires them to present duly verified evidence for the debts they pursue in court.

I have consistently paid my State taxes on time. An error by my employer in 2008, where taxes weren't deducted, has led me to deal with the State's collection authorities. The notion of the State intimidating residents to gather taxes is foreign to me. I reached out and collaborated, yet I am subjected to constant harassment from dawn till dusk by the callers. I take pride in my stellar credit history, which I've diligently upheld over the years. I have always settled any Federal taxes that I had committed to pay. And I have never once incurred a debt on State taxes. It is astonishing to me that they can pursue residents as aggressively as private debt collectors. I am currently retired and rely on a fixed income. The State's ability to threaten residents who are attempting to settle their taxes, even if only for a year, feels like an infringement of rights.

Being impolite isn't necessary in this situation. Certain tactics used in debt collection clearly ought to be banned. Other topics being discussed are clearly issues of personal convenience. If these preferences are commonly held and banning them outright doesn't significantly raise lending costs, then it is reasonable to prohibit them completely. However, if someone desires to block all types of robocalls from all devices, and these calls assist creditors in recovering their loans, then the creditor should have the option to impose a regulated fee for this service. It's not the debt collection agency itself that would levy the fee Simply that a method based on consent is an alternative.

I am interacting with a company that handles both debt collection and mortgage services. They are facing challenges in distinguishing between these two service areas. Additionally, they are experiencing significant IT (web) difficulties. Issues include a non-functioning website, restricted access for staff, and the inability to upload my account details. Their system erroneously reports sending me documents, which it fails to deliver. I have documented these issues extensively via screenshots and digital communication. I forwarded screenshots showing errors on my account page to their IT department, and this might have contributed to resolving their website problems a few weeks later. I strongly advocate for electronic media as an official communication tool for both parties.

It is essential for consumers to be informed about the sale or transfer of their debts. This notification should include details about the parties involved, such as the original and new debt holder, along with effective dates and contact information.

Details about the origin of a debt, like the date a service was rendered, can be shared without compromising a patient's confidentiality. Individuals should not be required to settle a debt before being informed about the reasons behind the financial obligation. This is particularly relevant for medical debts, which are infamously intricate and seemingly repetitive, with multiple charges often stemming from a single event.

In my view, the stipulation for debt collectors to dispatch a validation notice five days following the initial interaction seems counterproductive. I am convinced that the exchange between a debtor and a debt collector would be more effective if the debtor received the validation notice prior to the initial phone conversation. Debt collectors ought to be mandated to send the validation notice five days ahead of any phone communications, rather than after. Otherwise, the debtor is confronted by an unfamiliar caller unexpectedly demanding payment. This leaves the debtor without adequate time to gather their thoughts or to prepare pertinent inquiries regarding the claimed debt. Being caught off guard heightens the debtor's fear and anxiety, which inevitably hampers effective verbal exchanges. The debtor lacks any written factual documentation to consult during the call, whereas the debt collector possesses all pertinent information readily accessible on their computer screen, allowing them to quote data and statistics. This scenario results in a power imbalance that is not favorable for clear communication. Mandating debt collectors to send a validation notice five days prior to the initial phone call would not impose any financial strain on them. Given that sending validation notices to debtors is already a requirement. It's merely an adjustment in the timing of a pre-existing obligation.

I concur. Their remarks are appalling and merely more of the same rhetoric. Why should we anticipate that a lobby group representing debt collectors would genuinely desire enforceable new regulations?

I have been disturbed by debt collectors ringing me at 9:30 pm, which I find to be quite disrespectful. Additionally, I've had automated calls interrupting my sleep early in the morning. Being 69 years old and retired, I tend to go to bed late. Currently, my health isn't in great condition, which occasionally results in sleepless nights. I kindly request that robocalls refrain from waking me.

Initially, I understood that there is a notable legal distinction among 1) identity theft, and 2) mistaken identity, particularly in relation to contract law. Moreover, it's essential that these three terms are distinctly separated, clearly defined, and their legal treatment thoroughly assessed. Virtually no legal recourse exists for cases where the wrong person is identified. Providing additional information would not have been beneficial. The lawyer possessed ample information, yet he failed to verify any of it once he had located my address. The clerk informed me that these attorneys and their representatives were simply 'scouring phone books and the internet,' summoning individuals with identical first and last names to court, assuming one would ultimately be the debtor. This practice is a total misuse of judicial resources, imposes significant costs on innocent citizens, and involves the illegal detention and intimidation of innocent individuals along with their assets. It has been revealed that the debtor has since moved out of the county. The attorney could have effortlessly confirmed his data by consulting online public property records from both the Clerk of Courts and the County Clerk, discovering discrepancies such as the incorrect middle initial and more than seven other mismatched identifiers. The lawyer didn't even perform the most basic verification. I submitted a report to the IARDC, but no action was taken.

Consumers ought to have the right to record all telephone interactions as a means of verifying discussions with debt collectors. Additionally, after a collector is informed not to reach out to a debtor at their place of employment, they should be strictly prohibited from doing so, including for so-called 'location' purposes.

I support the idea that broadening the validation notice's scope would be advantageous for consumers. It's particularly crucial to provide a method for consumers to reach out to the original creditor and recognize the specific account involved. When debts are repeatedly sold, consumers face difficulties in: (1) confirming ownership of the account; (2) verifying rightful assignment; and (3) ascertaining whether the statute of limitations has lapsed. The existing regulations perpetuate "zombie debt" accounts which, despite having been settled by consumers, resurface repeatedly. Without a way for consumers to identify an account, they are unable to confirm that they have previously settled the debt.

Indeed. During the tough times following my divorce, I discovered that my father, whom I haven't lived with for over 20 years, receives a barrage of debt collection calls intended for me every day, to the point where he stopped answering his home phone. This situation is simply intolerable. We are completely baffled as to how they obtained his phone number. I never resided at that address during the time I held those credit cards, nor did he ever co-sign any loans or credit cards with me. The only link we can suspect is that my stepmother co-signed a short-term furniture loan for me two decades ago, just after I finished college, and perhaps her name is somehow linked to my credit report. Despite this, I've never seen any indication of it on my credit reports. This is occurring six years after my divorce was finalized. A few months ago, he mentioned to me that he continues to receive multiple calls each week from debt collectors seeking me. In my opinion, debt collectors should not be permitted to contact any number for more than three months without successfully reaching the debtor. It's clear they lack evidence that they have the correct phone number. All that results from calling the same unverified number for six years is the harassment of an innocent individual.

There is a concern among some individuals that collectors merely verify that the sum stated in the validation notice matches what the creditor asserts the consumer owes. That's essentially their entire process. They fail to take any meaningful action to challenge the assertions made by the creditor. In my experience, even when I presented actual evidence that countered the creditor’s claims, collectors solely depended on the information provided by the creditors. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) doesn't offer any improvement. Interacting with them felt similar to dealing with a collector. The CFPB did not undertake any verification or examination of the creditor's assertions; they simply accepted the creditor's statements as indisputable facts, overlooking contradictory documentation.

I concur with your view that incurring debt shouldn't be considered a criminal act, yet, when someone fails to repay a debt, they are essentially left without rights if they can't hire a lawyer since the government does not provide one for such cases. Representing oneself can quickly turn into chaos because there is no real assistance available for handling the necessary documentation, even state-supported self-representation services are only funded to guide where to get the forms, not to complete them.

The ability to sell it at a fraction of the owed amount stems from the debt buyer acquiring whole portfolios of non-performing debt. This approach mitigates the overall risk. If you could rally a million other overdue consumers to join you in making a 10% offer, it's likely they would agree to it. However, it wouldn't be financially viable for them to extend the same deal to you as they do to the debt buyer.

In the state where I practice, jurisdiction cannot be established solely on the location of the contract signing. Consequently, we restrict our legal submissions to jurisdictions where we have a reasonable belief that the consumer resides. Subsequent to this, states generally determine the appropriate court, considering factors like the amount involved, location, and others. Thus, even in expansive judicial districts, local regulations prevent us from choosing other venues for filing.

After maintaining an impeccable payment record for 15 years, I found myself compelled to default on six accounts simultaneously because I took on the role of unpaid caregiver for my parents. Nevertheless, before any default, I reached out to each account provider to inform them of my situation. It's important to add that I continued to make payments on five of the six accounts until my savings were depleted. I found out that credit card companies do not have a system in place for potential defaulters. I believe that establishing a division for potential defaults should be considered a business expense that credit card companies have opted to ignore because they have enlisted the courts to handle everything for a minimal fee. My objective was straightforward: continue making small automated payments on all six accounts to avoid harassing calls, allowing me to focus on caregiving and adjusting my self-employment to generate monthly income. Every request was denied, and the harassing and, more importantly, incessant phone calls began. I eventually had to switch my landlines to cell phones costing 6 dollars a month, and I seldom used them because I couldn't afford the 20 cents per minute charge. In essence, credit card companies and debt collectors ruined my most effective means of regaining income while still serving as an unpaid caregiver. And as Marlene so aptly noted, another significant obstacle is the debt collectors' complete refusal to document any verbal agreements made!

The current notification for validation is excessively lengthy, almost resembling standard legal jargon. Adding further information risks perplexing or intimidating the least knowledgeable debtor, potentially prompting them to request an immediate halt to communication from the creditor. This approach has a downside; it compels the creditor to initiate legal proceedings, leading to court-related expenses that will subsequently be added to the outstanding debt. Rather, it would be beneficial for debtors to be motivated to express their inquiries and concerns to the collector, who can then, after verifying the correct party, openly discuss the account and possibly resolve the debtor's queries.

In my opinion, the advantages of allowing debt collectors and purchasers access to these documents are likely not justified by the expenses unless these documents are required to accompany the validation notice. It would be ideal if debt collectors were genuinely concerned about confirming the correct debtor. However, I doubt that's the case. The person handling the call is primarily interested in obtaining the payment. Their priority isn't the source or the legality of the debt. Providing him the information without including the debtor likely wouldn't be very beneficial. Perhaps I'm being harsh. It's possible that these companies are diligent in ensuring the debt is collected from the correct individual. No way...

In a personal experience, a debt collector bypassed legal proceedings for a credit card debt and directly seized funds from our joint bank account. We only received a notification from the collector two weeks after the fact, and this incident took place between September and October of 2012. It is essential for debt collectors to give prior notice before they proceed with garnishing a bank account. The process to recover the funds was lengthy, requiring a judge's order for release, and this happened only after the debt collector had taken an entire tax refund.

Individuals ought not to be permitted to challenge a debt by citing identity theft unless they can provide evidence. If this policy isn't enforced, some individuals might exploit the system and lodge fraudulent disputes.

Debt collectors should be mandated to issue 'goodbye letters' and 'hello letters,' similar to mortgage servicers, to notify when loans are sold and acquired. Moreover, they must reveal the purchase price of the debt, indicating the discounted amount they paid. In addition, comprehensive information about the buyer of the debt should be provided, including the identities of the debt collection company's proprietors and its physical location. This transparency allows for the possibility of arranging face-to-face interactions. Any entity pursuing debt collection must adhere to a policy of complete transparency and full disclosure.

Until debt collection practices become more transparent for consumers, there will be continued exploitation and confusion regarding legal responsibilities. Suggesting that consumers should simply obtain legal counsel is an overly simplistic solution. Debt collectors must be mandated to provide a certain level of verification regarding the legitimacy of the debt. Collectors should be prohibited from depending solely on a borrower's perceived 'moral duty' to settle debts. Consumers who are financially disadvantaged, inexperienced, or easily swayed—particularly those on fixed, limited incomes, such as elderly Americans, ESL citizens, and others—are particularly at risk.

I propose revisiting the language currently outlined in the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy BR 3001 (in effect since 12/1/2012) concerning documentation. From my engagement with the Rule and the various comments and hearings, I am convinced that time can be saved without the need to develop a new set of standards. Bankruptcy involves the process of collection and includes consumers, as well as attorneys representing both parties. I advise a further review of the "validation" notice language and the numerous interpretations associated with it.

I worry that the suggested regulations are merely a covert way for Director Cordray to discover details about my unique toy collection. He has previously sent me letters requesting information about my special toy collection, and I fear that with his position as Director of the CFPB, he might be leveraging his authority to target my beloved toy, Mr. Longblack.

I have a strong dislike for option #2 as it might encourage directing consumers to specific websites, which could pave the way for spammers and hackers to easily spread viruses by adopting similar tactics. The idea of contacting every phone number listed and instructing users to visit a particular website could lead to their computers being infected.

The most effective approach is simply asking for a return call. Messages like "Foti" are pointless for everyone involved. It's obvious to all that the call originates from a debt collector, causing unnecessary disturbance to third parties.

Creditors are exempted from certain regulations under the FDCPA. The CFPB ought to ensure that any rules established clarify that actions prohibited for debt collectors by the FDCPA would also be considered unfair, deceptive, or abusive if carried out by a creditor.

I have an outstanding debt being processed by the court. The problem is that I was never notified about any scheduled court date. However, a month after the court session, I did get a letter from my bank indicating they had received a garnishment order. They could have avoided the court expenses, given that I had already informed them of my unemployment status.
