It should be mandated that they clearly identify themselves. so that consumers have at least some opportunity to engage with them. In my situation, I do not owe any debts, yet I am repeatedly targeted for others' debts. This happens because my last name is quite common. Their approach is to call everyone sharing the same surname as the actual debtor.

I am employed at a private university and we refrain from initiating lawsuits for debt collection. Considering that debts can remain on one's credit report for up to 7 years, we prefer to maintain our accounts with collection agencies throughout this period. Furthermore, due to recent changes related to time-barred debts, our collection agencies are unwilling to handle any accounts that exceed 4 years in age, specifically in Texas.

Even if these parties come to a private agreement, it remains true that the debt is still outstanding. The fact that the initial lender incurred a loss does not alter the reality of what is owed. Is it morally acceptable for an individual to accumulate massive debt and then choose not to repay it?

Several years back, a debt collection agency attempted to recover a debt for an emergency room visit that included X-rays of my foot and leg. The issue was that the sole occasion I had ever been to that hospital was for a workplace injury covered by worker's compensation, which only involved my hand (it was cut open, requiring six stitches). I reached out to the collection agency, explaining that I did not owe any money and detailing the circumstances of my hospital visit. Though this approach initially failed, when I shared the same information with all three credit bureaus, the debt collector could not validate the debt and consequently, they erased it from my credit report, ceasing all further communication with me.

The cost of purchasing debt paper fluctuates based on the likelihood of debt recovery, which depends on the information known about the debtor. It also varies according to the volume of documentation obtained from the original lender. The majority of debt purchasers typically acquire only a few recent credit card statements. They might issue a "bill of sale" however, these documents never specify the individual account being transferred and mention a master purchase contract that is never disclosed.

Emails are no more accessible or visible on the debtor's screen than phone calls the content of a phone call is actually more difficult to conceal if it is received in the presence of others SMS or text message. Regulations should address sensitive information by requiring that certain details be included as an attachment or through a link within the email, rather than in the email body. When an attachment is encrypted, or details are kept on a secure webpage, no unauthorized person can gain access. Indeed, this method offers far superior protection compared to other ways of conveying information to the debtor. Emails related to work should be treated differently, similar to workplace calls, which employers can also access.

Although Demand Letters might not always succeed in recovering debts, "providing notice is an essential element of justice." It's crucial that individuals adhere to established standards, which, consequently, contribute to the reduction of harmful practices. Procedural protections, such as demand letters, remain vital norms despite their potential ineffectiveness.

In the absence of a current federal regulation or statute addressing the scenario where a debtor moves from one state's statute of limitations to another, such a law should be established. There ought to be a clear determination of which statute of limitations is applicable when a debtor relocates between states.

The FTC must ensure that any rule concerning verification explicitly incorporates an exception for disputes that are frivolous or irrelevant. as the abundance of websites offering template dispute letters and encouraging their repeated use has led to misuse by numerous debtors, resulting in the establishment of a standard letter to tackle this matter.

Debt collectors initiate a high volume of default judgments primarily because consumers choose not to engage, rather than being oblivious to the situation. Typically, when a lawsuit is commenced, debt collectors have already tried to settle the matter through phone calls and/or letters. This doesn't even factor in the attempts made by the original creditor. Lawsuits are never the initial course of action. They are generally pursued only after numerous unsuccessful attempts to negotiate with a consumer to clear an outstanding debt. A default judgment is merely a continuation of this process. Even after we file a lawsuit, efforts might be made to contact the consumer and resolve the matter before a judgment is issued. I have encountered numerous instances where we informed the consumer about their option to respond, yet they still did not. In my view, default judgments are largely due to consumers' conscious decision not to participate in the process, rather than any deceptive tactics by collectors. I would note that many states have rules stating that if a consumer doesn't respond to a summons and defaults, they don't have to be informed about a motion for a default judgment. Thus, the entry of the judgment might indeed be unexpected, even though the summons warns that a judgment may be entered if no response is made. Nevertheless, an attorney adhering to local regulations is not acting in a deceptive manner. To mitigate this unexpected outcome for consumers who don't respond, it might be beneficial to require that all motions for judgment be served on the consumer, regardless of local rules suggesting otherwise. It's worth mentioning that many motions for default judgment aren't scheduled for a hearing. They can simply be submitted for a decision without a court appearance. Regarding what is needed to support a default judgment, requirements differ from court to court and judge to judge. In my experience, courts that demand more documentation typically look for affidavits of debt, charge-off statements, records of payments or charges, and assignment documents (if the plaintiff is a debt buyer).

All items numbered 1 through 10 should be included in the validation notice. Particularly, item number 10 must detail the Date-of-Service, or DOS, for any medical debts. A lot of consumers are unaware that medical debts are sent to collections in the same manner as other types of consumer debt. They incorrectly assume that their insurance company will handle the situation. Furthermore, when facing substantial medical expenses like those from inpatient surgeries, consumers receive professional bills from each doctor (such as radiology, pathology, etc.), as well as technical component bills from the facility. Often, the consumer never actually meets these healthcare providers and might either confuse the bill with another facet of the service received or, once more, assume the debt will be 'resolved' for them. Including the name of the consumer's insurance company or plan on the validation notice would also be beneficial. This might appear to be an excessive amount of additional information. However, the originating doctor or facility collects this information either at the time of service or beforehand.
There are regulations requiring mortgage lenders to notify borrowers when their loan servicing is transferred to another lender. Implement these notification standards for all types of debt.

Honestly, I feel like yelling. You've never had the experience of dealing with a debt collection agency that views individuals merely as dollar signs, regardless of whether they owe money. And this has been happening for a long time. It's unfortunate that this is the first thing you choose to say to me.

I've noticed that certain banks restrict their branches from accepting debit or credit card payments. Every agency should be required to accept payments via debit and credit cards. It feels as though they are living in the past, like it's 1950.

The concept of debt neutrality is beneficial. Unfortunately, being indebted is not treated as a criminal offense. Nevertheless, with the current legal framework and the exploitative tactics of debt collection agencies, it seems as though you're treated like a criminal. I concur. Implement a system where consumers have equal power compared to debt collectors.

A significant issue with privacy is the widespread use of the Social Security Number for various purposes, allowing everything to be interconnected. This has been a misguided approach since it was first implemented as a taxpayer identification number. While it might reduce some instances of fraud, the benefits do not justify the drawbacks. Essentially, we have rendered it unlawful to remain untraceable, which poses a significant risk for individuals like domestic abuse victims.

Nancy H's comment highlights a key issue: the lack of uniform standards everywhere. Wishing you the best. Your experience in this scenario is influenced by the collection agency, the initial creditor, and your location. Geographical location should not play a role.

Indeed, you are right. There is a significant distinction between sending and receiving. My point is merely that a creditor should only be obligated to send a notice to the most recent address they have, rather than ensuring the consumer actually receives it. and assuming all undelivered mail is always returned is overestimating the situation), in that case, the creditor should dispatch the notice to this updated address. If the aim of this conversation is to safeguard the consumer, then the consumer should be compelled to look out for their own interests by providing updated information to the creditor. If they fail to do so, a creditor should not be held liable in a lawsuit for a letter not reaching the consumer, when the creditor acted on the best available information.

Consumers ought to receive a distinct document outlining their rights, which should also be readily accessible. It's concerning how little we know about our rights as consumers, our negotiation options, or who can support us in these matters. Additionally, legislation should be established to specify times when debt collectors are prohibited from collecting. If the original creditor has not pursued the debt for a significant duration, receiving a collection notice two decades later should be prevented.

I previously posted a lengthy comment concerning a specific debt collector, yet I recently faced harassment from another collector who was pursuing a debt from a person that wasn’t me. The caller ID didn’t display a phone number; instead, it showed the names of various states, but ultimately it was the same company. These individuals have no moral compass and feed off the bottom. It should be mandatory for caller IDs to be accurate so that the person receiving the call can at least recognize the collector and obtain a number to call them back. Financial penalties should be substantially increased to deter their outrageous, predatory, and harassing behaviors. Harassment is ingrained in their business strategies. These individuals are despicable and should be obligated to disclose their identity truthfully. Automated calls and caller ID falsification should be prohibited with severe fines imposed.

Since it belongs to the consumer and they are entitled to that right! Why should consumers be charged for being annoyed?! Shift the burden of these business expenses onto the companies, not the consumers! I cover the cost of my mobile phone, I pay for the airtime, I am the one who decides how my phone is used and who gets to call me, not these unscrupulous, intrusive companies!

My daughter has both private and federal student loans serviced by Sallie Mae. Every day, they bombard her cell phone and mine with calls, at least 10 times each day. They reached out to me, and, notably, they don't have her consent to discuss her matters with me, yet they advised me to halt payments on her federal loans since they can be deferred, urging me to focus on the private loans instead. My daughter has a staggering $176,000 in private loan debt and cannot meet the payment demands they are imposing. They even contacted her workplace seeking details about her. She formally requested that all correspondence be limited to email and US mail. When they reached out to me, I inquired if they had received this request and they confirmed receipt but insisted on needing to communicate with someone. However, my number isn't listed as a contact for them. I informed them of this, yet they persistently call my cell phone daily. Currently, my daughter struggles to cover her existing expenses. I assist her in managing her private loan payments. I am not a co-signer or borrower on any of her loans. This relentless harassment must come to an end!

You've highlighted a dilemma involving two separate concepts: 'dispatched' and 'received.' I doubt that any customer would want to 'receive' a notification that was never 'dispatched.' Furthermore, it is common for letters and packages to go missing during transit. In scenarios where there's an obligation for a creditor or collector to 'dispatch' the notifications you're mentioning, the initial destination would be the address recorded in their system. If these mail items are subsequently returned, it would indicate that the intended recipient no longer resides at the recorded address. Nonetheless, it is essential for the letters to be 'dispatched' initially.

I require a visible number. Avoid concealing the number and refrain from using 800 numbers. In my view, 800 numbers are typically associated with sales or telemarketers. I desire confirmation if I have a debt in collections. Therefore, be transparent.

Collectors who resort to robocalls without initially having a real person confirm the accuracy of the phone number demonstrate laziness and a lack of responsibility. Robocalls to third parties are not only incredibly bothersome but also constitute an improper disclosure. This is because prerecorded calls must state the company's name at the beginning of the message, as stipulated by the TCPA. Personally, I've been subjected to countless calls of this nature, and as a result, I'm aware of which neighbors supposedly have financial obligations. I use the term "supposedly" because often, the companies behind these calls are the same repeat offenders who have faced lawsuits for attempting to collect debts that don't exist. Banning robocalls, especially those directed at third parties, would penalize the wrongdoers without significantly affecting honest collectors. I wouldn't mind live callers utilizing autodialers, but some agencies employ outdated technology. Telemarketers manage to remain within the mandated 3% call abandonment rate, yet my experience reveals that the drop rate for live calls from collectors is between 50% and 100%. I even encountered a situation where one company would immediately hang up every time their representative contacted me. It's unclear to me how such practices could be profitable. Applying the FTC's 3% abandonment rule to debt collection calls could resolve this problem.

I absolutely refuse to answer calls labeled as "unknown caller" or simply "unknown". If your company's name doesn't appear on the caller ID, it suggests something is amiss or you're concealing information. It's important to remember that you are the one reaching out to me, which makes phone calls an intrusion into my personal space. I am under no obligation to pick up calls that I prefer to ignore. A rule should be established requiring debt collection firms to disclose their identity when calling.
This is simply the cost of participating in the industry. If debt collectors are unable to handle the realities of the field, they should consider pursuing a different line of work for their careers.

It is essential to take firm action against the service sector. They have significantly disrupted the debt collection process by having their personnel engage in fraudulent serving and subserving of alleged debt defaulters. This has occurred to me on two occasions. Initially, the process server made a wild guess, assigning generic characteristics such as age, size, and weight, along with a fabricated name. On the second instance, the server labeled the sub server as 'Jane Doe,' again using vague attributes that spanned various age, height, and racial descriptions, which were completely inaccurate. In court, I overheard another defendant tell the judge they were never properly served as the documents were left outside their door. Moreover, the service company falsely represented in court documents that someone was served when they were not. which should ideally equip the judge with the discretion to take measures to safeguard the accused, when debt collectors realize they can rely on false services, their incentive to negotiate with the defendant significantly diminishes. Judges seem to overlook the implications of false service. I am confident in my understanding and I can assert without hesitation anywhere that I have been subjected to false service/subservice twice.

Collection agencies are not obligated to thoroughly verify the debt or provide detailed information to the consumer. For instance, I once challenged the legitimacy of a debt. The so-called validation I received was merely a single sentence stating: "The consumer owes the debt." To me, and likely to any rational individual, this cannot be considered proper validation. It should be mandatory for the collection agency to provide sufficient details to enable the consumer to identify or contest the debt. Ideally, this information would include a copy of the original application and the final billing statement.

Occasionally, the regulations of state and local courts can significantly increase the chances of default judgments. Consider a situation where an individual accused of owing money is summoned to court during their working hours, forcing them to choose between facing a default judgment or risking their employment. I recommend that the CFPB recognize that scheduling hearings at inconvenient times is unfair, deceptive, and abusive, or that it contravenes 1692i.

State laws ought to prevent them from amassing excessive profits from such a small investment (usury!!!). Additional factors to contemplate regarding this matter include: The bad debt buyer remains silent about the price paid for the bad debt. This information should be openly shared and made public since they possess the original debt details, such as SSN, contact numbers, and financial data. I am not against them earning a profit, however, their exploitative methods must be regulated. A higher court judge should have the authority to review the initial transaction, as well as all documents related to the debt's acquisition by a third party, and decide on a just and reasonable payment to resolve the issue, thus preventing bankruptcy.

I want to clarify that I'm not suggesting escaping debt due to a major life event. I propose that the debt should be locked in at its balance during the involuntary default, and it should be repaid over a span of up to ten years, if necessary.

I wholeheartedly agree with drose977's remarks. Presently, debt collection firms have the ability to sell debts without adequately verifying them. They can also transfer the debt if a consumer disputes it and the agency fails to produce valid confirmation. Such practices should be prohibited as they significantly harm consumers. Consumers' interests should take precedence over those of collectors and other agencies. because they generally possess far fewer resources to contest incorrect information. Furthermore, incorrect data has a more pronounced negative impact on consumers than on any other parties involved in these cases. Collectors should be prohibited from marking a debt as 30 days overdue if it is not actually 30 days overdue. Laws should impose substantial and enforceable penalties to discourage collectors from backdating debts. These regulations should be applicable to debts reported as overdue at any point, not only within the initial 30 days.

I share the same opinion as josephusmyer. About eight years back, our son accumulated minor debts at various retail outlets and financial institutions. Recently, debt-buyers have reached out to him, issuing threats of legal proceedings concerning these outdated debts, without informing him about their actual status.

Receiving work-related calls doesn't bother me. What concerns me is how often they occur. The truth is, I'm aware that I owe the payment. However, I believe they shouldn't contact my workplace unless I fail to respond. They should text or call me first and allow a few days for a response. If necessary, then contact my workplace, but not on a daily basis.

It's essential for consumers to actively engage in all their endeavors. Those who have the capacity to incur debt should also possess the ability to settle it. In my experience, every credit union I've encountered goes above and beyond to assist their members in reaching financial prosperity.

All types of written correspondence ought to be recognized as official written notifications. Additionally, Debt collectors should be obligated to adhere to any directives received through email communication.

In a legal dispute, it is customary for each party to showcase the evidence that substantiates their claims. From my experience as a debt collector, I submit evidence confirming the debt. Similarly, the individual accused of owing the debt must furnish proof to demonstrate that the debt does not belong to them. Indeed, the principle of being innocent until proven guilty stands, yet it is necessary to provide evidence to substantiate one's innocence. Supplying a signed agreement that indicates your commitment to the purchase, along with records showing non-payment, fulfills my responsibility to present proof. The responsibility to present proof is also shared by the debtor under our judicial system. This is precisely the judge's role: to listen to both parties, assess the evidence, and reach an impartial judgment based on the presented facts and arguments.

Publishing a piece on landlords involved in unlawful lawsuits and debt collections would attract a significant amount of attention. This issue, while not widely visible, is quite widespread in New York City.

I'm sorry to hear about what you're going through. Hearing about such abusive conduct is distressing as a customer. They have no obligation to "talk" to anyone. You and your daughter have every legal right to request that the calls cease and to opt for communication through other channels. Collectors who disregard this request are acting unlawfully. Furthermore, they should refrain from reaching out to you and certainly not contact you or your daughter multiple times a day. This behavior is undoubtedly excessive and abusive. I should also point out that, despite their claims that federal loans can often be deferred, debt collectors do not act as fiduciaries and they neither operate with nor have the capability to provide financial guidance that benefits the consumer or debtor. Collectors will say and do anything to ensure they receive payment. They should not be permitted to advise on which bills to pay and in what manner. Such so-called "advice" can be harmful to consumers and debtors. It might be beneficial for the CFPB to allow collectors to suggest referrals for financial advice, but they should prohibit collectors from directly providing financial advice.

Consider the idea of permitting arbitrators to rely not solely on legal frameworks but also on practical reasoning when handling credit card defaults. It's reasonable to assume that if a flood devastates a Colorado community, the residents might face difficulties in settling their credit card dues for several months. Practical reasoning suggests that circumstances such as medical crises, being a victim of a hit-and-run, losing one's home, or taking on unpaid caregiving responsibilities for a family member should be prioritized over the obligation of making monthly payments. The focus here isn't on forgiving the debt, but on classifying the debt as neutral, meaning no additional penalties, fees, or interest charges are added, and the debtor commits to settling the debt in a feasible manner, even if it takes up to a decade. __URL__

Debt collectors frequently exploit loopholes in phone communication laws, and there is a lack of enforcement against those who violate these regulations. Legislation should restrict collectors to communicating only through mail. These individuals are opportunists who flout legal boundaries. Ban them entirely from making phone calls. They have consistently demonstrated over the years that they disregard the law. Prohibit all phone communications.

ensuring security would be of utmost importance. Given that the current flaws in authentication processes for financial institutions and other entities governed by FACTA and the FCRA aren't addressed by this legislation, it should be relatively straightforward to apply equivalent security standards to any centralized database for debt collection.

A debt from 19 years ago resurfaced unexpectedly, causing me distress. I consulted three different lawyers, hoping to hire them to negotiate with the company, as the representatives I contacted failed to return my calls despite my leaving numerous messages and offering to settle the debt for slightly more than half of the disputed amount. Over the span of 19 years, the original debt of approximately $1,200 had ballooned to $9,300. There needs to be regulation against such practices. This situation is nothing short of a blatant scam.

Hey, it's 2013! It's frustrating when calls go unanswered and seeing a list of missed calls is irritating. Why are debt collectors operating like it's the past? Send me a text! Shoot me an email! These calls are just not going to be picked up because I have a job and children. Communicating would be far simpler if texting and emailing were options. Honestly, it's not like we're living in 1950!

I recently found out that my mortgage lender doesn't possess the note for my mortgage. and they are unable to track down the note. I am up-to-date with payments and have no intention of lowering them. I have reached out to the mortgage company to ask what actions we should take. For the past eight months, they have been sending us notifications indicating they are investigating the matter.

The CFPB ought to forbid any phone calls to workplaces. When individuals incur debt, they provide a home phone number, which should be the sole contact point for collection. Additionally, Using registered or certified mail should be the alternative means of communication, not calls to the workplace. Furthermore, Massachusetts' initiative to cap the total number of calls is an excellent proposal. In modern times, we do not imprison those with debt, yet the sheer level of mistreatment and disdain they face is completely intolerable.] It is crucial for the CFPB to overhaul the debt collection sector.

From a lender's perspective, I mostly concur with this remark. In my opinion, a well-crafted validation notice could address many of the consumer's inquiries. I believe the writer of the previous comment offered some very insightful thoughts. I wouldn't necessarily go as far as to insist on providing an itemized statement, especially if one may not be accessible due to record-keeping policies or it simply doesn't exist. However, supplying details such as the account type, the original creditor's brand name, the account number, the date of the last payment, and the name of the entity from which the debt may have been acquired would be beneficial. Offering documentation from the outset seems rather unnecessary and expensive, especially if the letter's language enables the consumer to easily recognize the account, and the disclosures permit the consumer to request validation documentation.

I have no issue with having a spouse. After all, she is my wife. Therefore, I don't see any problem with it. However, I don't support the idea of having a girlfriend or boyfriend for those who are not married. Having a spouse is acceptable.

It seems unfair to me that a third party can purchase overdue debts and then pursue the full amount along with legal fees, court expenses, and additional costs tied to intermediaries or arbitrators. I propose that there should be a cap on how much a third-party debt acquirer can seek in lawsuits beyond what they initially spent. Often, the original lender is a company listed on the stock exchange and shareholders have already absorbed the financial loss. Later, a debt purchaser acquires a collection of non-performing debts, paying just ten cents on the dollar. They then hand it over to a legal firm to recover 100% or more of the initial alleged debt. These debt buyers should be restricted from suing for amounts that are 900% of their original expenditure. Their recovery efforts should be confined to a proportionate representation of actual damages. To my knowledge, no other civil procedure would deem this practice ethical.

I strongly believe that there should be stringent oversight on so-called 'skip-trace' companies. These businesses are the ones that debt collectors and others engage with to obtain contact details. Based on my personal encounters (having a common surname and being pursued by numerous debt collectors), I feel completely at the whim of these companies. They compile various types of data about individuals without, as far as I can discern, verifying any of it. A debt collector informed my state's Attorney General that they engaged one of these companies, which provided my phone number as a legitimate contact for someone sharing my surname and first initial. This individual was unknown to me, yet the debt collector insisted that I settle the debt. I believe these companies need to be tightly regulated and should employ tools other than just the phone directory for gathering information. They shouldn't be allowed to supply 'valid' data unless it is genuinely accurate.

I am in favor of implementing these limitations on robo-calls and any calls made during work hours. Regarding robo-calls, any misleading ones should be prohibited. For instance, a robo-call claiming you have a message or an update on your account, urging you to dial a specific number with an extension, only to repeat the message asking about your payment, is a misuse of the consumer's time and cellular resources (involving two calls, one inbound and one outbound).

Illinois has implemented legislation against Caller ID spoofing. I continue to receive calls every day that display either misleading or indecipherable caller IDs, with no voicemail being left. __URL__
Indeed, I experienced that earlier today, a person contacted me pretending to be a 'courier service,' attempting to find a friend.

Considering the significant negative effects of having unfavorable information recorded by credit reporting agencies on consumer credit profiles, it seems only fair that a debt should not be marked as "verified" or "substantiated" until a final non-appealable ruling is made, especially when the consumer has promptly challenged the debt's authenticity or amount. At present, when you challenge a debt, the debt collector flags you to the credit reporting agencies and this negatively affects your credit score; in essence, the harm has already been inflicted. To put it another way, the indication that the consumer disputes the debt on their credit report is mostly disregarded by potential lenders, employers, landlords, and others. Therefore, disputing the debt does not effectively shield the consumer from damage. Debt collectors and creditors use the threat of reporting you to credit agencies as a pressure tactic to compel repayment even when you may genuinely not owe the debt or the amount claimed. Regarding my suggestion, I believe it will not result in increased litigation. Quite the contrary. If a consumer does not challenge the debt in a timely manner, then it can be classified as verified or substantiated. However, if the debt is contested promptly, creditors and debt collectors will need to decide whether to pursue legal action and assess their chances of winning in court, potentially leading them to be more selective about which debts to litigate. This proposal would also protect consumers from having their credit scores affected until it is definitively established that a contested debt is genuinely owed and the exact amount is confirmed. Alternatively, a regulation could be enacted imposing heavy statutory penalties, triple damages, and recovery of legal fees against creditors, debt collectors, and credit reporting agencies if the consumer proves the disputed debt is non-existent or the debt's amount is less than claimed. However, this method places the responsibility of proof on the consumer and I firmly believe that the responsibility of proof should lie with creditors and debt collectors to definitively establish the existence and amount of any contested debt before negatively impacting a consumer's credit report.

I believe the system should implement a series of 'handshakes': at the start of a dispute, upon its resolution, or when it is withdrawn. In each scenario, it is crucial for the consumer to be absolutely certain that the collector recognizes their position and that the Credit Reporting Agency (CRA) has been duly informed. The CRA should be involved in the handshake process. It is intolerable that consumer complaints may linger for extended periods, leaving the consumer unsure if the CRA has obtained the updated details from the collector or if there is an unnecessary delay in processing the update.

Social Media: Although courts seldom use social media as a method for delivering notices, it is important to note that not everyone uses every social media platform. Despite being quite skilled with the internet, I do not have accounts on Foursquare, Pinterest, and several more. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and others have thousands of individuals sharing my name, potentially leading to misdirected notifications.

Although this website doesn't specifically mention it, the existing penalties for breaching the FDCPA are largely ineffective. A fine of 100 dollars is insignificant for the majority of businesses. The legislation should be revised to implement a 7-year statute of limitations (currently, it's one year) and set a maximum penalty, payable to the claimant, of either $10,000 or $100,000 for each infraction.

Collectors should communicate through mail unless the consumer opts for phone communication. This method provides consumers with ample time to carefully evaluate the requests from collectors. Additionally, it helps prevent misunderstandings for both the consumer and the collector. The main reason this isn't widely adopted is because it restricts collectors from being intrusive and causing embarrassment—it's as straightforward as that.
If you don't pick up the call, they will likely try contacting you once more. Instead of disregarding the call, you have the option to answer and request the company to refrain from calling you.

For the initial inquiry, conducting thorough research is essential. Although collectors might still pursue legal actions, which seems unlikely to cease, a penalty should be imposed on them if they file a false claim. In situations where litigation is initiated against an incorrect individual, the entity responsible should compensate the victim with a reasonable amount and also pay a significant fee to the overseeing authority to assist in covering supervision costs. Regarding the second question, I assume that a vast majority of consumer debts can be settled. Nevertheless, there will always be exceptions to this rule. In instances where debt recovery is impossible for any reason, it should be considered genuinely uncollectible and prohibited from being resold as collectible debt. A precise definition and refinement of what constitutes "Uncollectible" must be established by the relevant regulatory agency. For the third question, assessments should be made for both parties. Currently, credit reporting agencies are in place to track the consumer aspect of this issue, and a numerical evaluation score could be added to the consumer's existing credit report. This could serve as an initial step that can be developed further as the system is refined. Conversely, collectors would necessitate a novel assessment mechanism to evaluate both the company overall and the individuals involved in debt resolution efforts. For successful models of such systems, I would refer you to the Department of Transportation's Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and their Compliance-Safety-Accountability framework. Admittedly, their system is far more intricate and comprehensive than what the debt industry would demand. Yet, their scoring system is adaptable and can accommodate future modifications. It would also enable evaluation of the original creditor. Such evaluations would offer the government and investors better insights into the risk level of a particular business. Incorporating Mr. Bartmann's suggestions would create a framework where collectors and financial institutions self-regulate to attain ethical and accountable outcomes, avoiding the defense of legality. This would benefit both parties and help numerous consumers escape the vicious cycle of debt. Ultimately, the federal government could introduce this system with minimal disruption to state sovereignty. It would lessen the volume of litigation in state and local courts, encouraging states to participate.

My last name is quite common, and in the phone directory, my entry is listed with just two initials instead of my full first name. Several times each week, I receive calls from debt collectors searching for different individuals who share my surname along with one or the other of my initials. They are essentially making random guesses. When I inform them that I do not reside with any relatives and that my credit score is outstanding, they remove my number from their list for the current day's target. If I request them not to call me anymore, explaining that there's no one else living with me whom they might be seeking, they mention that I was only on the list for today's individual. The next day, my number might be flagged again for a new target, but they say there's nothing they can do about future calls. A credit collection agent based in India actually told me this.

I can't figure out why debt collectors are so stuck in the past. I receive so many calls and it's quite bothersome. I would much prefer receiving a text message or an email. A ringing phone can be irritating, whereas a text is less intrusive. Additionally, it spares me from listening to a lengthy voicemail. I would rather get a text that tells me who they are and their purpose. Only if I don't respond promptly, should they then call me.

such an approach would lack efficiency. Under the FCRA, debts that are no longer managed by a creditor or collector cannot be reported. To illustrate, if your creditor sells the debt to a collection agency, the creditor loses the right to report it. However, the new owner can report the debt if they comply with relevant federal regulations.

The option to verify the debt should be eliminated. It is imperative that attempts are consistently mandated. Moreover, if verification does not occur, the debt should not be allowed to be transferred further.

Demanding so much detail is excessive. It isn't the responsibility of creditors or collectors to provide updates on "best practices" or staff details. This discussion focuses on the notification that a debt has been handed over for collection. It has not been sold, just delegated to a specialist in recovering overdue payments. Notification is issued when the validation notice is dispatched. The entity sending the notice is the collector; the letter itself will identify the creditor to whom the debt is owed. That's sufficient.

Two years ago, my daughter passed away, leaving behind some unpaid debts. Despite our requests to stop, we still receive persistent calls from debt collectors. In response to the ongoing harassment, my wife has lodged formal complaints with the Oregon State Justice Department. Isn't it reasonable to expect these collectors to thoroughly investigate the debtor's situation before bothering the family?
I firmly believe that ensuring the availability of documentation is essential. Why should I settle a debt without definitive evidence confirming it's mine?

In my view, the CFPB's jurisdiction should not extend into this domain. because current federal legislation does not impose such a restriction. Informing consumers that a debt has surpassed the statute of limitations is concerning as this date can be altered. Making even a partial payment can reset the statute of limitations on a debt. I am skeptical that a CFPB regulation could provide a solution in this instance. Educating consumers is the sole proactive approach I perceive as viable here. Nonetheless, this educational effort should also alert the legal community that any breaches in this field will be reported by the CFPB to their state's Attorney General.

Marian brings up a valid argument regarding the compensation of Debt Collectors. Their strategy is to secure as much payment as possible immediately. Interestingly, if they collect too much money at once, there's a risk the credit card company will reclaim the account from them. When debt collectors receive an amount deemed "too low," they lose interest. This contradicts many sales tactics, which suggest that it's simpler to engage with a paying customer again later, rather than attempting to secure a large payment in one go.

Enforcement is the core issue. Collectors are informed that they must cease contacting the consumer's workplace, yet they persistently disregard the legal obligation to halt such communications. It is pointless to report these breaches to the authorities, as no action is taken to enforce the regulations, a fact well-known to the collectors. Strengthen enforcement measures.

It can be managed in the same way as any document you send by fax or traditional mail, uploading is simply a more convenient method to deliver it. Regarding the appropriate time, I would suggest 48 hours.

I encountered a situation where my lawyer, working for me, asked for confirmation of the loan debt but the collector did not reply. As a result, I am unable to proceed with the settlement until they provide a response.

I experienced a similar issue with a different mobile service provider. It appears to be a tactic designed to make the debt appear constantly new. This involved another fee for ending the contract early, and I had to send numerous letters before it was eventually removed from my credit history. In my view, the practice of reselling the same debt to prolong its presence on credit records needs to be abolished. It remains a single debt, and there is a prescribed duration for how long it can remain on a credit history. A simple way to monitor this is to mandate notifications when a debt changes hands. Such notification is obligatory when a home loan is transferred. It seems to be an obvious requirement. Legislation should be enacted to not only discourage but outright prevent collection agencies from circulating debt with the intention of maintaining its presence on credit reports.

Indeed, if the account remains active, the bank is required to maintain the agreement for a period of 20 years. In cases where the account became delinquent two decades prior to litigation, the statute of limitations has expired, rendering the lawsuit baseless; it ought to be thrown out with penalties.
There should be no overarching federal regulations. States should be permitted to keep enforcing their own legislation.

In our office, we cast a wide net when it comes to "disputes." Defining this is particularly challenging since disputes can manifest in very unique and specific ways. Typically, the disputes we encounter involve situations where a debt buyer has acquired a debt, and the consumer doesn't recognize the debt buyer's name, leading them to generally claim they don't owe the debt, without further explanation, or they dispute the amount being pursued. Furthermore, allegations of fraud or prior payments might also surface. Our office prudently accepts disputes made verbally in addition to those in writing. In my view, the bigger concern isn't what qualifies as a dispute, but rather, how a collector is supposed to substantiate the debt. Many consumers request highly specific documentation. There is a poorly constructed form letter circulating online, which many consumers discover and use, where they ask for verification rather than validation—despite any difference between the terms—and insist on receiving certain details. I mention this because I believe many consumers assume that every item they request must be supplied, even though the FDCPA doesn't specify what constitutes proper verification. I'll save that discussion for a different post, but I suspect defining what verification means will be quite challenging as it can't be so precise that different types of creditors can't provide the necessary information, nor so vague that extensive litigation is required for clarity.

I don't believe that simply having a registration system for debt collectors effectively tackles the problem. I'm uncertain about the operational mechanics of the registration system. In Massachusetts, consumers have the ability to verify online if a debt collector holds a license to operate within the state, yet many are unaware of this online resource or, more fundamentally, don't realize the debt collector may lack the authority to pursue their debts. Is the intention behind the registration system to override state laws that mandate licensing for debt collectors in each state? I truly hope that isn't the intention because states hold a significant interest in overseeing debt collectors to safeguard their residents.

It is important to inform individuals that their debt has been transferred. as this insight is crucial for the consumer to understand the best approach for negotiating the debt repayment. Once a debt is sold, it is often sold for a fraction of the original amount owed, allowing the lender to record it as a loss, while the borrower faces a negative impact on their credit report for seven years. In many cases, the entity collecting the debt is a subsidiary of the original lender, thereby enabling the lender to receive tax benefits while the borrower's credit is affected, and they persist in attempting to recover the full amount. When a debt is sold, it should be genuinely transferred to an independent third-party, not a division of the original lender. Moreover, consumers must be thoroughly informed about the identity of the entity purchasing their debt.

Although this might not be the ideal place to delve into every detail of my company's collection strategy, we engage with unpaid debts for a minimum of 120 days. Our efforts include sending letters, making calls through live agents and automated systems, sending emails, dispatching invoices by mail, and suspending subscription services (where permissible) as part of our approach. Nevertheless, pursuing legal action is only considered when the debtor fails to respond to our outreach efforts. In my experience, when debtors communicate with their creditors, creditors often take their circumstances into account. I have provided extended repayment plans, decreased or waived interest or late fees, and even considered partial settlements for those who explain their difficulties. However, if a debtor remains uncooperative or ignores our efforts to negotiate a resolution, what other options are available for creditors?

we are inundated with robocalls daily, from the crack of dawn until late at night, coming from unknown numbers; no messages are left when the answering machine activates; such calls should be prohibited unless a message is left that includes the caller's identity and the purpose of the call, specifying the names of both creditor and debtor

It is important to highlight that numerous consumers have reported complaints regarding the aggressive or harassing behavior of debt collectors. Being a third-party debt collector, I handle multiple harassment complaints on a daily basis. I want to emphasize that in 80% of cases, the consumers my colleagues and I deal with are voicing concerns about being harassed and mistreated; and all of them are simply reluctant to accept the reality. This is the subject of their complaints. Whenever we inform them about their debts, they interpret it as harassment and mistreatment. They just refuse to acknowledge their issues. While it is true that a minority of debt collectors can be harassing and abusive, the majority, about 98%, are merely stating the facts. If consumers recognized that the issue lies with them, debt collectors would enjoy a more favorable reputation. But until that realization occurs, in the eyes of consumers, we remain the adversaries.

Moreover, the landlord's real estate lawyer also owned a debt collection agency which allowed him to routinely transfer the landlord's debts to his collection firm enabling the landlords to repeatedly write off these debts with each lawsuit, in this particular case, there were eight lawsuits for the identical sum.

When consumers are informed that their debt has been transferred, there must be a method to reach out to the original lender for verification. Furthermore, maintaining a documented record is essential. I perceive a risk where fraudulent individuals might deceive consumers into believing they owe money, urging them to settle their debts with the scammer immediately. A reliable paper or electronic record ensures that consumers can confirm and track the journey of their debt from one creditor to another, providing assurance, ensuring that the rightful recipient receives the payment.

There should be regulations preventing debt collectors from manipulating their caller ID details. They often disguise themselves as 'Process Servers' while seeking details about someone else's debt. This tactic obstructs consumers from filing complaints against the debt collectors for breach of consumer protection statutes due to the use of a fabricated identity..

There are persistent calls asking for someone named Sean, who neither resides here nor is known to me. I inform them about their mistake, yet the calls persist. Occasionally, they leave prerecorded messages on my voicemail. It's known that some individuals in debt might claim the phone number is incorrect, but these debt collectors should ensure accuracy in their records. This would prevent them from repeatedly dialing incorrect numbers. Whether the debtor deliberately provided the wrong number or it belonged to someone else before me is uncertain. The situation is incredibly frustrating. Although the callers don't explicitly identify as debt collectors, it's very apparent.

My surname is quite widespread, and for nearly three years, I received numerous collection calls meant for other people sharing my surname and the same initial. Eventually, I altered my phone listing from initials to my nickname, leading to a significant decrease in collection calls. I am a senior citizen enjoying retirement. I don't have a car loan or a mortgage. I consistently pay my bills promptly, and I avoid carrying any credit card debt. Not once has a debt collector confessed that they obtained my phone number from the directory, yet that seems to be exactly what they're doing. I wish every debt collector would inform the person they're calling of the origin of their contact details. Currently, I possess a lengthy list of individuals with outstanding debts. Considering I'm not engaged in debt collection, I don't feel legally bound to keep their identities confidential. However, I do feel a moral duty to refrain from doing so. We need to devise a method to prevent debt collectors from disturbing innocent individuals.

I was just viewing "CBS This Morning" and they reported that FICO plans to collaborate with more financial institutions, enabling customers to access their FICO scores at no cost. Currently, many financial institutions already provide FICO scores for free, but now FICO is actively broadening this offer through their 'Open Access' initiative. __URL__ I've been aware of this since FICO released a press announcement earlier this month. What I learned today from "CBS This Morning" is that Discover will allow their cardholders to view their FICO score for free on their monthly billing statements. I believe it's inappropriate for Discover or any company to include a consumer's FICO score on billing statements or any documents that might be given to debt collectors. Currently, debt collectors do not have access to consumers' FICO scores. However, they do have access to what is referred to as a 'collection score.' which bears no relation to FICO or the consumer's creditworthiness. This move by Discover raises significant privacy issues and the CFPB should prohibit creditors or others from accessing a consumer's FICO score.

A large number of businesses enforce a strict rule against personal phone calls; therefore, it should be mandated that "...unless the debtor provides explicit written permission, a collector is prohibited from trying to reach a debtor at their workplace."

It's absolutely unbelievable. When I was playing my voice messages at home, my mom overheard one. Communications should be limited to text messages. Text messages ensure privacy as they cannot be overheard. The lengthy message stating they are debt collectors is utterly absurd!

Individuals who owe money should be able to leave a message for a particular debtor, including their company's name, and request a callback at a designated phone number. Upon returning this sort of call, consumers should be informed by the collector or debtor with the mini-Miranda warning. It is unnecessary for collectors to leave messages that disclose the reason for their calls. The Health Information Privacy and Portability Act restricts the sharing of protected information with unauthorized individuals. This same principle should be extended to debt collectors.

In my observation, individuals younger than me, belonging to the boomer generation, tend to favor electronic communication methods like emails, texts, and chats. Reflecting on my past, when I was burdened with debt, I definitely would have preferred avoiding direct conversations with people. There exists a valid worry regarding the lack of encryption in emails or the chance that consumers might not realize others could access their emails. Nevertheless, it's important to promote communication in any form, especially if it aligns with the consumer's preference. I hold the view that emails, chats, and texts ought to be recognized as written forms of communication. I'm uncertain how all disclosures can be included unless individuals are directed to a source where they can understand them in straightforward language.

I find myself in a similar predicament, receiving phone calls for individuals who share my last name and either of my initials. To the best of my knowledge, none of the individuals being pursued have any familial connection to me, nor do they reside with me. I wish there were a way to officially assert that I have no outstanding debts and do not cohabitate with anyone who does. I would gladly update this declaration annually if it would prevent these calls, which are merely attempts to gather information.

Residing in Georgia, I've noticed that the legal system appears to heavily favor those holding debts. Take, for example, the laws concerning the limitations on mortgage debts. If the first lienholder proceeds with foreclosure, any secondary mortgage remains active. According to the OCGA, the statute of limitations on a "debt instrument under seal" is 20 years from the foreclosure date. This second lien can be repeatedly sold to different parties. The final holder of this lien can pursue you for up to two decades. In situations where homes are lost due to severe illness, unemployment, or other factors beyond the homeowner's control, new laws should be established to shield consumers from financial devastation.

Engaging in legal proceedings in a courtroom is fundamentally different from conversing over the phone with a debt collector who insists on evidence to establish the debt's invalidity. If pursuing legal action is your goal, then proceed with filing a lawsuit. However, demanding that someone you contact over the phone prove to you, rather than to a judge, that the debt doesn't belong to them is tantamount to extortion.

I urge the CFPB to tackle the problem of their "phishing" expeditions, specifically the practice of scouring phone directories and contacting anyone with a similar name. I was identified by my initials, and having a common surname led to incessant calls from debt collectors until I opted to use a nickname for my listing. Numerous comments on this site highlight that others are experiencing the same issue, indicating it is evidently a widespread practice. For some unexplained reason, when I inquire about how my number got into their system, the call center staff react negatively. Typically, their response has been to abruptly end the call. Furthermore, I recommend that the CFPB address the issue of repeated calls to incorrect individuals. If I'm not the intended recipient during the initial call, then I certainly won't be in any following ones. Through my dealings with debt collectors, I've come to realize there are two motivations for their relentless calls: Personnel in call centers are trained to persist and not accept No as an answer. By persistently calling, the debt collector aims to exhaust me into paying a debt that is not mine, just to cease their calls.

It is essential that consumers are not burdened with extra charges for phone calls, text messages, or voice messages in connection with collections. When a debtor faces increased costs, their ability to repay creditors diminishes. Debt collectors and creditors should be mandated to cease all forms of communication to any device that the debtor specifies as not offering free communication services, whether it be through calls or texts.

Credit reporting agencies ought to be mandated to immediately act upon disputes regarding debts and erase any mention of the disputed debt entirely. For instance, I am striving to get a paid lien, which is now time-barred, removed from my credit report. While two out of the three credit bureaus promptly took action to remove it, one remains adamant in not doing so. I have forwarded documents from the court, the original creditor, and the probate judge's office, yet my efforts have been unsuccessful. Lacking a solution, I am stuck with an incorrect entry on my credit report.

Perhaps I overlooked something but I never got any notification from my initial mortgage lender about the sale of my mortgage. This might be advantageous since the new "owner" could be a group of investors. in my case, the buyer sent a notice that included the name of the original creditor. Requiring both the seller and buyer to send a notification would lead to consumer confusion.

In my opinion, the primary reason for most default judgments is that consumers acknowledge their debt and find no benefit in delaying the matter. After being served, numerous consumers contact us to arrange payments. We inform them about their right to present their case in court, yet the majority opt out. Their main goal is to settle the debt promptly.

Consider robocalling; answering the call signals to them that this is a convenient time for you, encouraging future calls. The account frequently changes ownership, leading to repetition. "Updating our do not call lists requires time..."

Banks have the option to incorporate this clause into their Loan Sale Agreements. Any purchaser signing a Loan Sale Agreement with this clause would be legally bound to avoid engaging in litigation or even threatening it. Some existing buyers might decline to purchase if such a clause is included while other current buyers might demand a lower price because they would lose the option to litigate. In both cases, any stock not bought by current buyers would be rapidly acquired by other purchasers willing to adhere to these contractual terms. This approach would eliminate the need for new laws or regulations since the issue would be resolved through an agreement between a consenting seller and buyer. There would be no constitutional issues concerning the restriction of lawsuits and implementation would not be delayed. The only requirement would be the cooperation of the selling banks who could be easily persuaded with some Safe-Harbor language for those adhering to this protocol.

They have indeed taken such actions. I have received calls from the same debt collector who switches from a toll-free number to one with a local area code, and then alters one digit of that number. Search the number on Google. That proves to be incredibly useful. It will reveal the identity of the company making the call. It was consistently the same one. I believe this practice is unethical, deceptive, and a dishonest way to interact with people. However, the overall impression I get from what I am reading is that collectors are engaging in harassment primarily through phone calls. The appropriate action is to strengthen the laws to prevent such behavior. Currently, the only recourse for consumers is to file a lawsuit. However, for just $1000, it is challenging to find a lawyer willing to take on such a minor case. This situation has become increasingly detrimental to consumers, and it has gradually evolved into this state.

To equalize the financial playing field immediately, make any credit card debt incurred beyond the default moment contestable. The ability to challenge any debt amount exceeding the initial default would prompt credit card firms and debt collectors to collaborate with consumers on a feasible repayment strategy, wouldn't it? Currently, credit card companies have the option to raise interest rates to as much as 29.9% and sometimes choose to keep the account in default while accumulating frequent default penalties on the borrower. After I closed my award-winning video business to care for my parents, my savings dwindled and I informed my credit card providers of impending default. None of them could provide a solution other than advising me to pay my bill promptly. If credit card companies were aware that post-default, they couldn't impose further penalties, fees, or interest hikes, they would go to great lengths to assist the supposed defaulter in reducing their debt. Citibank increased my longstanding credit card account balance by $5,000 despite timely payments over 15 years. I contest this excessive amount considering the reasons for my default, but Citibank, along with the debt collector, remains indifferent. If the debt amount reverted to its level at the default time, Citibank would undoubtedly strive to cooperate with me.

I propose that the CFPB should establish a rule preventing creditors and debt collectors from transferring a disputed debt to another collection agency once the consumer has challenged the debt or issued a "cease and desist" notice. Based on my experience with similar cases, a "cease and desist" letter was sent to both the debt collector and the original creditor, demanding they stop pursuing the debt in accordance with the FDCPA. Nevertheless, they simply shut down one collection company and pass the account to another, forcing the consumer to restart the process from scratch. It is essential for the CFPB to implement a regulation requiring that once a debt is contested or a "cease and desist" letter is forwarded to a debt collector, the collector must inform the original creditor about the receipt of such a letter.

Since credit card agreements are adhesion contracts, it falls upon informed independent parties to ensure the fairness of these contracts. When individuals face unexpected events beyond their control that lower their income, it seems unreasonable not to allow them to pause interest and fees until they recover financially. They are still committed to repaying, but their lives have been disrupted by unforeseen circumstances, which should be considered in certain situations. It seems unjust to penalize a consumer when their house is swept away by a flood, consumed by a wildfire, or demolished by an earthquake, among other disasters. It is particularly unethical for credit card companies to obscure the penalties they impose when a consumer's genuine intention to pay is thwarted by a natural disaster. Insurance does not cover acts of war, yet the government permitted the owner of the World Trade Center to claim their insurance despite 9/11 being undeniably an act of war. Surveys have indicated that many Americans were displeased with the 2008 bailouts as they did not receive any relief. The "Promise to Pay" does not explicitly mandate making payments every month above all other circumstances. I think judges have misunderstood the "Promise to Pay," and attorneys favor the current setup because they are reluctant to address the clear deficiencies in credit card adhesion contracts as it might jeopardize their future earnings.

When a debt collection agency, Bayview, assumed responsibility for managing my mortgage, I began to receive phone calls at both my workplace and on my mobile regarding the status of my mortgage payments despite the fact that they were up-to-date. These calls even included automated messages. I was informed that this was considered 'standard practice' and advised to disregard these calls, but it made me extremely frustrated, leading me to file a complaint with the Better Business Bureau in the state where one of their offices is located. I have consistently made my payments on time, and my mortgage was not under debt collection proceedings. Although Bayview functions as a debt collector, they must ensure that their debt collection operations are kept distinct from their mortgage management services. It should be illegal to contact individuals at their workplace, use automated calls, and harass them when there are no overdue debts.

I am subscribed to a Senior mobile phone plan and I incur charges for every text message I send or receive. While I can send and receive texts, each one comes with a cost... therefore, it seems unjust to impose additional charges beyond what I already pay. I oppose the use of cell phones for sending business promotions or texts and calls related to debt collection.

I recommend examining the Federal Bankruptcy Rule 3001, which became effective on December 1, 2012, as well as reviewing the comments made during its proposal stage and the published statements from the hearing presentations. The Rule already tackles the issues related to documentation. In my view, including all proposed documents with the validation notice is not advantageous for either the consumer or the sender. I firmly believe that additional documentation regarding the chain of title should be accessible if a consumer faces a lawsuit in Court.

Collection calls and dunning notices, whether sent by mail or email, should incorporate a distinct Collection ID. This ID would be included in credit reports to facilitate tracking. Additionally, consumers could access an online database managed by the CRPB to report any violations or issues. This approach would simplify the CRPB's ability to review disputes and verify the presence of genuine problems.

In cases where our client(s) fail to verify the debt, we proceed by closing the account and informing the debtor through a letter about this decision. It's important to mention that this scenario has occurred only once or twice over the span of 20 years. An account with a dispute that remains unresolved should definitely not be sold. In such cases, the seller ought to be held accountable.

Emails from businesses or debt collection agencies ought to clearly state the state in which they are registered along with their registration number, enabling consumers to verify their legitimacy. The sheer volume of fraudulent emails makes it highly unlikely for recipients to trust that an email from a debt collector is genuine.

If a lawyer is categorized as a 'Debt Collector' according to their documentation but not legally recognized as a 'Collection Agency,' they are not held accountable for breaches of consumer protection laws, both at the state and federal level, in civil court. It is imperative to close this loophole. Lawyers acting as debt collectors are not under the supervision of the state bar because their actions fall under collection practices. (these lawyers purchase old debts and pursue collection through civil court) and neither state nor federal civil courts are overseeing these attorneys since their offices are not classified as collection agencies. - despite the fact that the lawyers acquire old debts and then bring the supposed debtors to civil court. I am aware of a significant law firm in Washington State that even conducts training sessions for other attorneys through the Washington state bar because these cases are relatively straightforward to win.

Residing in Florida, I've observed that it's becoming increasingly challenging for debt purchasers to validate debts without resorting to document falsification. In one of my current legal battles, I've noticed that the debt's bill of sale has been altered with white-out in three different areas, unfortunately, these altered documents were submitted by a lawyer who is a member of the Florida Bar Association. Debt purchasers appear to lack any sense of ethics.

Compliance 2013 epitomizes the kind of conceit I've been discussing in my earlier remarks. It is crucial to tackle the notion held by courts that any default is simply a default, alongside the system that REWARDS Strategic Defaulters while condemning those who default involuntarily to perpetual mounting debt due to continuous interest accrual. My investigation into consumer debt has spanned several years. and consumer debt is increasing worldwide, which is certainly detrimental. A Canadian financial expert issues a warning regarding the surge in consumer debt. __URL__ The name Canada in the title can easily be swapped with England, Australia, South Africa, China, Russia, Ireland, and many more. The spike in consumer debt is fueled by an unreasonably low 2% monthly minimum payment, which acts as a gateway to ever-increasing debt, and because consumers facing significant life-changing events leading to default are unable to argue INVOLUNTARY DEFAULT in legal proceedings. We allow offenders to plead involuntary in numerous crimes, yet deny law-abiding citizens this option concerning their credit card and student loan debts!

I work as a clerk at the city's local court. I handle civil cases and I believe that the laws regarding debt collection treat debtors quite unfairly. The Court is prohibited from providing legal counsel which makes it distressing to try to explain and comfort distressed litigants who are unaware of what awaits them. I advocate for more options for pro se litigants who cannot afford private legal representation (which applies to 95% of the litigants in my area). It's apparent that most individuals do not respond to summonses because they were either not served properly, simply ignore them, or mostly, don't comprehend the legal jargon. However, I do receive numerous calls from litigants inquiring about the steps to take once they have been served. When individuals do submit responses, they are often in letter format rather than a 'legal' verified response. Debt collection lawyers typically seize this opportunity to seek summary judgment. Our Court accepts letters without hesitation, and we forward a copy to the attorney, arranging a pre-trial meeting with a judge or court attorney to facilitate a resolution between the parties. The Court must follow a schedule for these meetings, but we maintain flexibility and if a defendant has scheduling issues, we strive to accommodate them as best as possible. When summonses are submitted to the court, half are packed with debt details, while others only state the amount owed. In my experience, it's sometimes challenging for litigants to obtain additional proof from attorneys, even when the court mandates it. When processing default judgments, I meticulously review the entire file, comparing the summons/complaint and the submitted default judgment, double-checking the affidavit of service for the summons (to verify the defendant had adequate time to respond), and ensuring the default judgment is accompanied by proper documentation such as debt purchase proof, a non-military affidavit, etc. I also verify that the correct interest rate and court fees are being applied. Ultimately, debtors lack sufficient laws to safeguard them, and the Court is constrained by these regulations, even if there was a desire to assist, it would be impossible. Although the Court is meant to be unbiased, in a small community where everyone is familiar with one another, witnessing these practices can be difficult.

At one point, a debt collector sent collection letters to my workplace. They already had my residential address. I believe this practice should be banned as well. Who typically receives personal correspondence at their job?

I also make it a point not to pick up calls that lack identification, such as those without a name, number or those from toll-free lines. After facing over a year of unemployment and managing only to secure part-time positions, I had to relinquish my landline. I frequently receive calls from unknown numbers on my mobile, despite having sent written instructions to all creditors to refrain from contacting my cell number. I'm nearing the point where I might not be able to afford my mobile phone, yet giving it up would mean losing any chance of being reached by a prospective employer. Once I secure a full-time position, I am more than willing to settle my debts, but incessant phone calls won't expedite the repayment of those debts. No company has ever reached out to offer me credit, thus they should refrain from calling my cell, as it only increases my expenses and delays their payment. Moreover, most of these calls are automated and never leave a message, leaving me clueless about whom the call was intended for.

I've been burdened with a debt lasting over two decades., On several occasions, I've refinanced and settled everything listed on my credit report.. These issues only surface once everything is finalized.. Year after year, they secure a judgment against me, and immobilize my bank account, causing delays in settling my bills..

Although Option 1 appears to be the most straightforward, there are complexities that aren't immediately obvious. Who decides what the term "principal" actually refers to? In the case of revolving credit accounts, interest accumulates (as finance charges) and becomes part of the total balance. Thus, does "principal" imply only the part of the balance that the cardholder charged (which is extremely challenging, if not impossible, for a collector to determine) or the complete charged-off amount? I acknowledge that managing various types of debts can be challenging. However, I believe this approach is impractical for a significant segment of consumer debt. Option 2 is ineffective because who determines the point at which a consumer has "defaulted" on an account? Many people have occasionally missed a payment but manage to catch up. Hence, it's too vague. This makes Option 3 the most practical, yet what about accounts that have never received a periodic or billing statement? I suggest that we break down the total by listing the amount due on the last statement issued by the original creditor, or if no statement was ever given, the original debt amount at the time it was incurred, followed by a detailed breakdown of all debits and credits applied since that balance.

Debt collectors should be prohibited from pestering a debtor's former spouse by incessantly calling them. Debt collectors often utilize the debtor's previous phone number, which now exclusively belongs to the ex-spouse. Despite the ex-spouse's request for her number to be erased from their records, the collectors ignore this and continue to contact her in an attempt to reach the debtor. It should be mandated that collectors delete her number from their records upon her initial request and refrain from contacting her thereafter. If this is not enforced, she is left without any means to put an end to the harassment.

MLegz13 has raised numerous valid arguments. My aging parents required assistance with their everyday tasks, despite their reluctance to admit it. I had to give up my successful video production business to take on the role of their caregiver. Once our savings were depleted, I was forced to default after maintaining an impeccable credit card payment record for 15 years. The debt collectors relentlessly accused me of being unwilling to pay, even though I acknowledged the debt and explained that I currently lacked an income. Situations like this necessitate that debts be frozen at the point of default, with the debtor committing to repay, even if the initial payments are minimal. This approach liberates the debtor's phone lines, allowing them to focus on progress instead of engaging in futile exchanges with persistent debt collection calls. This is also why I initiated the Debt Neutrality Petition. If you click the link, I urge you to read the remarks from over 500 individuals who have endorsed the petition. Notably, a debt collector endorsed the petition, and their comment, like many others, reveals significant truths. Debt Neutrality Petition. __URL__

only the phone number should be displayed on the caller ID. This allows consumers to search the number online to decide if they wish to engage in conversation or return the call. Moreover, this empowers attorneys to file FDCPA claims against debt collection agencies because the identity of the caller is clear.

Consumers ought to be informed or warned in advance if their debt is going to be handed over to a collection agency. Additionally, consumers should be alerted if there is a switch in the debt collection agency handling their accounts.

It is advisable for consumers who owe debt to be informed if a third party intends to settle their debt. Individuals who opt to pay off another person's debt should be obligated to disclose their identity to both the lender and the borrower.

Is it possible to establish a nationwide system for reporting harassing phone calls from debt collectors who disguise their caller ID? Several years back, I acquired a completely new phone number. which clearly was previously assigned to an individual who hasn't been keeping up with their financial obligations. as I constantly receive calls from debt collectors searching for the previous owner of my phone number.
