There should be a mandate for accurate caller ID so that the recipient can at least recognize the collector and have a contact number to reach them. Furthermore, financial penalties need to be significantly increased to deter their unacceptable, predatory, and harassing behaviors. Intimidation is integral to their business strategies. These individuals should at the very least be mandated to disclose their identity truthfully. Automated calls and identity spoofing should be prohibited with severe fines.

Since it belongs to the consumer and they are entitled to that! Why should consumers bear the cost of being bothered?! Shift the financial burden to the companies where it rightfully belongs, not onto the consumers! I cover the expenses for my mobile phone, I pay for the talk time, I am the one who will determine how they are utilized and who can contact me, not these unscrupulous, unpleasant companies!

My daughter has taken out both private and federal loans from Sallie Mae. She and I receive calls on our cell phones from them every day, at least ten times. They reached out to me, despite not having her consent to discuss her loans with me, advising me to halt payments on her federal loans since they can be deferred, and instead focus on the private loans. The private loans amount to $176,000, and my daughter is unable to meet the payment demands. They even contacted her workplace seeking information about her. She responded by sending a letter, requesting communication solely via email and postal mail. When they called me, I inquired if they had received her letter and their response was affirmative, yet they insisted on needing to speak with someone. However, they do not have my number listed as a contact. I informed them of this, yet they persist in calling my cell phone every day. My daughter is struggling to cover her current expenses. I assist her in managing her private loan payments. I am not listed on any of her loan agreements. This kind of harassment must come to an end!

You've highlighted a problem that involves two separate interpretations: 'sent' and 'received'. I'm confident no consumer desires to 'receive' a notice that was never actually 'sent'. Moreover, it's a common occurrence for letters and packages to go missing in the postal system. Should there be a stipulation for creditors or collectors to 'send' the notices in question, the initial destination will be the address they have on record. If these letters are returned, it indicates that the person is no longer at the recorded address. However, the letters must be 'sent' initially.

It's important for me to have a visible number. Cease blocking caller ID and refrain from using toll-free numbers. In my experience, toll-free numbers are typically associated with telemarketers or sales representatives. I prefer to be informed if I owe a debt that is in collections. Therefore, ensure transparency.

Collectors who employ robocalls without first confirming the phone number with a personal call are acting in a lazy and careless manner. Beyond being a significant annoyance, robocalls to third parties consistently result in improper disclosures. This is because prerecorded messages must state the company's name at the beginning, as mandated by the TCPA. I've been on the receiving end of countless calls of this nature. As a result, I'm now aware of which neighbors are reportedly in debt. I use the term "reportedly" because these calls often come from companies that have been repeatedly sued for attempting to collect debts that don't exist. Banning robocalls, especially those to third parties, would primarily affect the wrongdoers without significantly impacting legitimate debt collectors. I wouldn't object to live operators using autodialers, if not for the outdated technology employed by some collection agencies. Telemarketers manage to comply with the 3% call abandonment threshold. However, in my experience, the rate of dropped calls from collectors is alarmingly between 50% and 100%. Indeed, I dealt with a company that disconnected the call every single time one of their representatives contacted me. I fail to see how this strategy is financially beneficial. Applying the FTC's 3% rule to debt collection calls could effectively solve this problem.

I absolutely refuse to pick up any calls labeled as "unknown caller" or simply "unknown" on the caller ID. If your company's name doesn't appear on the caller ID, it raises suspicions about your transparency or possible hidden agendas. Bear in mind that it's you reaching out to me, and this makes phone calls a violation of my personal space. I am under no obligation to respond to calls that I prefer to ignore. It should be mandated that debt collection companies clearly disclose their identity when they make phone calls.
This is simply the cost of being in this line of work. Should debt collectors find themselves unable to cope with the realities of the industry, they ought to seek careers in a different field.

Make a strong effort to address issues in the service industry. They have significantly disrupted the debt collection process by allowing their employees to falsely serve and falsely subserve individuals who are purportedly in debt. I've experienced this twice; the first instance involved the process server inaccurately guessing my description with the most generic features and inventing a name. The second occurrence saw the server using 'Jane Doe' and again fabricating generic descriptions spanning various ages, heights, and races, resulting in a gross mismatch. Additionally, I overheard another defendant in court claim that they were never properly served, with documents merely left outside their door. The service company falsely represented court documents, claiming service to someone who was not served. This alone should empower the judge with the authority to implement measures protecting defendants. When debt collectors realize they can rely on false service, their incentive to negotiate with defendants significantly diminishes. Judges appear oblivious to the implications of false service. I am certain of my experiences and I can assert confidently, wherever necessary, that I've been falsely served or subserved twice.

Debt collection agencies are not obligated to substantiate the debt or provide consumers with detailed information. For instance, I challenged the legitimacy of a debt. The validation I received was merely a brief statement saying: "The consumer owes the debt." In my opinion, and likely that of any reasonable person, this does not constitute proper validation. Collection agencies should be mandated to provide sufficient details for consumers to either acknowledge or contest the debt. Preferably, this information would include a copy of the original application and the final billing statement.

Rules established by state and local courts can sometimes lead to an increased likelihood of default judgments. To illustrate, if a person accused of owing debt is required to attend court during their working hours, they might have to choose between facing a default judgment or safeguarding their employment. I recommend that the CFPB consider practices that schedule hearings at inconvenient times as unfair, deceptive, abusive, or contrary to section 1692i.

State laws should prevent them from earning excessive profits on such minor investments (usury!!!). Additional factors to deliberate on this matter include: The unpaid debt the purchaser does not reveal the price paid for the bad debt. This information should be openly disclosed. since they possess the original debt details, including social security number, contact, and financial data. I don't object to them earning a profit, but their exploitative methods must be subject to regulation. A higher court judge should have the authority to review the initial transaction, all the documentation related to the third-party debt purchase and establish a fair payment solution to settle the issue, thereby preventing bankruptcy.

I'd like to clarify that I'm not suggesting debt relief due to a transformative life event. I'm proposing that the debt should be locked at its original amount during the time of involuntary default, and repaid over a decade, if necessary.

I wholeheartedly support drose977's viewpoint. At present, debt collection firms can transfer debt without proper verification. Alternatively, they can sell the debt even if a consumer challenges it and the agency fails to provide appropriate validation. These practices should be prohibited as they severely harm the consumer. Consumers must be prioritized over collectors and similar agencies. since typically, they possess significantly fewer resources to counteract incorrect information. Moreover, erroneous information negatively impacts consumers more than any other group in such circumstances. Collectors should be prohibited from reporting a debt as 30 days overdue if it hasn't reached that period. Legislation should impose stringent and enforceable penalties to dissuade collectors from falsely dating debts. These regulations should be applicable to any debt reported as overdue at any point, not just during the initial 30 days.

I concur with josephusmyer's viewpoint. About eight years back, our son accrued minor debts with various stores and banks. Debt collectors, acting as debt buyers, have reached out to him, making threats of legal proceedings over these debts, which are actually past the statute of limitations, without informing him about this fact.

I am okay with receiving work-related calls. What bothers me is how often they occur. Truthfully, I acknowledge that the bill is my responsibility. However, I believe they should refrain from contacting my workplace unless I fail to return their calls. They should send me a text and call me initially, allowing a few days for a response. Subsequently, they can reach out to my workplace but not on a daily basis.

Consumers should be proactive in all their endeavors. If someone has the ability to incur debt, then they should also possess the ability to settle it. From my experience, every credit union I've encountered goes above and beyond to assist their members in achieving financial well-being.
All types of written correspondence ought to be recognized as an official notice. Debt collectors should be mandated to adhere to any instructions received through email communication.

In a legal dispute, each party is responsible for presenting the evidence that backs up their claims. As someone who collects debts, I provide documentation to support the existence of the debt. The person being accused of the debt must also furnish evidence to prove that the debt doesn't belong to them. Although the principle of 'innocent until proven guilty' is upheld, there is an obligation to offer evidence supporting one's innocence claim. If I present a signed agreement indicating you consented to the purchase along with proof of non-payment, I have satisfied my responsibility to provide evidence. In our judicial system, the debtor also carries a responsibility to prove their case. This is the role of the judge - to listen to both parties, assess the evidence, and render a fair judgment based on the information and arguments brought forward.

Publishing an article focused on landlords engaging in unlawful lawsuits and debt collections would likely result in a deluge of feedback. This is a sector of debt collection that remains obscure yet is widespread in New York City.

I'm sorry to learn about this predicament. It's distressing to hear about this type of abusive conduct as a customer. There's no necessity for them to "speak" with anyone. You and your daughter are fully entitled legally to request that the calls cease and to opt for alternative communication methods. Collectors who refuse to comply with this demand are breaching the law. Furthermore, they should refrain from reaching out to you. nor should they be contacting you or your daughter ten times a day. Such behavior is undeniably excessive and abusive. I also want to point out that although they are correct about federal loans often being eligible for deferment, debt collectors are not fiduciaries. They neither act in the consumer's best interest nor can they provide sound financial advice. Collectors will say or do anything just to secure payment. They shouldn't be permitted to advise on which bills to settle and the methods to do so. Such "advice" might harm consumers or debtors. Perhaps the CFPB should allow collectors to provide referrals for financial advice, but they should be prohibited from directly offering financial advice.

What if arbitrators were guided not only by strict legal frameworks but also by practical judgment when dealing with credit card defaults? It's logical to assume that if a flood in Colorado devastates a community, residents might struggle to meet their credit card payments for a while. It stands to reason that situations like a medical crisis, being injured in a hit-and-run, losing one's home, or assuming unpaid caregiving duties for a family member should take priority over the obligation to make monthly payments. This isn't about erasing the debt, it's about classifying the debt as neutral, halting penalties, fees, or interest rate increases, with the debtor committing to repay the balance responsibly, even if it takes a decade. __URL__

Collectors frequently exploit phone contact regulations, and there is a lack of enforcement against those who break these rules. Laws should restrict collectors to communicating through mail. These individuals act like bottom-feeders, blatantly disregarding legal boundaries. Eliminate their ability to make phone contacts entirely. They have consistently demonstrated over many years that they are habitual lawbreakers. Prohibit any phone communications.

The importance of security cannot be overstated. Given that the vulnerabilities in the current authentication methods used by financial institutions and others governed by FACTA and the FCRA are excluded from this legislation, enforcing those identical security measures on any centralized database for debt collection should not pose a challenge.

A debt from 19 years ago unexpectedly resurfaced in my life. I consulted three lawyers, hoping to hire them to negotiate with the company, but despite my repeated calls and an offer to settle for slightly over half of what they claimed I owed, I received no response. Over those 19 years, the debt inflated from approximately $1,200 to $9,300. Such conduct needs to be subject to regulation. It's nothing short of a blatant scam.

Can you believe it's already 2013? It is really frustrating when phone calls are ignored and it is irritating to always see missed calls. Why are bill collectors still operating like it's the past? Send me a text! Drop me an email! I'm not going to return those calls because I have a job and children to take care of. Communicating would be so much more straightforward if I could text and email them. Honestly, we're not living in the 1950s anymore!

I recently found out that my mortgage lender does not possess the note for my mortgage and they are unable to locate it. I am up to date with my payments and have no intention of reducing them. I inquired with the mortgage company about the next steps we should take. For the past 8 months, they have been sending us notifications stating that they are investigating the matter.

The CFPB ought to prohibit workplace calls altogether. When consumers incur debt, they provide a residential phone number, which should be the sole contact point for collection purposes. Instead of workplace calls, communication should utilize registered or certified mail as an alternative method. Moreover, Massachusetts implementing a cap on the number of calls is an excellent initiative. In contemporary times, we no longer incarcerate individuals for debt. Yet, the excessive level of mistreatment and disdain faced by debtors is wholly intolerable. It is imperative for the CFPB to reform the debt collection sector urgently.

From the perspective of a lender, I largely concur with this statement. In my opinion, a well-crafted validation notice could address many of the consumer's inquiries. I believe the author of the previous comment had some exceptionally well-thought-out insights. I wouldn't go as far as insisting on an itemized statement, especially if it might be unavailable (possibly due to record-keeping policies, or simply because it may not exist), but supplying details like the type of account, the original creditor's brand name, the account number, the date of the last payment, and the name of the entity from which the debt was purchased would be beneficial. Providing documentation upfront seems unnecessary and expensive, especially if the letter's phrasing allows the consumer to easily identify the account and the disclosures enable them to request documentation for verification.

I have no issues with my partner. After all, she is my wife. Therefore, I see no reason why it shouldn't be acceptable. However, I don't support the idea of having girlfriends or boyfriends for individuals who aren't married. A spouse is perfectly fine.

I find it unjust for a third party to purchase an overdue debt and then sue for the entire amount, including attorney fees, court expenses, and other charges related to mediators or arbitrators. I believe there should be a cap on how much more a third-party debt buyer can claim beyond their initial purchase cost. Often, the original lender is a company that is publicly traded and any financial loss has already been absorbed by the shareholders. Afterwards, a debt purchaser acquires a batch of non-performing debts, paying just ten cents on the dollar. They then send these to a 'law office' with the aim of recovering 100% or more of the initial claimed debt. Debt buyers should be prohibited from suing for returns equivalent to 900% of what they invested. Their claims should be confined to a portion of the actual damages. I am unaware of any other civil proceedings where such practices would be deemed ethical.

I advocate for stringent oversight concerning the so-called "skip-trace" service providers. These are the firms that debt recovery agents and others employ to furnish them with contact details. Drawing from my own experiences (having a common surname, frequently pursued by debt collectors), I feel vulnerable to these vendors. They accumulate various data about individuals without apparently verifying any of it, as far as I can ascertain. One debt collector informed my state's Attorney General that they engaged one of these services that provided my phone number as a valid contact for a person sharing my last name and first initial, despite this being someone unknown to me, yet the collector sought payment from me. I propose that these vendors should be tightly regulated and employ resources other than the phone directory to compile their data. They should only be permitted to supply "accurate" information when it truly meets that criterion.

I am in favor of implementing these limitations on robo-calls as well as any phone calls made during working hours. Regarding robo-calls, it is crucial to impose restrictions on any that are deceptive. For instance, a robo-call claiming you have a message or an account update, requiring you to dial a specific number with an extension, only to find it's the same message inquiring about your payment, squanders the consumer's time and mobile resources (involving two calls, one received and one sent).
In Illinois, there exists legislation against Caller ID spoofing. I continue to receive calls daily with inaccurate or unclear Caller ID information, and no message is ever left. __URL__
Indeed, I experienced that earlier today, an individual phoned claiming to be a "courier service" while attempting to find a friend.

Considering the serious impact of negative information being reported to or by Credit Reporting Agencies on consumer credit reports, it seems fair that a debt should not be labeled as "verified" or "substantiated" until there is a final, non-appealable judgment, but only if the consumer has promptly disputed the debt's existence or amount. At present, when you contest a debt, the collector informs the CRAs and this adversely affects your credit rating; in essence, the harm is done by then. Simply put, the note on the credit report indicating that the consumer disputes the debt is mostly disregarded by potential lenders, employers, landlords, and others. Therefore, disputing the debt does little to shield the consumer from damage. Debt collectors and creditors use the threat of reporting to CRAs as a tool to pressure you into paying a debt even if you genuinely do not owe the debt or the amount claimed. Regarding my suggestion, I don't anticipate an increase in litigation. Quite the contrary. If a consumer doesn't dispute the debt in a timely manner, then the debt can be considered verified or substantiated. However, if the debt is disputed on time, creditors and debt collectors will need to consider whether to proceed with litigation and assess the chances of success in court, which might lead them to be more selective about which debts to pursue legally. This proposal would also safeguard consumers from having their credit standing affected negatively until it is definitively shown that a disputed debt is indeed owed and the exact amount is established. As an alternative to my main proposal, a rule could be implemented that imposes substantial statutory penalties, triple damages, and the recovery of attorney's fees against creditors, debt collectors, and CRAs if the consumer can demonstrate that the disputed debt doesn't exist or is less than claimed. However, this method places the onus of proof on the consumer and I firmly believe that it should be the responsibility of creditors and debt collectors to actively demonstrate the existence and amount of any disputed debt before negatively affecting a consumer's credit report.

I believe the system should implement a sequence of 'handshakes': when a dispute begins, when it is settled, and when a dispute is retracted. In every scenario, the consumer must be assured that the collector recognizes their stance, and that the CRA has received proper notification. The CRA must be involved in the handshake process, It is intolerable for consumer grievances to linger for extended periods without a means to verify if the CRA has received updated data from the collector or if there is an excessive delay in processing the update.

Social Media: Although courts occasionally permit social media usage for issuing notices, it's important to note that not all individuals are active on every social media site. Even though I am quite adept with the internet, I still don't use platforms like Foursquare, Pinterest, and many others. On platforms like Facebook and Twitter, there exist thousands of individuals sharing my name who might receive erroneous notifications.

Although not directly mentioned on this site, the existing penalties for breaching the FDCPA lack any real impact. A fine of $100 hardly affects most businesses. The legislation should be amended to implement a seven-year statute of limitations (currently set at one year) and increase the maximum penalty, to be awarded to the plaintiff, to either $10,000 or $100,000 for each infraction.

All communications from collectors should be conducted via mail unless the consumer opts for phone communication. This approach gives the consumer the opportunity to carefully deliberate over the demands made by the collector. Additionally, it helps prevent misunderstandings for both parties involved. The sole reason this isn't the common practice is that it reduces the ability of collectors to be persistently bothersome and humiliating—it's as straightforward as that.
If you don't respond, they will likely attempt to reach you again. Instead of disregarding the call, you could pick up and request that the company refrain from contacting you.

In response to the initial inquiry, conducting thorough research is essential. Although collectors may continue pursuing legal actions, which I anticipate will persist, there should be repercussions for collectors if they make false claims. Should litigation be initiated against an incorrect individual, the initiating party must compensate the victim with a fair fee and pay a significant additional fee to the regulatory body to cover oversight expenses. Regarding the second inquiry, I am convinced that a vast majority of consumer debt is repayable. Nonetheless, exceptions to this are inevitable. For debts that cannot be retrieved for any reason, they should be definitively written off as non-recoverable and prohibited from being resold as collectible debt. The refinement and definition of 'Non-Collectable' must be determined by the relevant oversight bureau or agency. Addressing the third inquiry, both parties should be assessed. Currently, credit reporting agencies exist to oversee the consumer aspect of this matter, and a numerical evaluation score could be appended to the consumer's already existing credit report. This would serve as a foundational step that could be expanded as the system is refined. Conversely, the collector would necessitate a novel evaluation system that rates not just the organization overall, but also the individuals engaged in debt resolution activities. For effective illustrations of such systems, I would refer you to the Department of Transportation's Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and their Compliance-Safety-Accountability framework. Their system, admittedly, is considerably more intricate and delves deeper than what the debt industry would require. However, their scoring system is adaptable and robust for future modifications. It would also facilitate the evaluation of the original creditor. Such evaluation would provide the government and investors with better insight into the risk profile of a particular business. Incorporating Mr. Bartmann's suggestions, we create a framework where collectors and financial institutions self-regulate to ensure ethical and responsible outcomes, avoiding the defense of merely acting within legal boundaries. This would be advantageous for both parties and aid many consumers in escaping the cycle of overwhelming debt. Finally, the federal government could introduce this system with minimal disruption to state sovereignty. It would lessen the occurrence of litigation in state and local courts, thus encouraging states to participate.

My surname is quite common, which results in my phone book entry displaying two initials instead of my full first name. I frequently receive calls from debt collectors multiple times a week, searching for different individuals who share my last name and either of my initials. It's essentially a random guess on their part. Whenever I inform them that I am the sole resident and boast a stellar credit score, they remove my number from their list for the current target. If I request that they cease contacting me entirely since no other individuals reside with me, they simply respond that my number was only listed for today's target. My number might be considered again for tomorrow's target, yet they claim there's nothing they can do about future calls. In fact, one credit collection agent based in India told me that exact thing.

I find it baffling that debt collectors are stuck in outdated practices. Receiving numerous calls is quite bothersome. I would definitely prefer to receive a text message or an email instead. A ringing phone can be intrusive, whereas a text message is more discreet. Additionally, it spares me from listening to a lengthy voicemail. I would appreciate a text indicating their identity and purpose. If I don't reply promptly, then you should proceed with calling me.

such an approach would lack efficiency. According to the FCRA, a debt that is no longer being handled by a creditor or collector cannot be reported. For instance, if the debt is currently being reported by your creditor but is then sold to a collection agency, the original creditor loses the ability to report on that debt. The purchaser can report the debt, provided they comply with the relevant federal regulations.
The option to validate the debt should be eliminated. It should be mandatory to make attempts and if the debt is not verified, it should not be eligible for further transfer.

Requiring this much information is excessive. It is not the responsibility of creditors or collectors to provide notices regarding "best practices" or personnel details. The focus here is on notifications that a debt has been handed over for collection. The debt hasn't been sold; it has merely been transferred to specialists in debt collection. Notification is provided when the validation notice is dispatched. The entity that sends the notice is the collector. The letter will clearly mention the name of the creditor owed. This information suffices.

My daughter, who passed away two years ago, left behind some unpaid debts. Despite repeatedly requesting that they stop, we are still being contacted by debt collection agencies. In response to this ongoing harassment, my wife has reached out to the Oregon State Justice Department to lodge formal complaints. Is it not possible for these collectors to verify the debtor's information before distressing the family?
I firmly believe that documentation is an essential requirement in all cases. What reason would I have to settle a debt without concrete evidence that it is indeed my responsibility?

From a legal standpoint, I contend that the CFPB's authority should not extend to this domain. This is because federal legislation does not impose such a restriction. Informing a consumer that a debt is past the statute of limitations poses challenges. This is due to the fact that the expiration date is not fixed. A partial payment on an account can reset the statute of limitations. I am skeptical that a CFPB regulation would be effective in this context. I view consumer education as the sole proactive solution available in this situation. Nevertheless, this educational initiative should entail informing the legal community that the CFPB intends to report violations in this sector to the state's Attorney General.

Marian raises a great point regarding how Debt Collectors receive their compensation. Their strategy is to secure as much money as they can upfront. Interestingly, if they manage to collect too much initially, the credit card company might reclaim the account from the debt collector. If the debt collector receives an amount deemed "too low," they lose interest. This contradicts many sales strategies, which suggest that it's easier to engage later with a paying customer than to aim for a large gain all at once.

The real issue lies in the execution of laws. When debt collectors receive instructions to cease contacting a consumer's workplace, they often disregard the legal obligation to halt these calls. Informing regulators about these breaches is pointless, because enforcement actions are rarely taken, and collectors are fully aware of this. Strengthen enforcement measures.

It should be handled similarly to any document you send by fax or traditional mail, uploading simply provides a more convenient method for delivery. Regarding the appropriate timeframe, 48 hours would be my suggestion.

There was a situation where my lawyer, representing me, asked for confirmation of the loan debt, but the collector never replied. Consequently, I am unable to proceed with the settlement until they provide a response.

I've encountered a similar issue with a different mobile service provider. It appears to be a tactic designed to continuously make the debt appear current. This involved another charge for ending my contract early, and I had to pen numerous letters before it was eventually erased from my credit history. I believe this strategy of repeatedly selling the same debt to prolong its presence on credit reports must be halted. It's a single debt, and there's a specific duration it should remain visible on someone's credit record. A sensible approach would be mandating notifications for individuals when a debt is transferred. Such notification is obligatory when a mortgage changes hands. This seems like an obvious solution. Legislation should be crafted not just to discourage but to outright prohibit debt collection agencies from circulating debts merely to keep them active on credit reports.

Indeed, if the account remains active, the bank is required to keep the agreement for a period of 20 years. In cases where the account became delinquent two decades prior to any legal action, the statute of limitations has been exceeded, rendering the lawsuit baseless; therefore, it should be dismissed with penalties.
There should be no overarching federal regulations. States should be permitted to keep upholding their own legal frameworks.

In our office, we cast a wide net when it comes to "disputes." This is mainly challenging to pinpoint since it can manifest in very specific and personal ways. Broadly speaking, the disputes we encounter typically revolve around situations where a debt buyer has acquired the debt, and the consumer does not recognize the debt buyer's name, often stating they don't owe the debt (without further explanation) or they dispute the amount being claimed. Moreover, there might be assertions of fraud or previous payment. Our office cautiously accepts both verbal and written disputes. I believe the more significant concern isn't what qualifies as a dispute, but rather, how a collector substantiates the debt. Numerous consumers request extremely precise documentation. There exists a poorly constructed template letter circulating online that many consumers resort to using, where they ask for verification rather than validation, whatever distinction that might hold, then demand detailed information be supplied. I mention this because I think many consumers expect each of those requested items to be provided, despite the FDCPA not addressing what constitutes proper verification. I'll save that topic for another discussion, as my belief is that defining verification will be a formidable challenge since it shouldn't be so strictly defined that different creditors can't possibly furnish the requested information, nor so broadly defined that significant litigation is required to establish its meaning.

I have doubts that a registration system for debt collectors effectively tackles the problem. I don't fully understand how the registration system would function. In Massachusetts, individuals can verify online if a debt collector holds a valid license in the state, but many people are unaware of the website or, on a fundamental level, don't realize that the debt collector lacks the authority to pursue collection from them. Does the registration system aim to override state laws that mandate licensing for debt collectors within each state? I sincerely hope that isn't the intention because states have a significant interest in overseeing debt collectors to safeguard their consumers.

A notification should be issued indicating that the debt has been transferred. as it certainly guides the consumer on how to approach the negotiation of debt repayment. When a debt is transferred, it is often for a much lower amount than the original debt. allowing the lender to write it off, while the borrower suffers a negative impact on their credit history for seven years. In some cases, the "debt collector" is actually a fully-owned subsidiary of the "original" lender, thereby enabling them to benefit from a tax deduction; the borrower incurs damage to their credit; and they persist in attempting to recover the full amount. Debt sales should be to independent third parties, not subsidiaries of the original lending institution. Moreover, consumers should be thoroughly informed about the entity to which their debt has been "transferred."

Although it's not the optimal place to delve into my company's entire collection strategy, we pursue debts for a minimum of 120 days using various methods such as letters, direct calls, automated calls, emails, mailed statements, and even suspending subscription services where possible, as part of our collection efforts. Furthermore, we resort to legal action only when the debtor has consistently ignored all our attempts at communication. In my experience, when debtors engage in dialogue with their creditors, it often leads to creditors considering their circumstances. I have offered extended payment plans, reduced or completely waived interest or late fees, or even agreed on partial settlements for those who explain their difficulties. However, if a debtor is unwilling to cooperate or fails to respond to our efforts to negotiate a settlement, what other options remain for creditors?

we are inundated with robocalls daily, starting early in the morning and continuing into the late evening from unknown numbers; once the answering machine activates, no messages are left behind; such calls should be prohibited unless a message is left that includes the caller's identity and the reason for the call, specifying the names of both the creditor and the debtor

It should be noted that numerous consumers have lodged complaints about the aggressive or intimidating behavior of debt collectors. Working as a third-party debt collector, I encounter numerous harassment complaints on a daily basis. I'd like to highlight that in approximately 80% of cases, the consumers my colleagues and I interact with claim harassment and abuse. and all of them are simply unwilling to acknowledge the reality. This is the core of their complaints. Informing them about their debt is often perceived as harassment and abuse. They prefer to ignore their issues. Admittedly, a minority of debt collectors can be abusive, but the vast majority, about 98%, are simply stating facts. Once consumers understand that the problem lies with them and not us, debt collectors might gain a more favorable image. Until that realization occurs, we remain the adversaries in the eyes of consumers.

Moreover, the landlord's legal representative had ties with a collection agency , which he repeatedly used to transfer the landlord's debts into his agency , allowing the landlords to continually benefit from the write-offs with each lawsuit . In this particular case, there were eight lawsuits concerning the identical amount.

Whenever a consumer is informed about their debt being transferred, there must be a method to reach the original creditor to confirm the details. Furthermore, it is essential to maintain a documented history of transactions. I perceive a risk wherein fraudulent individuals may falsely assert that the consumer owes them money, tricking them into settling the debt with the scammer immediately. Having a transparent record, whether on paper or electronically, allows for the validation and verification of the debt's journey from the original lender to various collectors, ensuring consumer assurance, and guaranteeing that the rightful entity receives payment.

Debt collectors should be prohibited from modifying their caller ID details. They often disguise themselves as 'Process Servers' to gather data on someone else's debt. This tactic hinders consumers from filing complaints against debt collectors for breaching consumer protection regulations. due to the use of a fake identity.

I've been receiving persistent calls for someone named Sean, who neither resides here nor is known to me. Despite informing them of their mistake, the calls persist. Occasionally, they leave automated messages on my voicemail. I understand that some individuals falsely claim they aren't at the number being contacted, yet it is crucial that these agencies confirm the accuracy of the details to avoid repeatedly dialing incorrect numbers. It's uncertain whether the debtor deliberately provided a wrong contact, or if this number was recycled before my acquisition. This situation is incredibly frustrating. And although the callers never explicitly identify as debt collectors, it's blatantly apparent.

My last name is quite common, and for nearly three years, I was inundated with collection calls intended for others who shared my last name and first initial. I decided to change my phone listing from my initials to my nickname, and since then, I've received only one collection call. I am a senior retiree. I don't have any car loans or mortgages. I ensure all my bills are paid promptly, and I maintain zero balances on my credit cards. No debt collector has ever confirmed to me that they retrieved my number from the phone book, but that appears to be their method. I wish every debt collector would disclose to the person they contact where they obtained their information. I now possess a lengthy list of individuals with outstanding debts. Considering I am not a debt collector, I don't think I am legally required to keep their names confidential. However, I do feel a moral responsibility not to disclose them. Efforts should be made to prevent debt collectors from bothering innocent individuals.

I happened to be watching 'CBS This Morning' where they reported that FICO is collaborating with additional financial institutions to enable customers to access their FICO score at no cost. Many financial institutions already provide free access to FICO. However, FICO is now significantly broadening this initiative through its 'Open Access' program. __URL__ I became aware of this when FICO issued a press release earlier this month. A new detail I learned today on 'CBS This Morning' is that Discover will allow their cardholders to view their FICO score for free on their monthly statement. I believe it is inappropriate for Discover or any company to include a consumer's FICO score on a billing statement or any documents that could be handed over to debt collectors. Currently, debt collectors do not have access to consumers' FICO scores. However, they do have access to something known as a 'collection score.' This score is entirely unrelated to FICO or a consumer's creditworthiness. Discover's decision raises significant privacy issues. Therefore, the CFPB should prohibit creditors or any parties from accessing a consumer's FICO score.

The majority of firms enforce a stringent rule against personal phone calls; therefore, the legislation ought to incorporate a provision stating that "...unless explicitly permitted in writing by the debtor, a collector is prohibited from trying to reach a debtor at their workplace."

It's absolutely outrageous. While I was playing my voice messages at home, my mom overheard one. They should communicate only via text messages. Text messages prevent others from overhearing them. Receiving such a lengthy message about them being collectors and attempting to collect a debt is utterly absurd!

Individuals owing money ought to have the ability to send a message specifically to a debtor, including their company's name and a request to return the call to a designated phone number. Upon returning such calls, it should be mandatory for the collector or debtor to provide the mini-Miranda warning to the consumer. Collectors do not need to disclose the purpose of their calls in the messages they leave. The Health Information Privacy and Portability Act restricts sharing of protected details with unauthorized individuals. and this restriction should also be applied to those collecting debts.

From my observations, younger generations, including millennials and Gen Z, tend to favor digital methods of communication, such as emails, texts, and messaging apps. Reflecting on my past financial struggles, I can say I would have appreciated avoiding direct conversations with people. There's a valid worry about the lack of encryption in emails or the possibility that people might overlook the fact that their emails might be accessible to others. Generally speaking, we ought to foster communication in whatever mode suits the individual consumer best. It's my belief that emails, chats, and texts should all be recognized as written forms of communication. I'm uncertain about how to effectively include all necessary disclosures without directing someone to where they can clearly read them.

I find myself in a similar predicament—receiving calls concerning various individuals who share my surname and either of my initials. To my knowledge, none of these individuals being pursued have any familial ties to me, nor reside with me. I wish I could officially assert that I am free of any overdue debts and do not cohabit with anyone who has them. I am prepared to renew this statement annually to put an end to these calls, which are nothing but probing inquiries.

Residing in Georgia, I find that the legal system heavily favors those who own debt. A case in point is the statute of limitations concerning Mortgage debt. For example, when a primary lienholder initiates foreclosure, any secondary mortgage remains valid. According to the OCGA, the statute of limitations for any "debt instrument under seal" extends 20 years from the foreclosure date. This secondary lien can be repeatedly sold. The final entity holding it can pursue collection for as long as 20 years. Given the circumstances where homes are lost due to severe illness, unemployment, and other factors not caused by homeowner negligence, new laws should be designed to shield consumers from financial devastation.

Speaking with a debt collector over the phone, who insists on verification that a debt is invalid, and presenting your case in a court of law are fundamentally distinct scenarios. If you aim to initiate legal proceedings, then proceed accordingly. However, calling someone and demanding they convince you personally, rather than a judge, that the debt doesn't belong to them is coercive.

It's astonishing that this issue has been allowed to persist for such an extended period. This should have been tackled years ago! Put an end to companies changing names to continue their unscrupulous practices. Prohibit companies from using numerous phone numbers to deceive individuals. Prevent them from obstructing numbers so that caller ID merely displays "unknown" or even 000-0000. Stop shifting the responsibility of halting this entire sector onto consumers (who lack the power to ensure judgments are enforced). THIS IS THE DUTY OF CONSUMER PROTECTION! It is part of your designation! Your role is to SAFEGUARD the CONSUMER. Mandate these companies to clearly identify themselves upon request! For the past five years, debt collectors have been calling my mobile attempting to recover a debt from someone unfamiliar to me. This unknown individual listed my phone number as a reference for a loan, defaulted on that loan, and now I'm the one being bothered because of a stranger! When they call and specify who they're seeking, I used to explain I didn't know the person and attempted to inquire about the company's name, but they would hang up and call again later. So now, after they inquire about the person, I promptly ask for the company's name and address. They'd repeat their request for "name," and I would reiterate my request for the company's name and address. They'd ask again for "name," I'd continue asking for the company's name and address. This escalates into a shouting match, with them saying "I'll just call back later when you're more willing to provide information," and then they hang up. There's no recourse, protection, or assistance available for individuals like me. The company refuses to disclose its name, and I lack a phone number (as it's "unknown") to report their harassment to regulatory authorities. I have no means to prevent these calls to my mobile! This is my phone! I'm the one paying the bill, not them! They should have no "RIGHT," as they claim, to contact a mobile phone!

I would like the CFPB to tackle their practice of "phishing" expeditions, which involves sifting through phone directories and contacting anyone with a similar name. I was listed only with my initials, but due to my common surname, I was receiving daily calls from debt collectors until I changed my listing to a nickname. Numerous comments on this platform indicate others are experiencing the same issue, which suggests it's a widespread practice. Curiously, when I ask the phone center staff to clarify how my number got into their auto-dialer, they tend to react poorly. The typical reaction has been to abruptly end the call. I also believe the CFPB should deal with the problem of repeatedly contacting the incorrect person. If I'm not the intended recipient on the initial call, I certainly won't be on any follow-up calls. Based on my interactions with debt collectors, I've come to realize there are two reasons they keep calling me: Call center personnel are trained to persist and not accept a refusal. By persistently calling, the debt collector hopes to exhaust me into paying a debt that isn't mine just to stop the calls.

Consumers should not have to bear extra charges when making calls, sending texts, or leaving voice messages related to debt collection. Increasing the financial burden on a debtor diminishes their ability to settle debts with creditors. Debt collectors and creditors ought to cease all forms of communication to any device identified by the debtor as incurring charges, whether for calls or texts.

Credit reporting agencies should be mandated to promptly act on information about disputed debts and entirely erase any mention of such debts. For instance, I am working to get a paid lien, which is now time-barred, taken off my Credit Report. While two of the three credit bureaus swiftly removed it, one continues to refuse. I have provided documents from the court, the initial creditor, and the probate judge's office, but none have been effective. With no solution available, I am stuck with an incorrect entry on my credit report.

Perhaps I overlooked something however, I was never informed by my initial mortgage lender that my mortgage had been transferred. Maybe that is preferable because the new "owner" could be a group of investors. in my experience, the purchaser sent a notice that included the name of the original creditor. Mandating both the seller and buyer to send notices might lead to consumer confusion.

In my view, the primary reason for the prevalence of default judgments is that consumers recognize their debt and see no benefit in dragging out the matter. A number of consumers reach out to us to set up payment plans once they have been served. We inform them about their chance to voice their side in court, yet most choose not to. Their main desire is to settle the debt promptly.

Consider robocalls; answering them only signals that this is an optimal time for future calls because you're available. The account is frequently transferred from one entity to another, causing repetition. "Updating our do-not-call lists requires time..."

banks have the option to include this clause within their Loan Sale Agreements. Any buyer entering into a Loan Sale Agreement with this clause would be legally bound to avoid initiating lawsuits or making legal threats. certain current buyers might decline to purchase if such a clause is present and some existing buyers might demand a reduction in price because the inability to pursue legal action would be a drawback. In both scenarios, any inventory not bought by existing buyers would be swiftly acquired by other purchasers willing to accept these contractual terms. This solution would eliminate the need for legislative or regulatory measures since the issue would be resolved through the agreement between a consenting seller and buyer. there wouldn't be any constitutional concerns about limiting lawsuits nor would there be any postponement in execution. The only requirement would be the cooperation of the selling banks which could be easily encouraged by providing some Safe-Harbor language for banks adhering to this approach.

Indeed, they have. I've received numerous calls from the same debt collector, who uses a toll-free number, then switches to one with a local area code, and even alters a single digit in the number. Look up the number on Google. That's incredibly useful. It will reveal the company that's contacting you. It was always the same one. I believe this approach is unethical, confusing, and a deceitful way to interact with individuals. However, the overall impression from everything I'm reading is that collectors are engaging in harassment through phone calls. The appropriate action is to strengthen the laws that prohibit such practices. Currently, the sole option available to consumers is to file a lawsuit. And given the $1000 potential return, finding a lawyer willing to take on such a small case is quite challenging. This has turned into a situation that unfairly burdens the consumer, and it has developed into this over time.

To rapidly balance the situation for consumers, make it possible to contest any credit card debt that exceeds the amount at the time of default. Allowing disputes for amounts over the default sum would immediately prompt both credit card companies and debt collectors to collaborate with consumers to create a fair repayment plan, right? Currently, credit card companies frequently boost interest rates to as much as 29.9%. and might even leave the account in default status while accumulating frequent default penalties on the debtor. After closing my regional Emmy award-winning video business to care for my parents, my savings eventually depleted, and I informed my credit card providers before any defaults occurred. NONE of them could offer any solution except, "make your payment on time". If credit card firms were aware that post-default they couldn't tack on additional penalties, fees, or interest charges, they'd go out of their way to cooperate with the defaulter to reduce the debt. Citibank abruptly increased my consistently on-time 15-year-old credit card account by $5,000. I contest that excessive amount due to the reasons for my default, but Citibank is indifferent, as is the debt collector. If the debt reverted to the amount at the default time, Citibank would undoubtedly strive to negotiate with me.

I believe the CFPB should enact a rule preventing creditors and debt collectors from transferring disputed debts to another collection agency once a consumer raises a dispute or issues a 'cease and desist' letter. From my experience handling such cases, sending a 'cease and desist' letter to both the debt collector and the original creditor should halt debt collection efforts as specified by the FDCPA. However, they merely close the account with one collector and pass it on to another, forcing the consumer to start the process anew. It is essential for the CFPB to implement a regulation requiring that once a debt is challenged or a 'cease and desist' letter is sent, the debt collector must inform the original creditor of the receipt of the C&D letter.

Given that credit card agreements are considered adhesion contracts, it falls upon knowledgeable third parties to ensure these contracts remain equitable. When an individual faces an unforeseen and uncontrollable event that diminishes their income, it appears unreasonable to deny them the option to pause interest rate charges, penalties, and fees until they recover financially. They are still committed to repaying, yet their circumstances have been upended by events out of their control, and this should be considered in certain situations. It seems unjust to penalize a consumer for having their home swept away by a river, engulfed by a wildfire, or destroyed in an earthquake, among other disasters. It seems particularly unfair that credit card companies can obscure their punitive measures when a consumer, with every intention to pay, is thwarted by an act of God. Insurance policies typically exclude acts of war, yet our government permitted the proprietor of the twin towers to claim insurance despite the fact that 9/11 was evidently an act of war. I believe surveys indicate that a majority of Americans are discontented because the 2008 bailouts offered them no relief whatsoever. The 'Promise to Pay' makes no mention of prioritizing monthly payments above all other circumstances. I think judges have misunderstood the 'Promise to Pay' and that lawyers prefer the current setup as they are reluctant to address the glaring issues in credit card adhesion contracts because it might jeopardize their future earnings.

After Bayview, a debt collection agency, started managing my mortgage, I started getting calls at my workplace and on my mobile regarding my mortgage payments despite the fact that they were punctual. These calls included automated ones. I was informed that this was 'standard procedure' and advised to disregard these calls, but this infuriated me, prompting me to lodge a complaint with the BBB in the state of one office. I consistently paid on time, and our mortgage was not undergoing debt collection. Bayview functions as a debt collector, however, they ought to keep their debt collection operations distinct from their mortgage services. It should be illegal to contact individuals at their workplaces, make automated calls, and harass them when they have no outstanding debts.

I'm currently enrolled in a Senior mobile phone plan and I incur charges for every text message I send or receive. While I can send and receive texts, each one comes with a cost. Thus, it's unreasonable to impose additional charges on top of my existing expenses. I oppose the use of mobile phones for business promotions or for sending and receiving debt collection messages.

I recommend checking out the Federal Bankruptcy Rule 3001, effective from December 1, 2012, along with the remarks made during the proposal phase, and the presentation statements from the hearing that are publicly accessible. The Rule has provisions that address issues related to documentation. In my opinion, including all the proposed documentation with the validation notice is not beneficial for either the recipient or the sender. I firmly believe that additional documentation regarding the chain of title should be made available if a consumer faces a lawsuit in court.

Collection calls and dunning notices, whether sent by mail or email, ought to feature a distinct Collection ID. This Collection ID should be displayed in credit reports to facilitate tracking. Furthermore, consumers should have the option to access an online database provided by the CRPB where they can report the type of violation or issue. This system would simplify the process for the CRPB to investigate disputes and verify the presence of genuine issues.

In cases where our client(s) fail to provide proof of the debt, we proceed to close the account and inform the debtor via letter about this action. It is worth mentioning that this scenario has occurred only once or twice over the last two decades. Accounts with unresolved disputes should not be put up for sale. In such cases, the seller should bear responsibility.

Emails sent by companies or debt collectors ought to include their state of registration and registration number, allowing consumers to verify their authenticity. The sheer volume of fraudulent emails makes it difficult to trust any email claiming to be from a debt collector.

When a lawyer is identified as a 'Debt Collector' in their documentation, yet not officially recognized as a 'Collection Agency,' they escape liability for breaching consumer protection laws, both at the state and federal level, within civil court proceedings. This loophole requires urgent attention. Lawyers acting as debt collectors are not under the supervision of the state bar because it falls under collection activities (these lawyers purchase outdated debts and then pursue collection through civil court without oversight from state and federal civil courts because they operate as a legal office and are not classified as a collection agency - even though these lawyers acquire old debts and subsequently litigate against supposed debtors in civil court. I have firsthand knowledge of a prominent legal firm in Washington State that even conducts training sessions through the Washington state bar for other lawyers because handling such cases is straightforward and often results in victories.

In Florida, where I reside, it is becoming increasingly challenging for debt buyers to substantiate their claims without resorting to document falsification. At present, I am dealing with a situation where the debt's bill of sale has been altered with white-out in three different areas, regrettably, these altered documents were submitted by a lawyer who is a member of the Florida Bar Association. Debt purchasers seem to lack any moral integrity.

Compliance 2013 exemplifies the kind of arrogance I have been highlighting in my earlier comments. It is crucial to tackle the judicial perspective that treats all defaults equally, which currently rewards Strategic Defaulters while condemning INVOLUNTARY DEFAULTERS to perpetually increasing debt due to continuous interest charges. For several years, I have been delving into the topic of consumer debt and the level of Consumer Debt is RISING GLOBALLY, which is certainly not beneficial. A Canadian finance expert issues a caution about increasing consumer debt. __URL__ I can swap Canada in the title with countries like England, Australia, South Africa, China, Russia, Ireland, and many more. The surge in consumer debt is driven by a meager 2% monthly minimum payment, which acts as a gateway to escalating debt, coupled with the fact that consumers experiencing significant life-altering events leading to default cannot claim INVOLUNTARY DEFAULT in court. We allow criminals to plead involuntary for various crimes, yet this option is unavailable for law-abiding citizens regarding credit card and student loan debt!

I serve as a clerk at the local city court. I hold the position of civil clerk and I believe debtors face significant injustice under debt collection laws. The Court is not permitted to offer legal counsel thus, it's disheartening trying to explain and comfort distressed litigants who are unaware of the challenges ahead. There should be more resources available for pro se litigants who can't afford private lawyers. (which constitutes 95% of the litigants in my city). In my experience, many individuals fail to respond to summonses because they weren't properly served, simply don't care, or, more commonly, can't comprehend the legal jargon. However, I frequently receive calls from litigants seeking guidance on their next steps after being served. When answers are submitted, they are usually in letter form rather than a "legal" verified response. Debt collection lawyers typically seize this opportunity to request a summary judgment. Our Court does not reject these letters, and we forward a copy to the attorney, arranging a pre-trial conference with a judge or court attorney to facilitate resolution between the parties. The Court must follow a scheduling protocol for these meetings, yet we maintain flexibility and strive to accommodate defendants facing scheduling conflicts as much as possible. When summonses are submitted, half contain exhaustive debt information, while others only list the amount owed. I observe that it can be challenging for litigants to secure additional evidence from attorneys, despite court orders. When processing default judgments, I meticulously review the entire file, including comparing the summons/complaint with the provided default judgment, verifying the affidavit of service to ensure the defendant had sufficient time to respond, and checking for the necessary documentation, such as debt purchase proof and a non-military affidavit. Additionally, I verify that the correct interest rates and court fees are applied. The fundamental issue is that debtors lack adequate legal protection, and the Court is restricted by existing laws, even if the intention is to assist, the ability to do so is limited. Although the Court is meant to remain unbiased, in a small community where everyone is familiar, it can be difficult to witness these practices.

There was a time when a debt collector sent correspondence to my workplace. They possessed my residential address. I believe this practice should be banned as well. Who actually receives personal letters at their place of employment?

I also avoid answering calls from numbers that are anonymous, unlisted, or begin with 800. Following over a year of being jobless and only managing to secure part-time employment, I was compelled to discontinue my landline. My cell phone is frequently bombarded with unknown callers, despite having sent written instructions to all creditors not to use my cell number. I'm nearing a point where I might not be able to maintain my cell phone, yet relinquishing it would leave me without a means for potential employers to reach me. Once I secure a full-time position, I'll be more than willing to settle my debts, but incessant calls do nothing to expedite the repayment process. None of these companies reached out to extend credit to me, hence, they should refrain from calling my cell, which only increases my expenses and delays their payment. Moreover, the majority of these calls are automated with no messages left behind, leaving me clueless about the intended recipient of the call.

I've been burdened with debt for over 20 years. On several occasions, I've refinanced and cleared all the items listed on my credit report. These issues only surface after everything seems settled. Each year, they obtain a judgment against me and freeze my bank account, causing delays in managing my bills.

Although Alternative 1 appears to be the most straightforward, it conceals several complexities. Who exactly determines the meaning of "principal"? For revolving credit accounts, interest accumulates as finance charges and is added to the balance. Thus, does "principal" refer solely to the portion of the balance that the cardholder incurred (which is extremely challenging, if not impossible, for a collector to compute), or the entire charged-off sum? I recognize the complications that arise when dealing with various types of debts. However, I doubt that this approach will be effective for a significant portion of consumer debt. Alternative 2 is ineffective because it raises the question of who decides when a consumer has "defaulted" on an account. Many individuals have occasionally missed a payment but manage to recover. Therefore, this definition is too vague. This positions Alternative 3 as the most viable option, but what should be done about accounts that never received a periodic or billing statement? I suggest delineating the total by indicating the amount owed on the last statement provided by the original creditor, or, if no statement was ever created, the initial debt amount at the time it was incurred, followed by a detailed breakdown of all debits and credits applied since that balance.

Debt collectors should be prohibited from harassing the former spouse of a debtor by making persistent calls to them. It's a known practice that debt collectors use the debtor's old phone number, now solely used by the ex-spouse. Despite the ex-spouse's request for her number to be deleted from the collector's database, they ignore this and continue to call her in attempts to contact the debtor. Collectors should be mandated to promptly delete her phone number from their records at her initial request and should not contact her again. If not, she is left with no means to put an end to the harassment.

MLegz13 has shared numerous insightful observations. My elderly parents required assistance with daily tasks, although their pride kept them from admitting it. I put my award-winning video business on hold to become their caregiver. After exhausting my savings, I had to default despite maintaining an impeccable credit card payment history for 15 years. Debt collectors persistently accused me of being unwilling to pay, even though I acknowledged the debt but had no income at the time. Such situations highlight the need for debts to be frozen at the point of default, with the debtor agreeing to repay, even if the initial payments are minimal. This approach allows debtors to focus on progress rather than endure endless harassment from persistent debt collection calls. This is what motivated me to initiate the Debt Neutrality Petition. If you click the link, ensure you read the comments from over 500 individuals who have endorsed the petition. A debt collector also signed the petition, and their remarks, like those of many others, are profoundly truthful. Debt Neutrality Petition. __URL__

Only the phone number should be displayed on the caller ID. Consumers can search the number online to decide whether they want to respond or return the call. Furthermore, it empowers lawyers to file FDCPA claims against debt collectors. because we can identify the caller.

Consumers ought to be informed or alerted in advance when their debt is about to be handed over to a collection agency. Additionally, if there is a switch in debt collection agencies, it is important that consumers are updated about this change.
It is essential to inform the debtor whenever a third party proposes to settle their debt. A person who covers another's debt must disclose their identity to both the creditor and the debtor.

Should there be a centralized national database for reporting abusive phone calls from debt collectors who disguise their caller ID with fake numbers? A few years back, I acquired a new phone number which evidently was once owned by someone who failed to pay their bills as I am inundated daily with calls from debt collectors searching for the previous owner of my number. Despite repeatedly informing them of the wrong number, they disregard my statements and persistently call using spoofed numbers. This happens on my cell phone, which is illegal for debt collectors to contact. These debt collectors continue to reach out using falsified caller information. Here is a list of some numbers they've used: 808-792-8186, 462643, 858-568-7632, 805-322-4584, 706-913-1192, 808-348-0083, 858-345-4076, 858-312-7724, 908-505-9008, 800-633-2677, 252-808-7969, 571-522-0386, 407-712-3093, 213-816-2972, 804-721-3193, 678-781-4530, 427307, 858-240-4079.

Employees are terminated for making personal phone calls during work hours. During my tenure at a previous job, where our phone calls were recorded and occasionally reviewed due to the nature of our tasks, it was common for staff members to be dismissed immediately if caught on a personal conversation. Engaging in personal matters should be avoided in the workplace.

In my role as a banker at a modest-sized bank, I've experienced the collection process from both perspectives. Bankers are required to verify the legitimacy of a debt and provide consumers the opportunity to contest its validity. Whenever collection agencies approach us regarding medical debts, I perceive these individuals as unscrupulous. They show no concern for whether the debt is legitimate or accurate, or any other details. Their sole focus is on collecting, as they receive half of everything they manage to recover. You may ask them to cease contacting you, yet they persist regardless. I propose that collection agencies should be prohibited from making phone calls and should only communicate through written correspondence. If someone could clearly explain what I owe and the reason behind it, I am willing to settle the debt. However, they are unable to do so and remain indifferent.

Debt collectors are obligated to include the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed when they issue the Validation Notice. In my opinion, this serves as adequate notification that the debt is being transferred for collection purposes. I mentioned in another discussion that I do indeed believe there should be notification when a debt is sold. However, if the present creditor keeps ownership and merely assigns it to a collection agency or legal firm, the debtor will be notified when that agency reaches out to them and issues a Validation Notice. Furthermore, the collection agency or law firm might decline to take on the account due to conflicts or various other factors. Providing a notification that turns out to be incorrect would undoubtedly lead to confusion.

I worry that there exists a rewards mechanism that financially benefits those who flag consumers with possible credit issues. Viewed as a conspiracy theory, this idea holds water because it leads to increased loan expenses.

I don't have any personal anecdotes related to debt, except for my experiences assisting identity theft victims who deal with fake debts; which is quite a different situation. People are not informed about the workings of debt collection and revival. The main issue isn't about the process or whether they can ask for the debt not to be reported. The real problem is that, as things currently stand, there is no transparency on how settling a debt might enhance their credit score. It's not evident that they have the option to request collectors not to report a debt payment if it's over seven years old. Consumers are misled and hold these incorrect beliefs because there is a lack of clarity. Once more, it is the misunderstanding that concerns me - both creditors and consumers would gain if it were made simple and understandable that settling a debt is beneficial.
I bet you've never experienced having your phone number fed into a robo-dialer, have you? I must say, it's quite an enjoyable experience. Does manual dialing seem too pricey? That's unfortunate.

The issue doesn't stem from using a template letter for disputes. The real concern is that these sites and unreasonable letters mislead inexperienced debtors into thinking that creditors must provide an excessive level of proof, which isn't actually necessary. The point raised by 'stopwithspoofedcallerID' (assuming that's your actual name) is valid, as no genuine dispute should be overlooked, regardless of the format. However, it's equally important to prevent debtors from misusing the process by continually demanding unnecessary proofs.

I am still troubled by the notion that the CFPB might use "financial literacy" as a mere excuse to dodge addressing the core problem. Why not recognize those of us who have worked relentlessly to uncover the traps laid by credit card companies, especially when we've done it at our own expense and time? Credit cards represent the most lucrative profit-making operation in the U.S., surpassing even the mortgage sector. As the CFPB is aware, any highly profitable venture is shielded through lobbying efforts. This is precisely why the CFPB managed to impose fines exceeding half a billion dollars on credit card companies for their aggressive promotion of credit-protector insurance. When a venture generates such substantial profits with ease, it's difficult for people to resist the temptation to expand it further. I personally issued warnings about the credit card credit protector programs nearly five years before the CFPB levied their substantial fines. Credit-Protector __URL__ I built my website entirely on my own time and without any financial backing. I believe that my early warnings, almost five years prior, should be acknowledged. It's puzzling why someone like me, who issued an early warning without funding, isn't recognized in any way, particularly as an incentive for future generations to invest time and effort into causes that matter. Back in 2009, I also authored blogs exposing the dubious practices of Chase Bank with their credit card operations. Yet again, class action attorneys intervened, claiming 25 million dollars in legal fees. I didn't receive any financial compensation for my blogging efforts. Despite the fact that my protest blogs from 2009 likely contributed to the justified consumer anger that led to class action legal actions. Once more, I ended up with nothing. If government consumer agencies fail to recognize and value those who actively demonstrate concern, the system may never achieve genuine improvement. Daily-Protest __URL__ Bloggers Against Chase Bank __URL__ Parallel Foreclosure __URL__ Swarm The Banks __URL__ Wall Street Change __URL__ I have made significant efforts to provide financial education by highlighting the unfair practices of credit card and banking systems for several years. The tree fell, people noticed, yet no one acknowledged it.

I believe it would be beneficial to implement a rule where consumers must inform creditors of any changes in their address by providing written notification This way, if the account falls into default, creditors will have up-to-date contact details to reach out to the consumer. A significant number of consumers relocate often but neglect to update their address with creditors

Different levels of government, such as state, county, and city, establish their own sets of laws. This is something I've encountered myself. and without legal representation or being part of a larger group, consumers often face limited options. There are restrictions on the right to legal counsel, for instance, pro bono or nonprofit lawyers may not handle criminal or financial cases. I find the legal system to be quite perplexing. and I've spent the past two years trying to comprehend it all. Naturally, being older and a 100% disabled American veteran, that might contribute to my difficulties.

Massachusetts has made the right decision. It is necessary to impose strict and enforceable restrictions on how many times collectors can contact individuals within a week. I've experienced up to 40 calls in just 5 days from Citicards, and Wells Fargo calls me every 50 minutes during work hours. This is utterly disgraceful. Such relentless repetitive calling must be curtailed by legal means! Those of us burdened with debt are already aware of it and don't need constant reminders. Making multiple calls each day or week isn't going to expedite debt repayment. When you explain this to the collector, they often attribute the repeated calls to their computer systems. That's a weak excuse. Computers can be configured to dial either once daily or up to a hundred times. A single call should suffice.
Text messaging is ineffective for customers. Customers are required to pay for text messages, which is already prohibited by law for good reason.

Legislation at either the State or Federal level should impose a penalty for issuing a non-sufficient funds or "closed account" check, incorporating an assumption of culpability. A check either clears successfully or it doesn't. There is minimal ambiguity in this matter. Moreover, it would be prudent for either State or Federal law to provide the check's issuer a "safe harbor" option, allowing them to settle the check's full amount along with a modest fee for any inconvenience caused to the recipient, thereby circumventing the penalty. Michigan has implemented such a system, and it appears to be fairly just.

Indeed, the identity of a debt collector is quite ambiguous, especially when considering California law. Generally, the individual who dispatches the validation notice is a debt collector. This leads to a lot of misunderstanding.
