It baffles me how they manage to obtain my phone number. My number is not publicly listed, and I'm confident that these relatives do not possess it.

I am increasingly worried that both state and federal agencies are playing a major role in facilitating identity theft. Just last month, I was compelled to make an online payment due to what I perceive as a violation of the federal Hobbs Act by the Los Angeles Department of Building and Safety. Barely a day after completing the payment to avoid the risk of losing my home, the same credit card was illicitly used by criminals online. A few weeks later, yet another agency requested my bank documents. I sent them via fax, but they went missing! Moreover, it seemed like no significant concern was shown over the disappearance of these documents.

When setting regulations for this section, please take into account the implications of robo-calls. Refer to my observations about robo-calls leaving voicemails on mobile phones in the section regarding robo-calling. I acknowledge the importance of safeguarding privacy, however, this solution is not appropriate. Voicemails left on my mobile could be accessed by anyone with the phone, such as family members or curious friends, leading to the disclosure of sensitive information about overdue payments by the robo-caller. The practice of robo-calling does not prioritize the privacy of consumers.

Although I don't support the idea of receiving robo-calls every day, it puzzles me why consumers end up getting these calls in the first place. Receiving such frequent calls might suggest that the consumer is consistently neglecting their debt obligations. Unfortunately, there are individuals who think in this manner. If someone is facing financial difficulties, it seems logical that they would either answer the call or reach out to the debt collectors to seek a solution. Regarding regulations, I believe that limiting calls to once a week is adequate. The purpose of robo-calls is to keep the debt fresh in the consumer's mind, so when they have the funds, they'll remember to settle it. Any other intention might be seen as an attempt to irritate the consumer into making a payment. The group that permits this behavior is unlikely to pay at all, so what's the point of continuing this charade? Even automated calls incur expenses so why keep spending money without any return? Over three decades in this industry, I've come to understand there are two kinds of people: those who intend to settle their debts and those who never planned to pay.

It's incredibly perplexing whether I should pay my student loans directly to the Department of Education or to one of the numerous private lenders that have managed my loan over the years. They persist in trying to persuade me to refinance my student loan debt - highly deceptive - without revealing their charges. Currently, I can't even track a $30,000 fee that was charged twice to my balance. It feels like an inescapable maze of confusion. I foresee taking my student loans to the grave. since I have no alternative means to meet the monthly payments.

In my opinion, the primary issue stems from the financial institutions operating two systems that are not fully synchronized. One of these is the system of record, which maintains detailed account information. The other is a charge-off system, used to monitor activities following the account's charge-off. Events occurring within the charge-off system typically aren't communicated to the system of record. Moreover, the charge-off system is either not utilized or excluded from credit reporting. Another issue arises from mergers or acquisitions, where only the system of record is integrated, leaving behind the acquired charge-off system. This results in a gap concerning the specific status after an account has been charged off. When accounts are outsourced or sold, the information dependence lies solely on the system of record, excluding the charge-off system. A third complication involves consumers holding multiple accounts with the original lender, increasing the likelihood of different accounts being handled by separate agencies or debt buyers. Even if debt buyers and collectors gain access, the events that transpired on the account are generally not documented in the system of record, and the charge-off system might be phased out. The matter of credit reporting disputes hinges on whether an agency or debt buyer provides information to a credit reporting bureau. The volume of consumer data reported to credit agencies, both currently and historically, may not be precise regarding charged-off accounts, and establishing a chain of title would be costly without guaranteeing accuracy. Looking ahead, I believe the initial priority should be ensuring the accuracy of credit reporting.

When a bank intends to sell a consumer's debt, it should be mandatory for the bank to inform the consumer beforehand. The consumer should also be given a fair opportunity to bid on and buy back their own debt under terms equally favorable to those offered to other debt purchasers, which currently are typically a fraction of the original debt value. Debt purchasing entities offer no real benefit to society. Nevertheless, they are permitted to gain excessive profits by targeting financially struggling individuals for the entire amount of these debts. Implementing this suggestion would involve more than just providing a notification. since it would necessitate a shift from bulk loan transactions to enabling the purchase of individual loans under certain conditions.

I propose that the ability to initiate legal action in the jurisdiction where the consumer originally signed the agreement be eliminated. Often, consumers do not physically sign a contract, such as in the case of credit cards, or they might sign a contract in a far-off place, like paying for medical services while on vacation, or they might have relocated since they initially opened the account. In my opinion, the most consumer-friendly approach is to allow lawsuits to be filed where the consumer currently lives at the time the case begins, except in cases involving real estate, which should be handled where the property exists. Regarding concerns over large geographic areas, it's crucial to recognize that many states are experiencing financial difficulties impacting their state court civil divisions. In one of our largest districts, the number of courts where a suit could be filed was drastically reduced from 32 to just 2. To safeguard consumer interests in this context, I advise incorporating a rule section that prevents collections from selecting a court venue with the objective of hindering the consumer's participation in the lawsuit. To establish a violation, it would be necessary for the consumer (or a regulatory body) to prove that the collector's sole reason for choosing that court was to inconvenience the consumer, thereby showing intent.

Prior to entering litigation, a debtor has already been given at least one chance to settle the debt through the collector, starting with the initial demand letter, which legally must inform the debtor of their right to dispute the validity of the debt being chased. If the CFPB makes it harder to obtain a default judgment, it would essentially be rewarding debtors who opt not to address their disputes. Moreover, it can be argued that the CFPB lacks the authority to enforce new, stricter requirements on litigants in state court settings. Implementing such measures would imply that state court civil procedure rules fail to provide due process for other types of cases that do not receive the "advantage" of Federal oversight.

I've always relied on paper applications when applying for credit, and every lender I've dealt with has required extensive paperwork. I'm unsure about the process of electronic applications, but I wonder what stops someone from falsely claiming a debt is owed. It's essential for creditors to provide proof of claims, and if they aren't obtaining physical signatures, they should have solid evidence to support their claims. If you believe they wouldn't fabricate such claims, then I have some oceanfront property in Nebraska to offer you.

All workplace-related calls should be banned entirely. Disturbing a consumer at their place of work might catch the employer's attention, potentially leading to dismissal or hindering career progression. Consequently, the debt collector fails to receive payment due to their own reckless behavior.

It is often advised to contest credit reports through written communication. as the online method tends to be expedited by those employed for this task. There is no obligation to use the online approach.

My husband reached out to a creditor to discuss payments on an overdue account, aiming to update it after we fell behind because he lost his job. The account was reactivated but assigned a new account number. Consequently, my credit report now shows two accounts reflecting the same balance.

Unexpected assignments might cause customers to mistakenly pay the incorrect individual. To ensure clarity, the CFPB ought to mandate that any payment directed towards either the assignee or the assignor should diminish the outstanding debt.

My relatives faced similar challenges with Bank of America. Despite making their mortgage payments ahead of schedule each month, they were consistently marked as late. This situation is heartbreaking and it severely damaged their credit score. Once these errors occur, it can take years to restore one's credit, even if the information was repeatedly and inaccurately reported by a collector. Bank of America should face substantial penalties for such violations otherwise, they tend to disregard consumer concerns.

If emails are permitted, they should be restricted to the same timeframe as acceptable phone call hours. I propose limiting email dispatch to standard working hours relevant to the debtor's location. No business email should be sent from the office beyond the usual business hours. This reflects fundamental and proper business email etiquette. However, a middle ground could be reached regarding phone call allowances. Yet, my preference is to avoid sending emails on Sundays. Since the USPS does not operate on Sundays, business-related emails should follow suit.

Jeffreyjon, you appear to be describing the behavior of someone who defaults on purpose. On the other hand, those who default involuntarily lack the financial resources to settle a debt when interest charges continue to accumulate.
I concur. I've come across instances of this occurring and it is unfair.

Regarding medical debt, the notification should clearly specify the date and place where the service occurred, alongside the name of the attending physician (not a consultant or agency unfamiliar to the consumer), or the widely recognized name of the establishment like a hospital or clinic where the treatment was carried out. Based on my experiences, vigilant consumers who are cautious of fraudulent activities have refused to settle legitimate medical debts because they failed to recognize the debt and couldn't find an answer to the fundamental question, "Why am I liable for this payment?" When a debt lacks clarity, it is sensible to withhold payment, however, if the debt is indeed valid, the consumer might face significant repercussions for not settling it. A notification of medical debt should avoid simply reiterating numerical codes or unclear abbreviations. It ought to declare, "You received a bill on (DATE) following your visit to (PLACE)." If other related debts from the same appointment have been cleared, the notice should mention this, for instance, "You have already paid for other services during this visit, but you still owe..." Or, "Your insurance covered part of the expenses for this visit, yet you still owe...." This challenge is tied to the bewildering intricacies of medical billing, however, these complexities should not serve as a means to obscure the origin of a debt from the consumer.

I am convinced that there are three significant ways in which this practice is already being implemented. Creditors typically mandate that all their clients furnish them with updated contact information, Whenever a consumer relocates, the change of address along with other contact information updates are reflected on the consumer's credit report, Moreover, the USPS maintains records of mail forwarding protocols once a consumer has relocated.

Since I am responsible for paying for my phone minutes, I should have the freedom to decide which calls to accept or decline. When a call comes up as 'unknown', how can I be certain it's not a collection agency, a telemarketer attempting to sell vacation properties, cruise lines offering trips, or someone proposing a better mortgage rate, among others? Answering each call reduces my available minutes. which is simply unjust to me. I have resorted to blocking all calls labeled as "unknown, withheld, and private". If they are genuinely legitimate and wish to reach me, they should press 1 to unblock, just as I am required to.

The debate over states' rights versus federal authority stands as a major concern in the process of establishing rules. The diverse requirements of state laws create confusion among consumers, regulators, and industry professionals about which laws are applicable in particular circumstances. Implementing a universal rule applicable in all situations would help all parties by eliminating the current ambiguity and conflicts arising from the various regulatory levels at municipal, state, and federal tiers.

Every week, without fail, I receive at least one call from a litigant saying, "I got served with a summons today, and it states I must respond within 10 or 30 days, but it doesn't mention any court date for my appearance." I then have to explain the procedure to them and highlight the note explaining that they don't need to physically attend court to respond. I'm uncertain about how the summons could be worded more clearly, I completely grasp them, and it's not solely because I'm familiar with the paperwork, I suppose I'm just more intelligent than the typical litigant I encounter. Initially, the complaints do assert their rights to the debt, confirmed through notarized verification, yet they are unable to secure a default judgment unless they present an affidavit signed by both previous and current debt owners, which is typically included with their judgments.

You're being dishonest! For more than five years, I've been plagued by companies trying to reach someone I don't know. This person concocted a random sequence using our area code, local exchange, and four digits, which coincidentally matched my phone number, and then failed to repay a loan. I've repeatedly informed them that they have the wrong number and requested them to stop calling, but guess what? Even after half a decade, they persist in calling!

In Michigan, there was a case in 2008 where a company's Collection Agency license was revoked because of unethical conduct. Nevertheless, this hasn't hindered them; they have shifted to operating as attorneys and persist in their unethical behavior. Indeed, it is crucial for states to find a way to eliminate this loophole.

In my opinion, leaving a detailed voicemail that clearly states the reason for the call demonstrates a commendable level of diligence. Conversely, opting to make a call without leaving a voicemail is effectively equivalent to taking no action at all. This approach at least guarantees that their message reaches its intended recipient.

I gather that by "free to end," you imply the agency is accountable for the costs associated with that specific call. Exploring this further seems worthwhile. We encounter instances where the consumer lacks a landline and denies access to their mobile phone. Upon receiving a cease and desist notice, we document the account and return it to our client accordingly. Should a consumer request no contact via mobile, we remove the mobile number and send a collection notice, provided it complies with FDCPA regulations. An alternative approach might be to dispatch a settlement letter that offers the consumer an opportunity to save money while addressing the issue. The industry indeed failed to establish a commendable standard. Thus, regulation is certainly essential. I believe most of us grasp the message clearly and are diligently ensuring compliance. The approach should be dual-faceted. Consumers need to engage in dialogue about their accounts and show readiness to pay. Ultimately, if all debts were settled, there would be no reason for a call. This statement isn't intended to be confrontational. The undeniable truth is that, at day's end, debts are outstanding and our clients seek their payments. Consumers must also bear a portion of the responsibility.

Contacting a debtor while they are at work seems illogical; if debt collectors persistently make calls to an employee during work, it's likely that coworkers will alert the debtor's boss. The majority of businesses have clear guidelines regarding personal calls made on company or personal mobile phones during business hours. When a collector or creditor reaches out to a debtor's mobile phone and learns that they are currently working, the call should be ended immediately. Contacting employers should be strictly prohibited as it puts the debtor's job security at risk. What benefit does this bring to collecting debts? None at all.

I'm in agreement with RBell. Borrowers who are behind on payments typically already recognize their delinquency therefore, additional notifications do not yield any benefit. Whenever notices are sent out, they ought to contain the original account holder's name and the complete account number to clearly link any debt collector at any level with the initial account holder.

When I mentioned this, I was thinking about how some individuals fall into debt due to a medical condition that impairs their capacity to work. These individuals might be receiving Social Security disability benefits for this reason. There are instances where the medical condition is scientifically recognized to worsen under stress, such as with heart issues or anxiety disorders. As it stands, Section 806 of the FDCPA prohibits any form of abuse or harassment towards debtors. Nonetheless, what is considered abusive could vary for a debtor with a stress-sensitive disabling medical condition. I wish, and I propose, that a mechanism be established for debtors to inform collection agencies that they have a medically documented disability, highlighting that harassing or abusive calls pose additional health risks to them.

Federal district and circuit courts are presently conflicted over whether a debt's post-default assignee falls under the creditor exception. A rule should be enacted by the CFPB to classify a post-default assignee as a collector in relation to the FDCPA.

In my opinion, collection agencies are generally untrustworthy and frequently exceed their designated role. Some of them operate more like loan sharks rather than legitimate collection agencies. Additionally, their actions seem criminal, especially when involving threats to consumers and the intimidation of individuals with disabilities and elderly people. Therefore, I believe it is imperative to pursue criminal charges for their acts of concealment and harassment, along with other breaches of privacy and fairness.

Over three decades ago, a former resident at my address accumulated a debt with Household Finance. Despite returning letters marked "Addressee Unknown" and dealing with phone calls, I eventually contacted one number to inform them that the individual they were seeking no longer resided here. This prompted that particular law firm to cease their automated calls. However, after a few months, another firm began the same process. There should be a system in place to indicate when debts are transferred from one collection agency to another. It's unreasonable for me to endure this process repeatedly. Furthermore, I believe debt collectors should be restricted from using an address to obtain a phone number after two years have passed. This debt dates back over 30 years. Why would they assume anyone connected to the debtor would still reside here? I decided to search the woman's name online. With a simple search, I discovered she lives approximately 10 miles away. If I can locate her so effortlessly, why can't a debt collector, who has a vested interest, take the time to conduct a basic investigation?

Establishing a nationwide registry of collectors and providing them with identification numbers, similar to the system used by the IRS, would be beneficial. Mandate that collectors disclose their name and ID number, akin to the protocol followed by IRS staff. This approach would enable debtors to readily recognize a problematic collector or simply contact a collection agency to request a conversation with a particular employee. When leaving a voicemail, collectors are obligated to include their identification number within the message. Such a system would be advantageous for both parties involved: the debtors and the collectors.

It seems the debt collection industry is engaged in laundering money and racketeering by extracting funds from consumers for goods they never sell or services they never provide, without any original purchase agreement. Debt collectors are reportedly acquiring funds from consumers in areas where they lack the necessary licenses to sell goods or offer services. Debt collectors are imposing financial burdens on companies attempting to recuperate losses from missed payments on legally contracted sales of goods or services to customers. It appears that debt collectors depend on income from both companies and consumers without being directly involved in the original sale of products or the distribution of services.

This proposal is an excellent initiative. Currently, debt purchasers acquire debt at an average rate of 4 cents per dollar. Numerous debts are purchased at rates between 2 and 4 cents per dollar. Additionally, several other debts are transferred without any cost. As an initial creditor, I would aim to maximize the return from a debt owed to me. Therefore, if I could secure 10 cents per dollar directly from the debtor instead of 4 cents from a debt purchaser, I would be inclined to offer a considerably reduced settlement rate to the debtor (or as you describe, allowing consumers to bid on their own debt). At present, original creditors do not offer a significantly reduced rate to debtors before selling the debt for 4 cents per dollar. The majority of creditors scarcely provide debtors with a 10% discount as a settlement offer. Admittedly, a creditor might swiftly unload portfolios to debt purchasers by selling at 4 cents per dollar. However, creditors could potentially earn substantially more by presenting a one-time offer of 10 cents per dollar (or a similarly appealing amount that exceeds 4 cents per dollar). It might be beneficial for the CFPB to implement a regulation granting consumers/debtors a limited-time opportunity to receive a one-time offer, valid for a specific number of days (perhaps 45 days) from the receipt date of the letter from their creditors, featuring a markedly reduced rate. This offer would be available for a brief duration and would notify consumers that if they do not accept, the creditor will then transfer the debt to a purchaser. Such a letter would only be dispatched if the creditor intends to sell the debt, rather than as another collection attempt. This approach grants consumers one last chance to settle their owed debts while creditors experience reduced losses and increased profits, enabling them to offer more loans to consumers, provide better rates, and boost economic activity. When money circulates at higher values (10 cents per dollar versus 4 cents per dollar), rather than being stagnant in accounts receivable awaiting collection (eventually, if at all), it invigorates the economy. Implementing this rule would solely generate positive outcomes for everyone involved, without any negative repercussions. There might be a slight effect on the debt collection sector, as they could acquire fewer debts in their portfolios, but this minor effect is compensated by the substantial positive impacts on the economic landscape.

Most of the clients I assist strive to pay off their debts. The primary problem is that the majority of debt collection agencies do not provide a letter of agreement to the client until the payment is completed. Additionally, they frequently delay for weeks before issuing a receipt. I've even encountered cases where clients mentioned that the company demanded a $10.00 fee for issuing the receipt.

Breaking a promise to pay isn't equivalent to violating the law. We shouldn't continuously equate criminal law with civil law as they fundamentally differ. However, the crucial aspect missing here is the validity of interest. Let's set aside major financial institutions for a moment, and consider the scenario of borrowing funds from a friend or neighbor. If you withhold money that rightfully belongs to another person, you harm them, because they lack access to that money, which could be invested to grow or spent to enhance their living standards. This is one of the reasons interest is charged to provide compensation for the temporary loss of their funds until repayment. I'm not claiming that interest rates aren't excessively high they undoubtedly are regrettably, that's an entirely different concern. But ceasing interest altogether and allowing a borrower to indefinitely halt the repayment of their debt, simply because they borrowed beyond their means and failed to account for unforeseen expenses... I can't think of anyone who would lend money under such conditions, except perhaps for parents.

If the CFPB aims to regulate in this field, I think it is crucial to collaborate with local state judiciaries. As the CFPB functions as a federal agency, it lacks the power to direct state governments, including their judicial systems, on their operations or legal interpretations. Considering some states, such as New York, are moving in this direction, the CFPB may find its initiatives welcomed positively. However, pursuing changes through federal rulemaking is not viable in this specific context.

The FDCPA outlines specific criteria that must be met to validate a debt to the consumer. Federal law also imposes investigation requirements in other areas when a consumer raises a dispute. It is not permissible to fabricate a debt without legitimate basis. Typically, agencies that engage in such practices are swiftly halted and face significant fines, alongside cease and desist orders and regulatory measures. In essence, although debt collectors must keep and verify certain information, consumers merely need to declare, "I don't owe this" to pause collection efforts temporarily. Much like in the case of debt collectors, a few who act improperly tarnish the reputation of many who comply with the rules. I believe consumers should be obliged to provide some form of evidence when disputing a debt.

Obtain a copy of the police report and send it out to all three agencies. They are obligated to enforce a freeze on your report, and you will receive a pin, which is necessary if you ever need to lift the freeze. It's rather inconvenient. In 2012, I experienced a burglary -- resulting in a list of 14 pages of stolen items, I needed to contact all my credit card companies to have new cards issued. It was devastating -- the loss included not only my computer but also items of significant value and emotional importance. At the very least, you deserve the reassurance that comes with having a freeze on your report. And they are compelled to implement it. If not, consult with a lawyer and let them face the consequences. It's a hassle, but it's worthwhile.
It should be an option for consumers to ask that phone calls be restricted to one per week if they prefer. This represents a reasonable and ethical middle ground,

Numerous legal rulings, alongside the consensus of the FTC and CFPB, have determined that pursuing legal action or threatening to sue over a debt that is beyond the statute of limitations breaches the FDCPA. Among its various prohibitions, the FDCPA disallows any "false, deceptive, or misleading representation or means in connection with the collection of any debt." This includes falsely representing 'the character, amount, or legal status of any debt,' threatening 'to take any action that cannot legally be taken or that is not intended to be taken,' and employing any false or deceptive methods to collect or attempt to collect any debt. __URL__ Your interpretation of the law is a significant misrepresentation, as the statute of limitations is not a tool for plaintiffs to avoid being penalized for failing to file a legitimate lawsuit within the designated period.

From my observation, there's a significant difference in how various creditors handle the process when they need to hand over overdue or defaulted debts to collection agencies. In my case, I received little to no prior warning. Creditors should, at the very least, provide detailed information regarding the exact date and the company to which the debt is being transferred or sold. Receiving such a notification would enable me to understand the upcoming shift in whom I would be interacting with. The minimal costs and efforts involved in providing these notices are insignificant compared to the issues arising from failing to notify. I contend that issuing these notices could actually lead to savings over time. The notice should clearly include (1) the exact date when the debt will be handed over to the collection agency; (2) the name and address of the collection agency receiving the debt; and (3) detailed information about the agency's best practices, policies, and consumer expectations. It would be beneficial to have a single point of contact within the company, as well as access to the supervisors and owners of the collection agency. Collection agencies should be compelled to engage more openly with consumers and be mandated to operate with increased transparency.

I concur that, ideally, consumers shouldn't incur any costs. However, we mustn't allow the pursuit of perfection to hinder progress. My suggestion involved a feasible approach that grants consumers the opportunity for a hearing. Conducting hearings requires financial resources, which would eventually be charged to the collector.

Creditors should be restricted to making calls only from 9 AM to 7 PM local time, unless they obtain explicit consent—perhaps through a web form—that specifies a minimum 3-hour timeframe during which calls can be made. Furthermore, they should be capped at a maximum of three phone calls per day.

There are far too many instances of collectors failing to provide the 'mini-Miranda warning.' They contact individuals at all hours, both day and night, and often repeatedly. If they can't reach you due to caller ID, they'll alter their ID and attempt again. This behavior amounts to sheer harassment. Many resort to challenging, threatening, and harassing consumers to such an extent that I've witnessed someone seriously consider suicide. Additionally, when a debt is transferred, the original information must accompany it. Collectors frequently make these calls, often lacking details on debts that are 5 or 6 years old, and the consumer cannot recall such debts.

One topic that intrigues me is the variety of dialects. Spanish, French, and other languages have a wide range of dialects. Translating documents into every dialect of a language, such as Spanish, which often faces this challenge, would be costly for organizations. I would value any insights, discussions, and suggestions regarding the handling of different language styles.

I once knew a person who was taken to court by a debt collector, but he was never properly served with the lawsuit. Although someone was served, it wasn't at his residence, leading to a denial of his right to due process. He only discovered the lawsuit had happened when it appeared as a judgment on his credit report. He tried to have the judgment reversed due to the lack of due process, but the judge refused to do so. It is unfortunate, yet it is true that they can bypass due process and face no consequences.
The top priority should be avoiding phone calls at the workplace. This is equally crucial for the debt collectors, as someone without employment is unlikely to settle their debts.

The firm I am employed with is quite small and adheres strictly to the FDCPA regulations. However, we continually face lawsuits from lawyers acting on behalf of debtors. These lawyers depend on the reality that settling is cheaper than going through a legal battle to demonstrate compliance with the law. Our retail sector is experiencing difficulties due to the recent departure of our two biggest customers -- for this particular reason. They are now being hit with false lawsuits as well. Individuals no longer need to settle their debts; they simply send a "cease and desist" notice, retain a lawyer, and await the settlement offer. The outcome of this will be stricter guidelines for credit issuance, which is detrimental to the economy. Continuing on this path means that only those who have no need for credit will be able to obtain it.

The implementation of 'Blue Laws,' which restrict activities such as opening car dealerships and selling alcohol on Sundays, and mandating the debt collection sector to cease operations on Sundays (no communications of any form), would not impose any significant hardship. Since numerous industries that are subject to similar regulations, like automotive sales, alcohol distribution, and gambling, adhere to these 'blue laws' without issues and continue to generate substantial profits. It is advisable that the debt collection industry be mandated to fully suspend operations every Sunday.

Where in the adhesion contract is it specified that credit card agreements, which are often described as "unsecured" debt, are given precedence over all other life circumstances? Should victims of hurricanes in the Philippines or recent tornadoes in the Midwest, who have lost their homes and communities, be labeled as "defaulters" and subjected to continuous penalties, fees, and interest charges, while also having their credit scores affected? The essence of involuntary default is the occurrence of an uncontrollable event that hinders an individual's ability to meet their monthly financial obligations. Involuntary default indicates that the defaulter commits to repaying only the amount owed at the time of default, with no additional charges. I propose that the principle of a "promise to pay" constitutes a constitutional breach of cruel and unusual punishment. This is because credit card companies exert overwhelming control over their clients without explicitly declaring their authoritative stance at the outset of the agreement. The similarities between the influence of cigarettes and credit cards are remarkable. Isn't it about time for credit card products to carry transparent warnings that reveal the reality? Warning: The commitment to pay your credit card bill every month takes precedence over any natural disaster or personal crisis that might arise in your life. By allowing credit card companies to avoid displaying the aforementioned warning clearly to new sign-ups, they profit while concealing a fundamental contract principle that ought to be disclosed. Thus, the "promise to pay" has been established on misleading grounds.

Your observation about the overshadowing is indeed insightful. My remarks stem from proposed alterations to the debt collection procedures. I'm currently assisting a 72-year-old woman whose son misappropriated her identity. He faced fraud charges and was deported due to other credit cards he obtained using her name. I genuinely value your feedback but we must agree to differ on the belief that "he or she should be able to articulate that dispute". I found your thoughtful response very engaging and am eager for further discussions.

Clarification within the FDCPA regarding threats to sue by unlicensed debt collectors could simplify the process of filing claims, as these actions would be deemed as false, deceptive, or misleading. Enhanced clarity, along with stricter penalties, could effectively discourage debt collectors from breaching the law in states where they lack authorization.

The most sensible approach is to initiate legal proceedings in the consumer's home state. I find this concept quite appealing. This dedicated platform could also include a Summary of Rights under both state and federal laws. Considering the compensation structure for debt collectors could be beneficial. Based on my understanding from acquaintances in this field, collectors who earn commissions are motivated to exploit consumers. I believe the CFPB's goal isn't to ensure employment stability for debt collectors.

In my mailbox, I discovered an unsealed envelope containing legal papers from the court. I reached out to the debt collection agency to inquire about the situation as I hadn't been officially served. They insisted that subservice had already been executed to someone at my home. I conveyed that this was highly improbable because, as a caregiver, I am the sole person who would have responded to the door, and no service was received. I had to pay for filing a response, missed the deadline by one day, and consequently had to contest the default due to lack of service. The judge concurred that a valid subservice had not been conducted because the service company offered an extremely vague description: a woman in her mid-30s to late 40s, approximately 5 feet 4 inches tall, weighing between 130 and 150 pounds. Such a description is as generic as they come, and it was completely inaccurate. since this person did not exist. They even fabricated a name of someone unfamiliar to me, and upon searching it online, I found no results. On another occasion of false subservice, a description similar to the first was provided, and the supposed recipient of the subservice was named "Jane Doe". This level of deceit presents a serious risk. I have been solely responsible for caregiving for my parents, with no assistance from others. Introducing such fabrications into court documents could lead to accusations of exposing my parents to a non-existent individual at our home in the future. I was taken aback by this extent of dishonesty because on the rare occasions I've had to initiate legal action, I've ensured that services were executed lawfully and correctly. I anticipated the same treatment in return and lacking it undermines one's ability to address the situation.

Debt collectors must be mandated to provide the original credit application with the consumer's authentic signature and the initial credit approval letter. It should be obligatory for the debt collection agency to present comprehensive documentation proving the debt's validity. A significant number of debt collectors depend on counterfeit affidavits.

I should have explained earlier that I've tried to engage with creditors directly whenever I am aware of their identity and the entity they claim to represent. However, I feel they prefer reaching out to third parties. because they hope I might pay them to avoid public embarrassment. Additionally, concerning a comment suggesting creditors can contact a third party again if they reasonably believe the person knows how to reach the debtor, I completely disagree. Firstly, I am unaware of any law that obligates a third party to divulge current contact details for a debtor, so even if they do have knowledge of the debtor's whereabouts, they shouldn't be subjected to relentless harassment for months or even years for not sharing that information. Many individuals prefer to steer clear of involvement and to my knowledge, no law mandates their involvement if they aren't associated with the debt. Additionally, there isn't a straightforward or definitive method for a creditor to demonstrate what constitutes a reasonable belief. My in-laws are completely unaware of how to contact my sister-in-law because she intentionally maintains that distance. They haven't communicated for three years and I don't anticipate any change in that situation. Assuming that certain relatives must know a debtor's location is unfounded.

Simplicity should be the main focus and Alternative #2 aligns most closely with this idea, but terms like "charge-off" should be avoided. This is a specialized term used by accountants. Starting with the amount due on the date of default and adding interest, including the rate, is straightforward, however, the interest calculation could also be provided. All fees should be detailed, explained, and JUSTIFIED. The same principle should apply to other charges, with payments or credits added post-default. Presenting information this way would offer clarity.

Lawyers are included under the FDCPA, and reports of unethical behavior by lawyers are treated with utmost seriousness by most State Bars. Implementing further regulations for attorneys is unnecessary.

A straightforward approach to addressing the widespread attention on mobile phone calls, which remain the most prevalent method for reaching consumers today. I contend that certain collection agencies resort to pressuring individuals to make payments, aiming to restart the timeframe on debts that are otherwise restricted by the statute of limitations. Consumers should have access, at least upon request, to a detailed account or log showing the timeline and parties involved in the debt's collection.

Out of all the collectors who contact me about my children, only one removed me from their list after I informed them that my son hasn't resided with me for over two decades., even though I also mentioned that he is in debt to me.. After being granted complimentary credit checks due to the Target identity theft incident, I reviewed my credit report with Experian and discovered a $9,924 'collection' listed, which brought my FICO score down to 610! I was unfamiliar with Portfolio Recovery, a business based in Virginia. I promptly contacted the Office of Consumer Affairs in Virginia, describing how this incorrect entry on my credit report had impacted my overall score and my capacity to maintain a good credit standing. Each of my credit card providers reduced my credit limits, though I assumed this was a reaction to the continuous bank investigations and their way of retaliating against consumers. Everything clicked into place when I noticed this entry. What truly astonished, disturbed, and infuriated me was that Experian accepted this 'collection' entry without any supporting documents. I can confidently say that no such documentation exists. However, having been a victim of misplaced wallets and identity theft over the past two decades, I might have seemed like a plausible target for predatory companies like Portfolio Recovery. (Many online consumer complaints highlight their aggressive and unlawful methods to collect 'debts.') I plan to address this issue by notifying our Attorney General Kamala Harris and am thankful for your efforts in challenging an otherwise untouchable lobby. Whenever a consumer contacts a credit reporting agency, the correspondence ends up in Mumbai, is dismissed with laughter, and no action is taken. There should be a Congressional investigation into Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax to highlight their anti-consumer practices and false reporting, as well as the difficulty of restoring a previous 810 FICO score once entities like Portfolio Recovery are permitted to devastate credit scores and jeopardize the professional and financial stability of countless consumers.

Conflicts are left unchecked. It's simply laughable. Sending a letter to whoever the debt collectors assume is liable is purely mechanical — it lacks sincerity and does not adhere to legal standards. They employ vague identifiers, omit signatures, use post office boxes, and operate under numerous aliases for their debt collection enterprise This conduct must come to an end. The FTC mandates a 'reasonable' investigation, yet these firms fail to comply, which has become the norm. A constructive beginning would be implementing realistic, fair, and transparent laws that require companies to validate debts without making presumptions, or even worse, disregarding whether they have identified the correct individual. Any revision of rules should involve penalties otherwise, it will fail to affect an industry that has been exploiting consumers for the past twenty years. Misconduct is widespread. Additionally, there should be specific criteria for verifying medical debt due to privacy concerns. There appears to be little regard for infringing on individuals' privacy in the context of medical debt collection.

I received a notice from a doctor's office and their collection agency claiming I owed money, and they alleged I had ignored their previous notices. Firstly, I never received any such notices. Secondly, upon contacting the doctor's office, I confirmed that I have never been a patient there. The office manager even sent a letter to the collection agency to clarify this. It was obviously their error, The collection agency became agitated and impolite towards me because they had to incur the cost to erase the false debt claim from the records of the three credit reporting agencies. I really hope you take action against these reckless entities next -- and eventually, the claim was removed. While awaiting the letter, I managed to get through to someone at Equifax over the phone, I was extremely frustrated, and their response was dismissive, essentially saying, "we just report this" and similar dismissive comments. I believe there should be financial penalties imposed on these credit reporting agencies for such errors and their indifferent attitude. Their attitude is quite indifferent, as if it doesn't matter. Even after more than two years, I still feel upset due to their careless and disrespectful behavior when the fault was clearly theirs. I even contacted my own eye doctor and asked him to write a letter confirming that I am his patient. Do you think situations don't escalate? It's hard to comprehend how much this kind of problem can harm people's credit ratings, and then they have to deal with rude and incompetent individuals. If you hit them financially, you'll see how quickly they ensure no errors occur.

Creditors should be restricted to making phone calls only between 9 a.m. and 7 p.m. local time unless they obtain explicit, written consent, perhaps through an online form, that specifies a minimum three-hour window for contacting the debtor. When leaving a voicemail, they should be obligated to include the company's name, the representative's name, a callback number, and a reference number. Regarding the sale of debt, the seller should provide a 90-day advance notice of their intention to sell, informing the consumer and potentially offering a settlement option. The buyer of the debt must abide by all existing terms of the purchased debt, such as payment plans and deferment or forbearance agreements. My brother has multiple private student loans. Around a year ago, we began receiving calls from Discover about student loans, and we all thought they were sales calls since no one at my address had loans with them. Eventually, we answered one of their calls and found out that two of my brother's loans had been transferred to Discover without his knowledge. All this time, thinking it was a sales pitch because Discover only provided a generic 1-800 number and didn't mention who they were calling for, his loans were actually in default since Discover had canceled his forbearance upon acquiring the loans. When he tried to reinstate the forbearance, Discover told him they "didn't have a system for that yet."

Emails regarding collections ought to be avoided when sent to an individual's workplace email. As mentioned before, emails should only be initiated by the consumer currently, unless the consumer chooses to register an email address with the three primary credit reporting agencies.

Debt collectors and buyers face certain challenges due to Electronic Data Interchange when it comes to providing consumers with this information. In this context, the calculation methods for debts, particularly those with interest, aren't always uniform, and additional fees like statutory attorney fees and court expenses can be included in the total amount owed, which makes it complicated to compute the balance when data is exchanged daily among Trading Partners. This complexity arises because data can become misinterpreted due to delays in everyday transactions. The way computers process information differs from human thinking and what seems like a straightforward calculation to us becomes convoluted when partial payments are involved and data is shared among different entities.

It is important to note that before a lawsuit is typically filed, most debtors have been contacted by the original creditor, between two to four collection agencies, and even the creditors' legal office. This entire process can span over two years or even longer. Therefore, it's challenging to argue that the judicial system should offer special treatment to these individuals. Everyone summoned to court has had ample opportunities to validate their debt or arrange for payments before a default judgment is issued. I firmly believe that fundamental evidence should be presented. Such evidence could be a statement or a bill copy featuring the consumer's name and proof of their address at the time the debt was incurred. Other corroborating information from skip tracing services could serve as proof of address. There have been notable issues with the way debt buyers have been able to file suits and obtain default judgments with minimal evidence. Thus, while evidence should be enhanced and standardized, it shouldn't necessitate the presentation of every single bill copy.

The CFPB doesn't have to establish rules to promote non-litigation methods or avoid selling to those who implement litigation strategies. BillBartmann’s assertions are questionable regarding the claim of 10 million lawsuits annually, and it is probable that his comparative models between litigation and non-litigation have not been made public. It's essential for consumers to initiate communication with a lender, agency, or debt purchaser instead of remaining silent. In numerous regions where programs to divert bad checks are implemented, anecdotal reports suggest that firms overseeing these initiatives often intimidate individuals with threats of legal action, even when their situations don't fall under the state's bad check regulations such as checks that fail due to printing mistakes, checks that had sufficient funds when issued but lacked them upon presentation, and individuals who settle the owed amount through alternative methods within the grace periods allowed by state legislation.
